ANSWER.PARA: Major mineral developments today usually have very long lead times from discovery, let alone the beginning of exploration, to production. Australia should be now discovering the oil bodies which will be the main producers 20 to 30 years from now. This is not happening. Establishing a clear and practical regime for access to prospective land for exploration and mining purposes and security of titles is important to the industry but is even more important to Australia. The legislation now before the federal parliament would, if passed, meet the majority of the concerns.

Industry does face a major challenge with the Wik legislation—the manufacturing industry less so, but obviously the mining industry. The September edition of the Delta Electricity and Access Economics Investment Monitor shows that 21 projects worth $13.7 billion are subject to Aboriginal land claims. Wik must be passed to ensure that these projects do go ahead without undue delay. It was pointed out in the Australian today in a joint statement by the Minerals Council, responsibility for which was fully accepted by the Minerals Council:
We believe it—
the Wik legislation—
will encourage jobs and investment in Australia by improving certainty and clarity; not just for the mining industry and farmers but also for aborigines.

The industry respects aboriginal community values, culture and heritage and provides opportunities for mutually beneficial co‐existence. This is reconciliation in practice. This new relationship requires underpinning by legislation. The law must provide for timely, fair and certain resolution of issues concerning the interaction between native title and other land uses.

This is why the 10-point plan legislation now before the Senate should in fact pass the Senate—and the sooner the better for the preservation and expansion of jobs in the Australian economy, Aboriginal jobs and Australian jobs more generally.

As the debate unfolds in the Senate, I also draw your attention to the advice of Senator Bob Collins. Senator Bob Collins is not a member of the coalition; Senator Bob Collins is a Northern Territory Labor senator. He has said that we should avoid emotion and we should avoid raising the temperature. He gave advice to his own colleagues and to the parliament that people should think very carefully about their contributions to the debate. What we have seen already over there is Senator Bolkus shooting from the hip; we have seen the term `racist' falling off the lips of Labor members and senators like confetti at a wedding; we have seen about enough of the gutter‐type debate which is taking place in the Senate. I invite the Leader of the Opposition, for the first time in the Wik matter, to exercise a bit of leadership over his Senate team and urge a purposeful way forward with the Wik legislation.

Finally, there is the matter of Noel Pearson and his contribution to this debate. Two nights ago on the 7.30 Report he said that all Aboriginal people wanted was access to land for traditional purposes. He put it in terms of collecting some wood to make didgeridoos. When challenged on that and asked about ambit claims—the claims that seek exclusive possession to the exclusion of all others—he said that these claims were `not very intelligent and not helpful to the native title process'.

Yet in claim C0065 lodged a month ago in Cape York a parcel of land was claimed in an ambit claim which has this clause attached—and I invite members to listen to this. No matter that they are leases in transition where the pastoral leaseholders are still on the leases involved, this is the first clause of claim C0065 lodged by Noel Pearson and other signatories:
. . . the right to possession of the land, the waters and the resources and attributes of the lands and waters to the exclusion of all others.
It is an area 1½ times the size of the ACT, an area of 4,000 square kilometres. Here is the claim document.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a scaremonger!

—Daryl, you have had it too easy in this debate for too long. We are now going to get the truth out with regard to the outcomes of this legislation which is about providing certainty to Aboriginal people and Australians as a whole. I simply challenge Noel Pearson to remove his signature from that ambit claim if he is going to be consistent on these matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement when announcing the automotive tariff freeze six months ago. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: This is a package. If it is amended in any way the whole package will be off . . . I ask the Senate to guarantee immediate passage.

Minister, can you confirm that, apart from the tariff cuts legislation, the automotive and TCF packages are still not finalised? Will you give a guarantee that the full package will be made public and debated in this parliament before the next election?

TALK.START.PARA: —It must have been a big day at the strategy meeting this morning. The government's commitment to the automotive industry is a complete package. It is totally on course. We undertook consultations with the industry as it related to export facilitation to ensure that it was WTO consistent. Those discussions are well advanced, and the government will have legislation before the House before the next election.

—Is the Acting Prime Minister aware of a Western Australian nickel mine project called Yakabindi which has five native title claims claiming such things as mineral rights and exclusive tenure? Is the Acting Prime Minister aware that mediation, as described under the current 1993 Native Title Act, has allowed this process to extend over many years, thus effectively vetoing any significant development of the mine, adding uncertainty for overseas investors and ending any immediate development? How will the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 help sort out this complicated claim process where it seems no-one benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, there are considerable elements in the legislation which address the particular problem which the member for Cowan raises in respect of the Yakabindi Mine in Western Australia. It is another example of how claims mounting up right across Australia have not been processed successfully under the Labor legislation whereas our legislation offers a fair and proper process. There has been just one claim determined in all these years under your legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: I will offer a wager to this House that, if our legislation passes, under the proper process provided for in the Wik 10-point plan legislation, there will be a large number of claims determined, and they will be determined fairly. For those who want a bit of extra insurance, the High Court awaits a test case and no doubt will be exercised with regard to a test case at some future date. All our legislation is going to be subjected to the High Court.

In answering the member for Cowan, Western Australia in particular has reached a circumstance where there are claims, counterclaims and overlapping claims—a raft of claims—which put in jeopardy a large number of mining projects, export projects, the standard of living of Western Australians and, through that, Australia as a whole. I draw your attention to the statement of the President of the Business Council of Australia who said:

Continuing land tenure uncertainty detracted significantly from Australia's ability to draw much needed investment. Australia's national develop ment will be in jeopardy until native title issues are definitively and effectively resolved. I call for the early passage of the government's bill.

I tell the gallery, the House and the nation that our bill is about a fair outcome. It is about allowing farmers to manage their farming lands—whether they are Aboriginal or whatever. It allows mining companies to negotiate in certain circumstances with indigenous people so that mining projects can be developed, jobs created and export efforts sustained to the world.

It allows native title to be claimed on 79 per cent of the Australian landmass, no matter that the original Mabo court decision was in respect of the Murray Islands off the mainland of Australia and no matter that the Wik test decision, 4:3, was in respect of two brilliantly selected leases by Professor Reynolds. Full credit: they have played it absolutely brilliantly in selecting two leases which were non-conforming, absolutely non-typical leases and had been deserted for many decades. We are accepting the challenge of getting it right. As soon as the Senate passes the legislation, the sooner we will have more job certainty across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. With regard to the estimated 12,000 Australian personnel who were involuntarily exposed to radiation during the British atomic tests at Monte Bellos, Maralinga and Emu between 1952 and 1963, why have these veterans not received service recognition or public recognition? Why cannot these servicemen access benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act hazardous service clause? Why are the names of those who served still secret after all these years?

—In relation to the forces exposed to radiation that the member referred to in her question, my understanding is that those people exposed to radiation were covered under the Commonwealth's compensation scheme, not under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. If she would like any further answer in relation to that service, I am happy to provide further information, particularly in relation to the Commonwealth compensation scheme.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The minister would be aware of my interest in the welfare of veterans. I would like to ask him how important he considers research to be undertaken in areas directly relevant to the health and wellbeing of the veteran community. What is the government doing to encourage such research? Minister, are you aware of any other proposals that seek to address the increasing health needs of the veteran community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the member for Mallee because he does have a very strong interest in veterans' issues and is a great advocate for the veteran community, as I know many on this side of the House and many on the other side of the House are. Research into areas of health relevant to the veteran population is extremely important. The needs of veterans and war widows are special and are different as a result of their war service. In addition, their needs continue to change as they age. We as a nation and as a government must ensure that the treatment and the services made available to them are at the cutting edge of medical practice.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has just allocated something like $468,000 to four research projects covering the areas of the transition of genetic disorders, community nursing, palliative care and the relationship between social isolation and health. These are all very important priority areas for the government in terms of meeting the needs of our veteran community. The most significant of these projects is the research into the links between herbicides used in the Vietnam War and birth defects, particularly spina bifida. The government believes that there is still much to learn about this issue. To move forward we need more research and, as promised, we are funding that research.

In relation to the second part of the question, I was wondering whether there would be any interesting proposals put forward by the Labor Party in their statement last week. I was obviously setting the bar a little too high. What we got from the opposition was just one page—seven dot points, in fact. That is what they think of the veteran community. We had cliches and platitudes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you understand it?

—The platitudes rambled on and did not make much sense. Labor said that they would continue with what is already in place—in other words, the programs that we have put in place in relation to research. What they have not done is focus on—what they must focus on—the evolving issue of how to deal with the changing needs of our veteran community.

ANSWER.PARA: When it comes to costing the opposition's platform, there is nothing to cost. The approach of the opposition stands in stark contrast to what this government has done. Defence service home loans have been cut as a result of the economically responsible approach we have taken to the economy. Because of this government, an extra 10,500 veterans are now entitled to claim compensation benefits, including for service in Vietnam, the British Occupation Forces, the Far East Strategic Reserve and others.

Veterans living in remote regional and rural areas, who were largely neglected under Labor, are now getting their fair share of resources and services. The vocational rehabilitation scheme is about to commence. It is particularly important to our younger veterans. The medication management program is particularly important to those veterans who are at risk from medication misuse. The list goes on and on.
In conclusion, the shadow minister recently told a meeting of veterans in relation to Labor's platform, `There will be very little in respect of veterans.' He exaggerated, because there was nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Minister, in March last year after axing support for clothing outworkers you promised through your department, `The government shortly expects to announce the new program delivery arrangements for outworkers.' Minister, with 20 months gone and nothing yet delivered, could you explain your definition of `shortly'? How long will Australia's outworkers have to wait before they see any results?

—The member for Corio, being the principal pencil writer for the former industry minister Mr Button, should not be commenting too much about the record of the Labor Party. You know that for 13 years you did nothing at all about outsourcing problems within the industry—not a thing.
—You cancelled the program, you dill.
—I warn the member for Hotham!
—The government's TCF response quite clearly set out what we proposed to do.
—I ask the Attorney-General: has the Attorney-General announced a review of the civil marriage celebrants program? Can he outline to the House the reasons for doing so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Menzies for his question and commend him on his longstanding interest and commitment to marriage.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is some good news. Maybe the members opposite are not aware of the member for Menzies' longstanding involvement with marriage guidance and Centacare. The government is committed to ensuring that the community has reasonable access to high quality civil marriage services. As part of a review of the program, I have today released a comprehensive discussion paper covering all aspects of the civil marriage celebrant program.

ANSWER.PARA: Members would be perhaps surprised to learn of the role of civil marriage celebrants today. Just over 20 years ago, the concept was created. There are now some 1,700 civil marriage celebrants around Australia, far short of the number of religious marriage celebrants, who exceed 20,000 in number. Of the more than 100,000 marriages conducted each year, nearly half are now conducted by civil marriage celebrants.

Couples should be confident that their wedding day will be one of the most memorable days of their lives. Those who wish to have their marriage conducted by a civil marriage celebrant should be confident that the celebrant is providing a high quality service which meets the couple's needs. The review aims to make the program more relevant to the needs and aspirations of couples marrying and to ensure that civil marriage celebrants are thoroughly professional, sensitive to the wishes and needs of their clients, and committed to marrying couples with dignity.

The discussion paper covers matters such as ethics, a code of conduct for civil marriage celebrants, service standards, professional development, training, fees, advertising standards and legal matters. Once the review is completed and implemented, civil marriage celebrants will have an integrated policy framework and clear guidelines within which to operate. Couples in the community, irrespective of where they live, will have access to a choice of high quality civil marriage services. This initiative is a further demonstration of the government's determination to uphold and enhance the institution of marriage in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. On Monday, the Acting Prime Minister listed a number of industries given A plus priority for fast-track tariff reduction at APEC. Given your government's plans to automatically cut Australia's automotive and TCF tariffs in 2005, why did you not put these industries on your A plus list to ensure that our competitors keep up to the mark? If it is good enough to fast-track trade liberalisation on toys, jewellery and fish, why will you not do the same for cars and textiles?

—The member for Hotham probably does not know that the auto industry is on the A list, so that comes into the second area. While he is campaigning on this particular area, what is the Labor Party's policy in relation to all this? You would turn it further back. You do not subscribe to trade liberalisation. Your total policy is opposed to it.
—Of course we do.
—That is different from what you said before.
—Read the policy.
—That is why they call you Cheapjack: you never know where you are. You are over there one day and back here the next.
—Why would people believe you anyway—1993?
—The member for O'Connor!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Can the minister inform the House of the arrangements which this government has put in place to finalise the JORN project and rectify the inadequate management and oversight of this project by the previous Labor government? What are the cost implications for the Department of Defence and the Commonwealth?
—I warn the member for Isaacs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He, like a lot of people on this side of the House at least, has become increasingly concerned as he learnt of the facts relating to the Jindalee Over‐the‐Horizon Radar project. In 1991, the then Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, awarded that project to Telstra.
—What party was that?
—I warn the member for O'Connor.
—Telstra was an unproven supplier of defence systems with no track record in Skywave radar at the time.
—Marconi?

—Well, you know the story as to how they finished up. The total approved project cost was $1,116 million in December 1996 prices. Robert Ray, when questioned at Senate estimates in June 1995 as to the completion date, advised the committee that it would be 24 months until the radar was fully operational. Far from being delivered last June, the situation is this: Telstra is now no longer the manager; someone else is the manager. Telstra has had to make provisions for losses of $211 million in 1995-96 and $394 million in 1996-97.
—What about Defence?

—I will tell you that in a minute. That is a total of $605 million at least in losses and provisions, and the project, far from being delivered last June, is now running four years late. So it is not surprising that last December, the First Assistant Secretary, Development and Analysis in the 1980s, Dr Michael Gilligan, told the Joint Committee of Public Accounts:

ANSWER.PARA: By a series of default decisions . . . that had nothing to do with the probability of a successful outcome—we ended up with a combination that really had no experience . . .
He also said:
. . . discipline just fell away in the late 1980s.

If you add it all up—this is the figure you wanted—the complete cost of JORN, including additions, is $1,116 million to Defence, which is the proper price, plus $605 million of losses and provisions that your government racked up. That makes a grand total of $1,721 million, which is an overrun of 53 per cent on the original price. My guess is that, if you were able to get into the Telstra books, you would find that it is more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you disclose it?
—It is disclosed.
—They would have been included in the float.
—I warn the member for Dobell.

—As the Leader of the Opposition raises the subject, let me say that the member for Kalgoorlie asked that very question only the other day and the Minister for Finance answered the question. It raises the point that maybe it was not $14 billion but more if you had not racked up these losses for one‐third of Telstra.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation now is that the project is under new management. Future Defence contracts will be paid for by a combination of project milestones and earned value. This is an amazing story of pathological financial incompetence, as usual. It is a depressing but not unique example of Labor's staggering incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Is the minister aware that Commonwealth government expenditure on information technology has declined sharply by about $100 million over the last 12 months, with Australian companies especially hard hit and local jobs placed at risk? What steps will you now take to ensure that the government's outsourcing program is restructured to give Australian companies a realistic chance to bid as principal contractors, thereby helping to reverse our growing deficit in IT? Do you have an industry policy to promote our domestic IT and telecommunications industries or is your government's only initiative the outsourcing of all government IT services to overseas multinationals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Finance and Administration, I welcome the opportunity to respond to the nonsense that was just put into that question by the honourable member opposite. The question was: what is this government doing in respect of promoting Australian industry in the information technology area? The government indicated some time ago that we were going to outsource information technology on a whole of government basis subject to market testing.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been some clusters that have been put together. By the end of this week, the first cluster will receive tenders from various people who are capable of delivering the services and complying with the criteria within all the documents that have been put out for tender. Can I indicate to the honourable member what those criteria are. They very much centre on supporting Australian business, particularly small and medium enterprises.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can do all the ranting and raving you like, but I am going to give you this answer. For once you might like to have a little listen to it, because it is about supporting Australian business. If you do not want to hear it, just keep babbling.

ANSWER.PARA: The criteria will indicate very clearly that the multinationals are welcome, if they wish, to tender for this work. But they must do so by showing who their partners are. Those partners must be small and medium enterprise Australian companies. They must show what content, in terms of the hardware, is Australian produced. That is also about supporting Australian business. They must show what other work they will do for Australians in Australia outside of the government contract—not just work for the government but also work in other parts of Australia—as a consortium. On top of that, they must show where they will do work as a consortium—that is, the multinationals with small and medium sized businesses—outside of Australia. It is about growing this industry, which has growth built into it.

They must show what they will do for regional development. We know that, down in Launceston, if you wish to book a ticket on an Ansett flight, you speak to someone in Launceston. Two hundred people are down there at that call centre. They take the calls from all around Australia. Call centres and databases can be located anywhere. They need not be in the capital cities. We are interested in seeing regional development. As a government, we will promote regional development.

What the outsourcing will do for government, through its purchasing power, is provide savings. I can say that we are on target. All the indications are there over the seven-year contract to save $1 billion in respect of outsourcing. We are about growing the industry by the criteria I have indicated. We are about supporting small and medium Australian enterprises in the course of seeing this growth industry develop over the next several years.

BREAK.PARA: The jobs will grow significantly in this area. The government's purchasing power will also assist it. So do not come in here with rubbish about our not supporting small, medium or any Australian businesses. We as a government are demonstrating that very much. When these contracts are signed, it will be there for all to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister inform the House of the procedures by which doctors from overseas are accredited to practise medicine in Australia? Can he assure the House that the current high standards of Australian medical care will continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. At the moment there are a number of overseas trained medical practitioners undergoing a hunger strike in Sydney. I think it is relevant that I inform the House what the procedures are and what the situation is. First, it is my view that people who come from overseas who wish to have their qualifications assessed should be able to have that done on a completely non-discriminatory basis. To this end, we as a government have not sought to reinstate the quota that used to exist on the AMC exam. We have also said that, for doctors filling country positions before they come from overseas, Australia should look to overseas trained doctors here in the first instance.

ANSWER.PARA: We give a substantial amount of assistance to help doctors from overseas try to pass the exams. We spent $900,000 last year on 153 bridging courses that we paid for for doctors, and we spent $400,000 paying the examination fees of unemployed doctors who could not afford them. Unlike comparable countries—such as the UK, Canada or the United States—in Australia the Australian Medical Council actually publishes a booklet of test questions.

However, there are countries that have a very variable pass rate in the AMC exams. Some countries, such as Hong Kong and South Korea, do very well, and that reflects the very high standards of their medical schools. Other countries, such as Colombia and El Salvador—and Italy, for that matter—do poorly, and that reflects a different type of medical education in those countries from the situation in Australia.

The whole point of the AMC exam is to make sure that people who want to practise here are safe. That was illustrated in a recent exam where, I am informed by the Australian Medical Council, a question was asked about what you would do if, 20 minutes after childbirth, a woman had a substantial post‐partum bleed. Eighty per cent of the people got the answer wrong, and 56 per cent of the people gave an answer that would have killed the woman.

That said, since 1990, 1,600 doctors who trained overseas have passed the AMC exams—about 220 a year—and that is an addition of about 20 per cent of the total number of doctors we graduate ourselves. So the system is a fair one, but I concede that some people have difficulties. In the end, not all medical universities overseas are the same and, as health minister, I have no intention of allowing people who are not properly trained loose on the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer the minister to the bipartisan steel industry committee that he announced in February of this year. Is it a fact that the report, entitled The Australian Iron and Steel Industry , which I am waving now, has been sitting with you for over two months? The committee asked you if you would table the report. Would you indicate if you will do so and, if so, when? Will the government be announcing a formal response to the report? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Wannon who was chairing the committee that looked into the steel industry in Australia. The committee travelled widely, visited various sites in Australia, and I thought that the outcome of the committee's findings were very informative, well based and very thoughtful. However, on reflection, I looked at the Labor Party platform and saw in that that they are coming back to a steel plan—the usual old thing.

ANSWER.PARA: There is nothing new in the Labor Party's proposals whatsoever. They had a steel plan to help Newcastle before, and none of the bounty that was paid under it went to BHP's Newcastle steelworks. It is no wonder that employment fell out of it completely. The industry eventually announced that it would close down. Quite clearly, a steel plan organised by you would fail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table the report?
—In relation to the report, it is available to all members. I recommend that they read it, but it is not proposed that the government will respond to it.

—My question is to the Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, with 33 per cent of women now owning and operating businesses throughout Australia, could the minister please outline what the government is doing to support women, particularly those in small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Gilmore. We know that women are strong contributors to our economy through their work in the small business sector. Although women are frequently part‐owners and partners in many of our nation's small businesses, only a small percentage of these women run the businesses in their own right. This demonstrates a clear imbalance in the number of women in key management roles.

ANSWER.PARA: In recognition of this, the coalition government has approved $½ million for the establishment of a business incubator. The business incubator is to be delivered through the Victorian Women's Trust. We recognise that small and medium enterprises are the engine room which drives the Australian economy and is a major producer of jobs, particularly for our young people. We need to take every opportunity to assist small and medium enterprises to develop in this country.

BREAK.PARA: Called the business matrix, the program has been designed as an incubator to nurture new businesses though the start‐up period. The project will cater for 35 small businesses at any given time, and it will provide a range of services, including office space, management assistance, marketing advice, financial and legal services, and network and business mentoring.

The business matrix program was launched in Victoria last Friday and it will be administered by the Victorian state office of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. This innovative project is just one example of this government's commitment to providing tangible measures—not just the empty rhetoric of Labor's pathetic 1998 platform but practical, realistic measures to deliver greater equality, choice and opportunity to all Australian women.

It is projects such as this that will ensure that women are also able to take full advantage of this government's policies for strong economic growth and participation in the business sector. It is measures like this that will enable women in business to prosper from responsible financial policies, low inflation and the lowest level of interest rates on small business loans in over two decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer to the recent economic downturn among a number of our Asian trading partners and the potential for this to result in a significant increase in dumping from these countries. Minister, what have you done to safeguard Australian manufacturers from unfairly priced markets and imports? In particular, when will you implement the recommendations of the Willett anti‐dumping report?

—I thought this question had been dealt with a couple of weeks ago on two fronts. Firstly, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs is handling the Willett report, and he is quite adequately doing that at the present moment. Secondly, as it relates to other areas of dumping, you should wait until we respond to the total Willett report.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the enormous level of investment in the Australian mining industry and I ask the minister: is the government committed to further enhancing production and export income from the minerals sector? What would be the impact of a shift away from Australia's responsible policy on greenhouse gas emissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The fact is that a shift away from the government's greenhouse policy would place in jeopardy some very important Australian industries and the jobs that go with them. Apparently those opposite would be quite happy to go down that road, but we have a number of projects which could very well be put at risk: the Korea Zinc refinery in Townsville; the South Australian steel and energy project; the Comalco alumina refinery in Gladstone; the direct reduction iron project in Western Australia; the Chevron gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea; the An Feng/Kingstream steel project at Geraldton in the Leader of the Opposition's home state—he is not too worried about jobs in his own home state—the Bass Strait to Sydney gas pipeline; and three proposed liquid gas developments.

ANSWER.PARA: These projects amount to thousands of jobs for Australians, and the fact of the matter is that the opposition has come up with a greenhouse policy that it has stolen from the United States government. They have been over there borrowing ideas from Clinton—or is it from Gore? Perhaps they want to reposition themselves in case they are seen as wanting to imitate the United Kingdom Prime Minister.

The fact of the matter is that you have not said much about the policy. You are probably ashamed of it, because you ought to be. Your position on this immediately calls into question that very dubious document, your policy platform, which states that Labor will `encourage downstream processing of minerals, resources and energy products, and promote the sound development of Australia's coal resources'.

BREAK.PARA: This sort of goes hand in hand with the very rubbery figures that they have been promoting in relation to what they claim was their effort on greenhouse versus our effort on greenhouse. I find it amazing that they are claiming that $400 million of their expenditure on greenhouse gas has been cut; $300 million of it is related to the defunct LEAP. That is where $300 million of their $400 million was supposed to have been. That program was a labour market program, not a greenhouse program. It was not even a good labour market program! It certainly was not a good greenhouse gas program.

Then you have other tenuous links that you tried to establish, such as cuts to cooperative research centres—you claim. They do not all fall on greenhouse gas emissions efforts by any means. In fact, the reality is a simple one—that we have significantly increased expenditure in the very areas that you are claiming that we have made cuts. What you cannot bring yourselves to acknowledge is that Australia's greenhouse response represents an effective and credible package of measures to address the issue of climate change.

Really, despite the difficulties left by Labor, in budgetary terms, we have put together a very substantial and impressive package which will make a real difference to environmental outcomes and demonstrates a very real commitment ahead of Kyoto. Your greenhouse statement shows quite clearly that you do not care about jobs, you do not care about restoring the economy, you do not care even about the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, after 20 questions and answers in record time, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

—Mr Speaker, I have a rather timely question to you, in view of the latest frivolous answer from the minister. Mr Speaker, one of the measures that was announced by the government in the Prime Minister's greenhouse statement was a commitment to a review of energy efficiency in the government sector, but of course no dollars were provided for its funding. Can I raise with you the process that I would ask you to consider about reporting to this parliament about our own parliamentary departments' contribution towards energy efficiency. Might I, in passing, mention that in fact we actually have a very good record of some very significant energy efficiency gains—I think about 40 per cent since the building was first commissioned. Might I ask whether you would consult with the President of the Senate to undertake an annual review of environmental and energy efficiency practices in the parliament and to produce to the parliament—I know sometimes these are mentioned in the annual reports—a specific report on these measures against best practice settings and an external review through an organisation such as the Sustainable Energy Development Authority. Might I specifically ask whether you might consider, as an interim measure, one particular measure: that is, whether it is appropriate to establish a glass and aluminium recycling facility in the cafeteria and coffee shop areas so that members who currently throw away bottles and cans can actually contribute towards energy efficiency practices in the parliament.

—I thank the honourable member for Denison for his multifaceted question. I will be happy to take up the matter with the President, but you have already acknowledged that we are in fact world leaders in many of these areas of energy efficiency. The parliament has on many occasions received very high national and international awards for the way in which we do manage, and the way we have improved, our energy management in these last few years. As I said, it is multifaceted. I will be delighted to take it up on notice and report back to you at a later date.
—I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I have been misrepresented, Mr Speaker, by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore).
—Proceed.
—In the course of question time, the minister intimated that I was a pencil man on the Button plan for TCF industries in this country. The plan was devised—
—Where were you misrepresented?
—By the minister's statement that I was a pencil man on the Button plan for TCF industries.
—Are you denying that?
—I am denying that because the plan was devised and in operation before I ever became an employee of Senator Button.
—Resume your seat. You have shown where you have been misrepresented.

—Could I ask a question of you, Mr Speaker. You will have heard the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism indicate that he was not going to table a report but that the report would be available to all members. Would you write to the minister and ask that sufficient copies be provided to the Table Office so that members can access them.
—I will be happy to take that up with the minister on your behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

DEBATE.TITLE: RIGHT OF REPLY OF PERSONS REFERRED TO IN THE HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This brief statement is from the Standing Committee of Privileges. Members will be aware that on 27 August 1997 the House agreed to a resolution establishing a framework under which citizens may apply for the publication of responses to comments made about them in the House. The main features of the framework are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . citizens who wish to make a response to comments made about them may make a submission to the Speaker;
. unless the Speaker considers that the subject is obviously trivial or that the submission is frivolous, vexatious or offensive, the Speaker must refer the submission to the Committee of Privileges;

. the Committee of Privileges must consider the submission. The role of the committee is to recommend whether a response, in terms agreed between the person and the committee, should be published. The committee may confer with the applicant and the member involved, but it may not consider or judge the truth of any statement made in the submission or in the House.

The resolution of the House sets out the key features of the mechanism, but the resolution allows the Committee of Privileges to agree on guidelines and procedures to apply to the consideration of applications.

I am pleased to report to the House that, while the committee will consider each application on its merits, it has agreed to draft guidelines to apply to the consideration of applications. I ask leave to present a copy of the draft guidelines.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt, as the committee gains experience in this matter, it may find it necessary to refine and develop these guidelines further. The committee would also welcome any comments members may wish to make on the draft.

SPEECH.PARA: I also inform the House the Mr M. Salwin of Anders, Salwin and Salwin of Melbourne has made an application for the publication of a response to a statement made in the House. The Committee has considered Mr Salwin's application and recommends that no further action be taken on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling on some splendid work on our behalf.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's failure to develop a comprehensive industry policy which directly encourages growth in investment, exports, jobs and research and development.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The charge levelled at the government in this matter of public importance is its failure on industry policy. The consequences have been lower economic growth and fewer jobs. The culprit is the inability of the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to show any leadership, not only on this issue but on any other, and the inability of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) to win an argument unless Labor creates a sense of urgency for him. This matter of public importance is about establishing that sense of urgency on industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Where did the problem begin in relation to this? Their election promise 18 months ago was to create 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing by the year 2000. They also promised not to cut research and development funding, not to cut the computer bounty and not to weaken our anti‐dumping system: all of them core promises, all of them now ditched.

In the first budget we saw a $4 billion cut from industry support, and manufacturing was hit particularly hard. There the programs have been cut to 20 per cent of that which prevailed when Labor was still in office. And this is the sector that they were going to make the only focus for an employment target. I challenge the minister, in his response today, to recommit their target of the 200,000 jobs in manufacturing but, more importantly, to tell us what sort of progress he has made now that this government is more than halfway through its term.

We also saw in that budget assistance to exporters declining over the period and we saw research and development assistance cut by $500 million off the amount when Labor was in office. All of these cuts were dressed up by the minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in particular as an attack on `business welfare' and that they were covering the rorts. Yet they have produced not one example of a rort associated with the programs. If the minister is still going to resort to this argument today, I challenge him yet again to just give us some examples.

Your budget has also been responsible, Minister, for reducing economic growth in this country by between half a per cent and three‐quarters of a per cent. That is why we have unemployment in this nation stuck at 8.4 per cent. It should have been pushing seven per cent. That was what Labor was on track to do as evidenced by the department's own analysis of Labor's program. Since August last year you have destroyed 15,000 full‐time jobs—not one added but 15,000 lost.

Let us have a look at the minister's record. Affectionately known in some quarters as Black Jack, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has only had success, if we can call it that, at stopping things: for example, the tariff cuts in both auto and TCF. But who led the campaign in these areas? It was Labor in consultation with the industry. They just followed. We had to create the environment in which he got the win. The minister has not created anything new in terms of industry policy initiatives.

Look at steel. Rod Cameron's research showed that the weakness of the government's response to the closure of BHP's steel plant at Newcastle was a turning point in how this government is perceived in the community. If we cannot keep the steel industry in this country, what industry can we keep, Minister? Yet you indicated again today that, despite the fact that the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) participated in the steel report, it is a good report and that we should read it but that he is not going to act on it. The minister is directly responsible. He was out to lunch at the time, something that he keeps confirming every time he turns up in this place. We might actually get an answer if we put question time on before lunchtime. Next week we will be changing question time to an hour later so the Prime Minister can visit his cricket match. Can we have one that starts at 10 o'clock? We might get an answer from you.

Not only was he out to lunch when the BHP announcement was made; he was nowhere to be found to make a comment. When he was asked to attend a meeting in Newcastle he refused to go, saying he had too an important meeting. Do you know where he was? The opening of the Crown Casino. He was rolling the dice but gambling on the future of the Newcastle workers. They lost because of your high stakes arrogance and your incompetence.

What have you done to assist the automotive industry? You have adopted Labor's plan. That is what you have done. You have done the same thing with the TCF industries. You described the decision on the tariff concession orders as `dreadful' but would not lift a finger to change it.

The government has failed to meet its election commitment to reduce the time for anti‐dumping complaints from 245 days to 155 days. Instead the government called for a inquiry, resulting in the Willett report. The government has failed to implement the recommendations of that inquiry and has referred the anti‐dumping issue to the Productivity Commission. As yet, the terms of reference have not even been announced.

We have had another fiasco in this country. Because the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) made such a botch of scrapping the DIFF scheme, it counted against us in our international trade relations. He went to China and said to them, as part of the trade‐off, `We are now prepared to treat you as a market economy.' Despite the fact that we produced evidence that shows there is price fixing going on in China, this government now says China is an open market and that we will accept fixed prices on any product that is alleged to be dumped in determining whether or not to act. This is a sham.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, you negotiated a $200 million deal with the pharmaceutical industry to replace our factor F scheme. Industry welcomed the announcement, but two months later we had the budget announcement on drug pricing. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has been running away from that ever since because of the attack on him by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). That has resulted in a twofold negation of the first announcement. Industry was not even consulted. The Prime Minister holds this industry up as the shining light of his new interventionist approach to industry policy, but he never satisfies the claims. He does not know what he is doing and he cannot get his ministers to act in concert. The simplest form of industry policy is to have two departments working together. This minister cannot coordinate a thing with the health minister, and that is why the industry and future investment in that industry is under threat.

Now we hear that the government is going to announce its response to Mortimer. The only answer we got from the minister today in response to a whole series of questions was that he only `anticipates' it will be Monday week. He did not say it would `definitely' be Monday week. Isn't it funny that Monday week is the day after the House gets up? Isn't there a pattern about this? They will only announce things when they are not accountable in the parliament. Why don't you bring it down next week, Minister? Why don't you bring this great policy down?

Let us try to anticipate what it will contain. As I understand the hotchpotch of measures, it will put back some of what they took out, it will reannounce measures already announced, it will set up an investment committee and trade promotion agency as the chief substitute for real action and it will reannounce their automotive and TCF package. We will be very interested to see this replacement export scheme not only for the car industry but also for the textile industry. That is what your agreement promises to do. You will put a bit extra into R&D, you will introduce Labor's manufacturing in bond scheme, you will announce an investment facilitator, you will announce a list of industries that will get sectoral plans, you will replace some of the money cut from the export market schemes and you will re‐create something approaching the DIFF scheme. However, there will be no investment fund, no targets and no restoration of the 150 per cent research and development tax concession.

It will not be good enough because this government is not committed to industry policy in this country. This government believes that industry should be cut loose and left on its own to try to get into markets without a partnership with government. It is only Labor that is committed to developing that partnership. We have our policy out there; we announced it last week. It is built around the concept of strategic intervention, partnership, mutual obligation on the part of the corporate citizen in return for assistance and government schemes to commit to targets in exports, jobs, research and development and investment. That is what we need by way of an industry policy, but we will not get it from you.

Let us look at your performance today in question time. You made a complete goose of yourself yesterday. We thought we would test you out today to see if you could redeem anything. The minister's only answer to the first question was that he anticipates we will have an industry statement next week. The second answer was in response to a question from the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) in relation to the automotive plan and the export scheme. The minister said the scheme is complete, then he said it is well advanced and discussions are continuing. Can you make sense of that gobbledegook? Do you know what you are talking about, Minister? On the question of outworkers, you said Labor did not have a scheme in place, yet the whole question was: why did you cut Labor's scheme and still have not replaced it? How can the Labor government have been doing nothing on this, Minister, if you cancel that which we were doing?

There are two APEC lists, Minister. The automotive industry is not on the A plus list and the textiles industry is not on either of the lists. Why aren't you fast tracking these sectors? Why are you going to unilaterally expose these important sectors with us cutting tariffs in the year 2005 with no obligation on the part of our trading partners? It is a complete mockery, and that is why industry still does not have confidence in you.

You could not even cope with the question on outsourcing and industry policy for IT by the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans). You flicked it to another minister, and you have policy responsibility for it. You are earning money under false pretences, Minister. You should give it back. You are interested in savings for the government so give it back, because you are doing nothing.

On the steel industry, we have got the position where you found it interesting; it is a good report, but you are not going to be responding to it. They will love that in Newcastle. Black Jack at the casino, but now he is not even going to respond to the steel industry report. Then, on the issue of dumping, again he buck‐passed on the basis of saying he did not have responsibility for it. I happen to have a letter here which I would like to table, if the minister will allow me. In response to a query, this is what John Moore said:
I am responding as the minister with responsibility for anti‐dumping and countervailing policy.

And yet you come into the House and say you do not have responsibility. Give the money back, because you are a joke. You are not performing for industry and you are not even keeping your side up over there.

We have heard stories about you—you have got this appointment to London; the staff are moving on. We had the story the other day of Mr Abjorensen who went to a senior cabinet minister and put this proposition: `This was arguably the worst government Australia has ever seen.' The senior minister responded, `You're expecting an argument with a proposition like that, but you will not get it from me.'Yesterday we were in the position of the minister admitting in the parliament to being that minister, but then he wrote a letter saying that he had misconstrued it.

I woke up early this morning, at a quarter to six, and there was a Fawlty Towers grab on ABC radio. For people who are Fawlty Towers fans, it was the waldorf salad grab. There was a great quote at the end where an American tourist, having been insulted, says to Basil in frustration, `This is the worst hotel in western Europe.' But the major, who was always sticking up for the person running his home, said, `No, no, no, there's a worse one in Eastbourne.' Here we have that position in relation to the minister. You can almost tell the story here. The journalist says, `Would you say that this is the worst government that Australia has every had?' And John Moore—or whoever else—replies, `No, Billy McMahon's was worse.'

You are a joke as a government. You cannot introduce any policy or any direction. We are now taking a book on how that senior minister was. I must say that you were clear favourite yesterday, but the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) is closing fast on you. There is Peter Reith. He is second or third favourite—not a bad position to be in; one back, nicely placed, ready to run. This is a government that is a shambles. It is a government that has got no leadership, no commitment to industry policy, and Australians and their jobs are suffering as a consequence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt about it. After the editorials in the Financial Review , the next best laugh you get is from the industry spokesman for the Labor Party—the battler from Bordeaux. There he is, squawking about who has been paid too much. But he takes a long extended trip to have a look at the new French government—from the Left Bank and then from the Right Bank. Then we catch the TGV down to Bordeaux, have a little bit of a look around and take in a few sights down there. No trouble. From there we go to look at the unemployment problem in Venice. We are off to Venice. We catch the Orient Express , no doubt, across to there. And then, to top it all off, we go down for a couple of days in Rome.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, what a trip—looking at unemployment and left-wing governments. And you come back here and talk about some people putting in a long day's work. Getting up at a quarter to six in the morning to watch Fawlty Towers is about the size of your industry policy. It is about the size of your strategy committee too, because they really did make a bit of a boner today. They were out there having a right old go, but they failed the lot. It is no wonder, Simon, that you are saving up for Christmas. It is not far away, mate. If I were you, this time I would go to Alaska. There are not so many wines up there, so it might not be so bad for you.

When the Labor Party fell out of government, a totally disgraced government, they left this government with a deficit of $10 billion, a deficit which they claimed did not exist and which we then had to approach in the oncoming budget. They left an unworkable set of industrial relations laws. They left the lowest business investment on record and the poorest overseas perceptions of our investment climate. Australia's share of world direct investment was four per cent in the 1980s; it is now less than three per cent. That is a reflection of what goes on under the Labor Party.

Business expenditure on R&D as a share of GDP was 25 per cent lower than the OECD average. There was an average productivity improvement of just 0.9 per cent—half the world average this century. An accelerating manufacturing trade deficit went from $7.7 billion in 1982 to $27.5 billion in 1995. It is no wonder that when they left government with that record the current spokesman for industry was moved to say on Radio National on 11 August 1997, `I think we have to admit that we didn't get it all right.' It was after he came back from that trip to Bordeaux that he talked about those little situations where he had to admit that they did not get it all right.
There is no wonder that he went to the archangel of the Labor Party, Graham Richardson. In the Bulletin on 17 June 1997, he said:
The greatest failures of successive Labor governments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a coherent industry policy.

Well, hear, hear! You got that one right. When you look at the state of the nation when they fell out of government, there is no wonder that there was a huge task to be done by the government. The government has accepted that complete picture.

We have turned Labor's financial deficit around. We will have halved the government debt by the year 2000. Interest rates in Australia have had five official cuts from 7.5 to five per cent. We have the lowest borrowing costs for business for very many years. On top of that, inflation in Australia is at a record low, making it certainly a 30‐year low.

Business investment shows strong growth—almost 20 per cent in the year to 30 June, 1997. The Reserve Bank, for the first time in my time as minister, has noted that growth of more than four per cent would not have a bad effect on the balance of payments or interest rates within Australia.

So I welcome the opportunity, under those circumstances, to look at what we have been doing in relation to industry policy in Australia. For the whole of this year, the government has had a very busy time in terms of addressing all of the matters left by the previous Labor government. At the end of this year, by the time we have the response to the Mortimer inquiry, more will have been done on industry policy than John Button or the Labor Party ever thought of in 13 years.

I am pleased this MPI was put on this afternoon because it gives me the opportunity to look through the history book to see just what we have done this year. Let me start with the pharmaceutical industry. The pharmaceutical industry investment program was initiated—a $300 million program, not $200 million as was suggested by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean)—to encourage investment in that area. In a world in which major pharmaceutical companies are increasingly merging, and in which there is more capital investment and a huge development program, it is very important that we keep our eye on research and development in this area. There is no doubt that development in pharmaceuticals does lead to open‐sided areas of research and development. They are no longer concentrated in one place such as New Jersey. Any country can attract pharmaceutical R&D with the right R&D programs.

BREAK.PARA: In response to the Productivity Commission's report, we then moved on the automotive industry. Here is another example where nothing much had been altered for many years. The Labor Party program would have run out in the year 2000, and the government decided to act decisively by deciding not to carry on the program. It had led to very significant reductions in employment, and there was huge uncertainty within the industry. They did not know what was going to happen past the year 2000. The government addressed this in its policy statement in June.

A high priority was to ensure that the next round of major investment was carried forward into the auto industry. We did this in no small measure and got commitments from the corporations themselves to investment between now and 2005 of something like $6 billion. All the major corporations that are currently manufacturing here are committed to a new round of model development in this country. Combined with that is the huge spin‐off that goes to the auto component area, which is very important indeed and certainly world class in itself.

We then moved to addressing the TCF industries. This was a very difficult one indeed because of the regionality of those industries, the high levels of unemployment and because investment in that area is hard to come by. Nevertheless, in September we announced a comprehensive package in response to the Productivity Commission report. The expectations are that we will get $400 million worth of new investment between now and the year 2000 on a per annum basis. The certainty corporations get from that will enable them to develop investment programs, to get up new product and to carry out whatever amalgamations may be necessary in the future. It was very important, when we looked at what the right response would be on the TCF and auto industries, that we looked to the investment, the employment side of it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look to Labor.

—If they looked to Labor and looked at their platform, they certainly would not be voting for them; that is one thing for sure. We made quite certain the responses were in a way in which all companies in those two sectors could have a future in terms of committing themselves. If corporations are prepared to commit to investment programs, there is no reason to suspect that those programs will not be very successful in the future.

BREAK.PARA: On top of that, the government then asked Mr Mortimer, Mr Goldsworthy and Mr Cutler to carry out a series of reports into the whole of industry assistance in Australia across the board, including the IT area and computers and intellectual property.

The inquiries were wide ranging and came up with a number of significant recommendations. I am quite sure the industry response will blow the Labor Party away. It is a complete and comprehensive report on the whole of industry in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: So at the beginning of this term we had a shambles. We corrected the budget and then moved to pharmaceuticals. We then moved to the responses from the Productivity Commission in relation to both auto and TCF. We then set up a series of inquiries—Mortimer, Goldsworthy and Cutler—and their recommendations have been answered by the government. That has been a comprehensive program for the whole of the year and an outstanding achievement by the government as a whole.

I want to tell the House about the three goals which all of these answers were directed towards. Firstly, there is investment. We will not get employment growth in Australia, and we will not have Australia in the competitive position we want it to be in, unless we attract significant investment to this nation. That must be the hallmark of what we want to see in the next few years.

To do that we firstly addressed the fundamentals in the budget in terms of the debt and the question of industrial relations and all areas of industry. We are now moving to taxation reform. All of these will indicate the positive nature of Australia for investment in the future. When you look at the last five years you will see that $40 billion of foreign investment has gone into South-East Asia. All of it has swum past Australia. Why? Because we have not been a competitive nation to attract that investment. Governments of the day have not gone out there and sold the story of what we have here. This government will address that problem, because without adequate investment you will not have the necessary record to build on.

Secondly, there is research and development, the most significant driving force in Australian industry. You must have research and development and innovation for the future. As a consequence of that, we wiped out the Simon Crean rorts for all his mates, all the rorts around the place—

This concept enables private money raised by the private sector to be managed by the private sector and to be applied to research and development identified by the private sector. As a consequence of that, these funds are there to pick up the research and development which has been so successful. I hope in the future we will see far greater outcomes in this particular area.

Innovation in itself is extraordinarily important. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Amendment Bill 1997 amends the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 in order to implement refinements to the administration of that act to rectify certain problems identified during its initial implementation. The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act gives effect to Australia's obligations as a party to the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction, usually referred to as the Chemical Weapons Convention. The convention bans the development, production, acquisition, stockpiling, retention, transfer and use of chemical weapons and provides for the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons.

Australia has long supported the Chemical Weapons Convention as a key international instrument in the fight against the spread of weapons of mass destruction and was the sixth country to ratify it on 6 May 1994, following the passage of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act three months earlier. Three years later, on 29 April of this year, the convention entered into force and less than 27 days later Australia's initial declarations were submitted to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.

The Chemical Weapons Convention requires Australia to make regular declarations concerning activities with chemicals listed in its schedules and activities producing discrete organic chemicals. The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act allows the Chemical Weapons Convention Office in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to collect, through a system of permits and notifications, from chemical facility operators the information required to compile these declarations. National inspectors appointed under the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act have the power to inspect chemical facilities to ensure compliance with obligations imposed by the act. Certain facilities are also subject to inspection by the Technical Secretariat of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.

The task of preparing Australia's initial declarations has highlighted some aspects of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act, which needs to be refined in order to simplify its overall administration, to promote compliance with it and to ensure more effective fulfilment of Australia's commitments under the Chemical Weapons Convention.

A key element of this amending bill is the provision it makes to automate the annual permit renewal process in the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act. This will simplify the compliance obligations for each company or organisation requiring a permit, but maintain the annual reporting cycle that is needed to fulfil our convention obligations. Simplification of compliance obligations should reduce the possibility of inadvertent breach of the act. It will also provide for continuity in the relationship of each permit holder with the Chemical Weapons Convention Office.

This bill also provides for clarifications of some outstanding technical issues to be implemented through regulations under the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act. The Chemical Weapons Convention is a complex instrument and a number of technical issues related to its implementation remain unresolved internationally. Some of these issues bear directly on which industrial facilities should be subject to declaration and inspection requirements. Understandings clarifying these issues are expected to be reached by the organs of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.

The bill also includes amendments which refine its secrecy provisions, streamline certain administrative procedures and provide for applications, notices or reports to be made by way of electronic lodgment. To reinforce the effectiveness of Australia's compliance with the Chemical Weapons Convention, this bill also includes amendments dealing with minor drafting errors identified in the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994.

Before concluding, I wish to thank all those from Australia's chemicals industry for their input with respect to this amending bill. In particular, I acknowledge the very important and useful contribution made by the Plastics and Chemicals Industries Association.

Australia has been at the forefront of efforts promoting the effective implementation of the Chemical Weapons Convention. The refinements to national implementing arrangements in this bill demonstrate an ongoing commitment by the Howard government to that goal. I present the explanatory memorandum to the House.
