SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continuing my remarks on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill, the government's proposal for a common youth allowance. During the few minutes I had available to me last week, I took the opportunity to outline the basis of the legislation and what it attempts to accomplish. I had then moved on to discuss a recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which is entitled Youth employment: a working solution .

SPEECH.PARA: The committee took some 15 months to interview and consider submissions from employers all over Australia—from employer bodies, from educational institutions, from educationalists, from parents, from business people, from ANTA and from representative bodies of the education and training industry itself. We held forums where we interviewed 303 young people—themselves involved in secondary education—who are looking forward to some future and to getting a job.

One of the central themes of the common youth allowance is that we want young people to remain in formal education and/or training for as long as possible. There is a very good reason for that: Australia has an unacceptably high rate of youth unemployment. This report dealt with the other side of that equation—that is, youth employment, not unemployment—but there is no doubt that the two are interrelated.

We would wish that, when every young person has received at least an initial education—in terms of literacy and numeracy, in terms of understanding society and in terms of learning how to be able to learn again in the future—they be given the opportunity to continue with that education through training courses at our institutes of TAFE or with private training providers to obtain specific skills for doing specific kinds of jobs in specific industries, or that they be given the opportunity to go on to university and to obtain a more broad based and higher level qualification which would prepare them either for some specific career or for a broad based generalist career.

It is true that entry level jobs in Australia for young people have shrunk, particularly over the last decade. One of the reasons for that is that unskilled jobs have fast been disappearing from the Australian landscape. It is appropriate that young people obtain the right kinds of skills and education before they go out to enter the formal job market itself. Not only that; they also need to approach that job market with the right kinds of attitudes.

One common theme amongst the over 300 young people with whom we discussed these issues in great detail was that, if you want a job, there are jobs available. It did not necessarily mean, because they were young and they were still in secondary school, a full-time job or exactly the job that they wanted. But if you wanted to work, you had the right attitude to work, you could speak, you could write and you could read, then there were jobs available and you could get a job. It might not be exactly what you want: it might be clerking in Woolies or in Coles; it might be cleaning up in a hairdressers' salon; or it might be a skilled job at one of the McDonald's outlets—but, nonetheless, a job. I was highly impressed by the attitude of the young people that we talked to throughout Australia. We talked with young people not only in the capital cities but also in the regions and in the outback—indeed, all over the country. I was very impressive by their attitude to work.

Some of the recommendations that we made are perhaps appropriate to this debate on the common youth allowance. The first recommendation concerns the government's funding of labour market programs. That includes those programs which, one way or another, help find jobs for young people and pay for them to be in employment because, for some reason, they have either missed out on part of their education or they have not been able to find work for whatever reason. When labour market programs are being developed, the government should favour programs which address attitudinal and other barriers to learning and employment in individuals. That is code for saying that labour market programs need to address pre‐employment training. One thing that employers all over the country told us is that the first thing they look for in an individual they employ is attitude. The second, particularly with young people, is literacy and numeracy. The third, way down the list, is specific skills for the job.

It is interesting that we had some debate in Victoria recently about the acceptance by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) of a training program for young people in school at the McDonald's training facility in Melbourne. Some of the trendies thought that was pretty terrible, because they seemed to hate McDonald's. The committee heard over and over that where an employer had a short list of potential young employees, if one of those individuals had worked at McDonald's, the chances of that individual obtaining a full-time job were greater than they were for any of the others. Why is that? Because McDonald's gives young people personal skills and attitudes, such as how to show up for work on time, how to work with colleagues cooperatively, how to approach customers with a smile and willing service, how to produce high quality work quickly and how to be responsive to your employer's needs and the clients' needs, the ones who come in to purchase. Those attitudinal skills are highly important.

Another recommendation the committee made is that literacy and numeracy are of critical importance to our young people. That is another good reason for young people to stay in school. It is also a good reason for us to do a much better job in basic literacy and numeracy teaching in the very early, formative years of primary school, which are perhaps grades 1, 2 and 3. It has been recognised nationally, and absolutely accepted by everyone in the business, that if a young person has not achieved satisfactory levels of proficiency in reading, writing and maths by the time they reach age 7 or grade 3, the chances of them being kept behind in their studies, ultimately failing and winding up on the dole scrap heap, in correctional institutions or on the streets or whatever are enhanced immensely.

We are saying that if we fail to teach any young child to read, write, count, add, multiply and divide, we have failed that child absolutely. Our recommendation is that literacy and numeracy teaching needs to be comprehensive, which means that you need to go about it every day in the early years of primary school. If that means it displaces some of the other curricula that has been crowded into primary schools, so be it; let us be done with the other curricula. There is also the quaint but important recommendation that you teach literacy in the morning, not in the afternoon after lunch when the children are sleepy and less attentive. It is the most important grounding element of their entire education program. Fancy trying to study Australian history if you cannot read. It is not difficult; it is impossible.

The committee recommended another very innovative device that would go with the common youth allowance. The committee recommended that the government institute a national youth guarantee, which entitles every Australian under 21 who has not attained year 12 at school to a funded place at a high school, TAFE or a recognised training provider to complete their year 12 education or its equivalent. As I recall, the common youth allowance says that if you leave school before you are 17, the dole is no longer available. You will need to stay in school or in training.

The Commonwealth, through the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and other programs with ANTA and the state, is working very hard to try to increase the availability of skills training in our secondary schools. That includes apprenticeship training or other kinds of skills training that will help lead young people into jobs or, if they do well enough in that extra training, get themselves back in shape to be able to study again, and then perhaps go on to TAFE courses or university at a later time. The committee believed it is important that if young people leave school early and find they need further training, we say to them, `Look, as long as you undertake this work, by the time you are 21 we guarantee that you can have a funded place at TAFE, with a private training provider or back at school to get the equivalent of a year 12 education for yourself. This will help you to ultimately find a job and live a rewarding, self-satisfying and self-fulfilled life.'

The committee made a number of recommendations regarding the standards of the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the portability of training outcomes. In this way, young people who take a course in one location can take that qualification to another state or territory and have it recognised. People will then not look askance at the piece of paper and say, `You're from Victoria and I'm in New South Wales, so we will not consider that piece of paper. You will have to start all over again.'

Another important issue that teachers tell us about is that, for some young people in secondary school, by the time they are in year 9 or year 10, the teachers know that they are likely to leave school without finishing. New programs are being developed—and the Commonwealth is beginning to fund some of those programs—to try to retain those young people who are likely to leave school without completing a year 12 qualification, with programs which are different, which will excite their imagination, keep them interested in the learning experience, and keep them in touch with formal education.

Most of those programs involve some experience with real work. The student might spend one or two days a week in a real job, and the rest of the time in formal training mode within the high school. The formal training time should also, in my view, include attitudinal and pre‐employment type training. At least one hour a week should be devoted to trying to impart work skills to these young people who do not have work and real life experience—whose parents may not work, and whose grandparents may have never had a job—and to teach them about the things that employers are looking for so that they can successfully take their place in the employment market.

BREAK.PARA: If those kinds of programs are successful, then we will not need the common youth allowance, except to the extent that it replaces Austudy. Wouldn't it be a fantastic day if the common youth allowance were about helping students with their living expenses while they are studying? That would be a terrific day, because then we would not have high youth unemployment. We would not be destroying young lives. We would not be creating a situation where future generations of young people will not thank us because they will not have the work ethic at all.

The committee made a series of recommendations regarding a national youth wage. We said that it is time to do something radical, something different. While we made substantial recommendations regarding curriculum advice, which I think are perhaps the most important recommendations we made, nonetheless, it is clear that, with youth unemployment stuck at between 25 and 30 per cent, we need to do something radical. The coalition members of the committee believe that we ought to take youth wages out of the hands of the tribunals. We ought to take them away from the control of the unions, and we ought, by statute, to establish a system for a national minimum youth wage. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my address on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 this afternoon by complimenting the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) not just for his very fine address but for the contribution he made to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. He has moved on to greener fields, but very few members of the parliament have shown such singular commitment not just to youth employment and youth education but, more particularly, to those aspects of youth employment and youth education which can be facilitated and improved. I have been on inquiries with him, and he is a very persistent questioner in cross‐examining people on what factors really affect the educational and workplace needs of young people.

SPEECH.PARA: Moving on to the subject of the youth allowance, one of the most demoralising things I see in my electorate is young people on Austudy or partial Austudy struggling to stay at university or TAFE, who find that down the street there is a houseful of young hoons, who are all on the dole, who sometimes might even have a swimming pool if they can get a house for the right rent, or they are spending their time on the beach, and they have a better lifestyle than the young person who is making a contribution to society and his future. That is very demoralising for that student and his parents. For someone on the margins of either studying or dropping out, the incentive not to go on and do something useful with your life becomes very attractive.

To some extent, this bill tries to go to the heart of that problem. Recent statistics in the Wide Bay‐Burnett area where I come from show that, with 36.6 per cent of young unemployed—that is an extraordinarily high and unacceptable figure—school leavers have never had more pressure on them to find a job which will lead them to a satisfying career. From their point of view, things look bleak unless they are better equipped.

With such high unemployment in the area, there is an added incentive for young people to drop their bundle and, in doing so, drop out of school. Research shows that there was strong school retention growth during the 1980s—the percentage had risen to 77 per cent by 1992—but that last year it started to drop away again, and it was down to 71 per cent. The male dropout rate was higher than the female rate.

A second reason for wanting to keep young people at school and in training is not just to keep them off the street, as the common idiom has it, but to keep them focused and motivated so that, when regions like mine go through tough times, the young people are given skills with which to advance themselves when better opportunities arrive.

If you provide unemployment benefits at a higher rate than Austudy, young people are not going to want to continue their studies or further training if there is some incentive for them to drop out or if they are not achieving well at school. The students' view often is that they do not think they will get a job anyway, so why bother studying or training. Young people need skills such as computer skills for clerical work; retail training skills, as the retail trade is expanding; trade skills in plumbing, carpentry, mechanics and hospitality; and short‐course skills to drive bobcats, operate cranes or whatever.

Many of these courses today are delivered either at a school or at a TAFE. Many schools are now taking up these school to work opportunities. In my electorate, the first of which came from Toolooa High School in Gladstone, we even have school to apprenticeship programs. But, if you do not keep students at school for grades 11 and 12, they are never going to get that opportunity. When we were young people—there are many people of my age group in this parliament—getting a job was not a problem. Today, young people are expected to have many more skills.

Why are we replacing Austudy and unemployment benefits with a youth allowance? The government recognised there is an increasing number of young people who do not go from school straight to full‐time work. Young people need to be able to make key decisions about education, training and employment without the pressure of losing financial support. Young people should complete or further their education and this bill removes the incentive to leave education early or to choose unemployment over education and training. Those young people whose circumstances change slightly will no longer have payments cancelled, thus giving them the flexibility in training and looking for work. For example, an unemployed person who undertakes training will not be required to switch to Austudy for short periods, nor will a student who drops a subject lose their entitlement altogether.

This legislation also encourages those families who can to provide support to their children until they reach the age of financial independence. The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has said this legislation tries to defy diversity. I disagree. The legislation recognises the diversity of individuals more than the current legislation. Many young people do not find full‐time work straightaway; they undergo training, part‐time work and more training until they find a full‐time job. This legislation also recognises the discrepancies of payments between those who are studying and training, and those who are looking for work. Why should someone be paid more for looking for work than a person who is studying? That seems to me to be illogical. This is a question many young constituents and parents often ask me. I put it to the member for Werriwa: what makes looking for work more important in terms of the amount of payment than studying or training or, to put it another way, investing in your own future?

The legislation goes on to recognise the diversity of the community, and the new system will not affect payments for those young people who collect Abstudy, assistance for isolated children, pensioner education supplement, disability support pension, sole parent pension, parenting allowance, the veterans' children education scheme and wage top‐up agreements for apprentices and trainees. Unemployed people over 21 years of age will receive the newstart allowance, as before. If this does not recognise the diversity in the scheme in our communities, then what does?

The member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) has been bleating in the chamber and in the media that the government is abolishing payments for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds, again proving Labor is equally irresponsible in opposition as it was in government. Young people aged 16 to 18 will not get the youth allowance if they are not studying or training. There is a need to encourage children to stay at school.

The legislation goes on to recognise that it is not all smooth sailing for young people in those instances where young people suffer from a short‐term illness, substance abuse, family problems, caring for the ill or the frail, parents at home and so on. But the average 16‐year‐old will not be paid the common youth allowance if they are not studying or training, and I reiterate that point.

The member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) has called the youth allowance an assault on Australian families. On the contrary, many Australian families will benefit from the introduction of the youth allowance, including many families in my electorate of Hinkler who send their children away to university. They will receive assistance for the first time. For others, it will be a return to parental love, guidance and—dare I say it in this chamber—discipline.

Our electorate office has roughly 12 different types of computer programs which we use on a regular basis. We have word processing, databases, Internet, e‐mails, spreadsheets, Pagemaker and so on. My staff are highly skilled and computer literate. They have good communication skills with the public and senior government officials. They interact with community leaders in business and industry. That is the environment that a lot of young children will go into. If they do not stay at school and if they are not well educated, if they are—in the words of the member for La Trobe—not literate and numerate, they are going to have a very tough time of it.

Keeping young people at school at 16, 17 and 18 years of age, or in training, is not a bad thing. We need to give children time to plan and to organise their lives. They need to know how to spell and to write a good letter. They need to know a bit about the world, about economics, about history, about how Australian government works, and so on. They need to know a lot about many things. While some of this knowledge is gained on the job, I could not employ a person who did not have at least some experience in computer skills and customer service. I think that is one of the reasons that at times over the years we have suggested in this place that perhaps we should have juniors in our office, but successive governments have not agreed to that. I think part of the reason for that is that, for young people to participate effectively in an electorate office, they must have those basic skills.

I do not think my office is any different from any of the small businesses across Australia. In everything today there are electronic developments and computerisation of all sorts of things from cash registers through to computing, right through to accountancy. Again, if those skills are not in place, those young people are totally disadvantaged in getting a job.

I have heard it said that if a young person completes grade 12 they have a 60 per cent better chance of obtaining a job than a young person who does not. That is a very sobering thought. At the end of the day, no young person can seriously hope to drop out of school without qualifications and pick up a job, as they might have done 30 years ago. The point bears reiterating once again: young people aged 16 to 18 years of age will not be eligible for the youth allowance unless they are studying.

The days of young people copping out, three or four moving into a house, living the life of Riley and going into their 20s without any experience whatsoever of work are finished. And so those sorts of things should be finished. In effect, they were holidays at taxpayers' expense. The member for Werriwa has said that we live in the `post‐traditional age of families' in order to describe the Labor Party's policy which, incidentally, contributed to the dependency on the Australian social welfare system and the taxpayer. It has robbed many young Australians of their birthright. First and foremost, we must look after our families. We must encourage families to look after their children and encourage them to achieve.

When 16‐year‐olds drop out of school or TAFE because they do not like it and sit around watching television every day, I cannot see parents being very happy with that in the long term. It will bring home to parents, in a very forceful way, that there are other opportunities for their children. I think it will encourage parents to take up the traditional role of nurturing, caring, loving, guiding and perhaps disciplining their older children.

What I can see is many parents insisting their children put themselves into a TAFE course or go back to school to get qualified and, as such, be eligible for a decent job. By encouraging families to take responsibility for their children, we put the onus of raising children in their teenage years back onto the family, but we support families giving their children focus and opportunity through the youth allowance.

It is not the government's job to raise children. I have said this in relation to the changes to child care where it applies to non-working parents, and I say it again in this instance when it comes to our older children not making an effort to find jobs or to undergo training. This legislation will benefit more people than the current legislation. It is fair, it is equitable and it gives them goals.

The question that follows from this is: who benefits from this legislation? First and foremost, the whole community will benefit, including taxpayers. Seventy thousand young people who are studying or training and living away from home will get rent assistance. The average will be $31.30 a fortnight. Also, 41,200 students will benefit from the abolition of the $1,000 per annum Austudy minimum requirement. These aspects seem to have been lost on the member for Jagajaga. That does not bother me much because I know a few of my constituents will appreciate receiving even a few dollars a week to send their children to school or to university.

A family living in Gin Gin, just outside Bundaberg, and sending their child to the University of Central Queensland campus in Bundaberg—a 30 minute drive—or in the Boyne Valley sending their child to the Gladstone campus of the same university, will probably appreciate $20 extra a week to encourage them and to make it easier to get their children to and from the university.

Labor has forgotten how hard and how expensive it is to raise a family. So I would not expect the member for Jagajaga to appreciate how difficult it is in regional areas where the average family income is less than $20,000 a year. They are not the only ones who will benefit; 16,600 students will benefit from the independence criteria which are more lenient than those for Austudy.

Fifteen thousand unemployed and 19,500 students, most of them under 18, who are living away from home and/or are independent will benefit from receiving an increased rate of payment and 9,300 continuing students aged 25 and over will benefit from the alignment of rates with the youth allowance. Thirteen thousand four hundred families of youth training allowance recipients will benefit from access to the family payment initiative. In short, lots of people will benefit.

Legislation creates social expectations, and Labor's badly planned social security legisla tion implemented over the last 13 years has fostered, whether we like it or not, a welfare mentality. Legislation which creates a climate such as the one we have in Australia today is indefensible and this government has accepted the responsibility to change it, just like we accepted responsibility to pay back the $10.5 billion black hole debt.

Do not believe young people are the little horrors the media paint them to be or that society would sometimes say they are. Most are upstanding young citizens who make an effort to contribute to the economy and to society. Many young people strive to get qualified and get a job, but the system is too forgiving on those who do not make an effort to contribute. We can attribute that to the social environment which Labor fostered, especially over the last 13 years.

Finally, looking over the whole ambit of this problem, we need to get those young people in the age group of 16 to 18 years of age better equipped to compete in a much more demanding work force. On all the inquiries I have been on with the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training that have involved young people and the suitability for education, one thing has come through clearly: disadvantage can be linked to literacy and numeracy, or literacy and numeracy can be linked to disadvantage. The experts disagree with comes first, the chicken or the egg in that instance. That there is a correlation between the two things is beyond any doubt. If we extrapolate from the young people that the member for La Trobe talked about at the very critical ages of their school development out to the 16‐ to 18‐year‐olds, it follows that if they are going to take advantage of the new programs, the new computer skills, the school to work opportunities, the TAFE opportunities, the university opportunities that are folding out before Australians, then there must be encouragement and support. That can be found in this youth allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 , I would like to thank all the mem bers who spoke in the debate. While I recognise the two members who have spoken here this afternoon, the debate has been a long one and many have contributed. The non‐government speakers in this debate have focused on several specific issues to which I will refer.

SPEECH.PARA: Several speakers have suggested that the requirement that a young person aged under 18 must be in education or have finished year 12 to qualify for youth allowance should be omitted from the bill and that those who have not finished year 12 should be able to enter into an activity agreement which would be included in case management.

It is worth reminding the House of Labor's own rhetoric in this area. For instance, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) told the Age newspaper on 15 November that Labor would recognise the lack of entry level jobs for 16‐ to 18‐year‐olds and design policy to support this group to stay in school or training.

The youth allowance provides positive incentives to realise this objective while also making provision for those young people for whom education or training may not be a reasonable requirement. For instance, in cases of illness, the imminent or recent birth of a baby, living in a remote area, recent job loss, inability to secure an appropriate education or training place, caring responsibilities, learning difficulties, major personal crises, homelessness, major disruptions to the home, substance abuse, substantial part-time study and/or workload, having been a refugee prior to claiming youth allowance, being subject to a community service juvenile justice order or some other special circumstance which may include non-employment related case management, youth allowance will be available. Employment case management will continue to be available to young people who are not on youth allowance through FLEX, that is, flexible labour exchange services, from May 1998.

It has also been claimed that the education sector will not be able to cope with the numbers of students who stay on at school or seek education or training places. The government is funding a range of innovative programs to improve education and training opportunities for young Australians, particularly in the area of vocational education and school work experience programs.

Funding has been provided through a number of measures. Firstly, the Australian Student Trainee Foundation has been allocated funding of $9.9 million for each financial year for its core operations, that is, approximately $40 million over four years. The budget also increased funding by $10 million in 1997‐98 and each of the following two financial years to support workplace coordinators, that is, $30 million over three years. Secondly, the National Training Authority Ministerial Council agreed in 1996 to provide $80 million over four years—1997 to the year 2000—to state training authorities for allocation to schools for vocational education and training. Thirdly, the school to work program funded for $23 million over the four financial years 1996‐97 to l999‐2000 promotes effective and reliable pathways from schooling to employment for young people.

The honourable member for Jagajaga expresses concern about the extension of the parent means test under the youth allowance to unemployed customers aged 18 to 20. However, she fails to explain why it is acceptable to means test Austudy recipients but not their peers who may be unemployed. This inconsistent treatment sends the wrong message to young people that they may be better off on the dole than in education or training. For example, in a family on $30,000 per annum with an unemployed child and a student child, both aged over 18, while the student would be paid $111.60 per fortnight, the unemployed sibling would be paid $174.80 per fortnight. That difference of almost $60 a fortnight could be a persuasive argument against taking up education or training opportunities despite the obvious longer term benefits to the young person of doing so.

It has been suggested that the rules for de facto couples should be aligned with those for other social security payments, so that people would not have to have been in the relationship for two years to be considered members of a couple for youth allowance independence purposes. The arrangements for members of de facto couples under youth allowance represent a compromise between arrangements under Austudy and those under other payments under the Social Security Act.

Currently, de facto relationships are not recognised at all in relation to Austudy independence, whereas de facto couples are recognised under the Social Security Act regardless of the length of the relationship, although there is no financial gain for people to present themselves as members of a couple if they are not genuinely in a relationship.

The youth allowance position of recognising relationships of two years duration is a fair compromise which recognises that young people in long‐term relationships should be considered independent, without providing an easy means for young people to avoid having their payments parentally means tested. Young people who are in a relationship where one or both are not considered independent—for other reasons—will not be subject to the partner income test.

It has been suggested that the youth allowance should be indexed every six months, in April and September, in line with the arrangements for pensions and other social security allowances. The youth allowance indexation provisions are not in fact contained in this bill at all—they will be introduced in the forthcoming consequential amendment bill—and they therefore cannot be amended now. However, the intention is that indexation will occur once per year only, based on the June CPI, effective on 1 January each year.

This is in line with current arrangements for Austudy. It is also in line with current arrangements for social security allowances for single people aged under 21. Contrary to suggestions that the latter are indexed twice yearly, in fact they are not. Clearly, it would be ludicrous to move to twice-yearly indexation when both major customer groups are currently accustomed to indexation only once a year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is not inclined to oppose any of the three amendments. I will make some brief observations about them. The first is that if Minister Kemp wishes to take away from the Secretary to the Department of Social Security the approval for courses of education for the purposes of the youth allowance, the opposition will not stand in his way, although I do suggest that the minister will be creating somewhat of a rod for his back. We will be following with great interest the sort of approval and disapproval that he brings to these particular matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only join with his Victorian Liberal colleagues in suggesting that, contrary to 20 or 30 years of public rhetoric, he is in fact one of the great centralists of federal government and the federal parliament. I am told that, in the Victorian Liberal Party, to call him a centralist is the greatest insult that can be levelled. I am sure to be called a centrist or a centralist is an insult in the terms and conditions of the Victorian Liberal Party.

The third provision concerns the maximum age requirements for youth allowance. The amendment provides that a person simply has to be undertaking full‐time study and have turned 25 to reach the maximum age. It is poor indeed for the government to be moving amendments at this late stage which deal with fundamental questions like the maximum age for qualifying for the youth allowance. This is sloppy drafting which in fact is typical of the whole bill, and the opposition expects there will need to be a raft of government amendments in the Senate to correct similar problems in other parts of the legislation. We will be watching those amendments with interest. But, as I mentioned, we are not inclined to oppose any of these three government amendments to the youth allowance bill.

(3) considers the Government's response is inadequate and its rhetoric does not match either its election commitments or the committee's findings; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue from where I left off last night in the debate on the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill . The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is currently supporting our legislation. His support for unconscionable conduct being included in the bill is unchanged. The member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) said that the opposition would try to amend the legislation to remove unconscionable conduct from the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: After 13 years in government, 17 reports and reviews on fair trading, the ALP have not learned any lessons about small business. There is a history of procrastination, reports, reviews, white papers, et cetera, but they still have not learned that small business wants an end to uncertainty. This bill is about a new deal and a fair deal, which is what small business wants.

The evidence presented to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry further exposed the abuse of market power and unfair conduct in commercial transactions. The intent of the committee and the government was to make changes to induce behavioural change on the part of big business towards small business.

By nature I am not a person of regulatory mind, but in this instance it was necessary to introduce some changes. There has been an ongoing debate on the Trade Practices Act for something approaching 20 years. By way of confirming that I am not overly regulatory, the other major inquiry I did was in 1988 in the Victorian state parliament, an inquiry into `electricity supply and demand in Victoria beyond the 1990s'. That led to deregulation of the whole electricity industry in Victoria and was the forerunner to the establishment of the national south‐east power grid in Australia.

I want to come back to the unconscionable conduct provisions and talk about the changes to the Trade Practices Act. The government has decided to establish a new small business provision in that act, section 51AC, that builds on well understood consumer protections against unconscionable conduct to small businesses and provides further protections against the business conduct issues identified by the standing committee. It is based on established legal doctrine in that there is already a body of case law on the protections available to consumers against unconscionable conduct. The approach will also provide small businesses with the protections they need against a range of unfair business practices.

The new small business provision is designed to induce behavioural change in dealings between large and small business and ensure the commercial dealings are carried out on a more equitable basis. It balances the need for fair conduct in commercial relations with the need to maintain an open market and does this without compromising the basic principles of contractual relations and commercial risk which remain at the core of our free enterprise economy. A bargain or commercial transaction will be deemed to be against conscience where one party is at a special disadvantage and the other party unconscientiously or without conscience takes advantage of the opportunity thus placed in their hands.

The key is still that a party has to be in a position of special disadvantage, so the new amendment will not provide relief simply because there is some difference in the bargaining power of the parties. The new legisla tion goes beyond this base point, however. Our proposed section 51AC suggests the court must take a number of items into account when hearing a case of unconscionable conduct against the small business. Many of these items matched those proposed by the fair trading committee report in its suggested prohibition on unfair conduct.

In fact, our provision in the government's bill is an amalgam of the factors the court may have regard to in the existing consumer provision with the final five factors of the committee's recommendations. It is set out in the bill and it goes through all of the recommendations that were contained in recommendation 6.1 of the committee's report. Clearly, these items, as spelt out in proposed subsection 51AA(2)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), (i), (j), (k) and (l), are the additional provisions which the court may take into consideration in deciding unconscionable conduct.

Clearly, all of those items go to the heart of the issues raised by the committee. One of the important things that I do want to mention about the work of that committee is the way the committee operated. I believe that one of the major reasons for the success of the committee in developing that report was the composition, the membership, of the committee. They had extensive experience in business both large and small but no formal legal qualifications. That was important. None of the members of that committee—I took the opportunity to check this—from either side of the House had any formal qualifications in law. So there was a very clear intent by the committee—and they did an excellent job on this report—for the recommendations to be formulated as clear statements of principle rather than formal legalese.

This led to the opportunity for the bill to be introduced into the House, which makes it very clear that recommendation 6.1 has been adopted with all of those enumerated factors which I went through included in it. An important adjunct to the inquiry that we conducted is the fact that the government has taken all of those things into consideration without destroying the intent of the committee.

BREAK.PARA: The government's response to those recommendations subsequent to the tabling of that report included good legal advice. I wanted to mention a couple of other issues as well which relate to the matter that I just raised—that is, the government's decision to establish a new small business provision, proposed section 51AC, in the Trade Practices Act.

This particular matter had a very long history and went right back to the days of Charlie Blunt. Then there was the Beddall report and the Schacht report. In all, over the time of the previous government there were 17 matters of inquiry and no action for small business. Small business were very frustrated by the inaction of the previous government.

I have taken great satisfaction from being able to work with the members of that committee. They were very clear on what their intent would be. I want to particularly mention them: the members for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), Petrie (Ms Gambaro), Lowe (Mr Zammit), Canning (Mrs Johnston), McEwen (Mrs Bailey), Mallee (Mr Forrest), Aston (Mr Nugent), Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin), Scullin (Mr Jenkins), Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), Rankin (Mr Beddall), Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and Corio (Mr O'Connor). They did an excellent job in bringing that report to fruition. It was supported by both sides of this chamber.

In conclusion, I want to place on record my thanks to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). It is great to have a government which has small business representation in the cabinet. That has been very well received by the small business community in Australia. He is doing an excellent job. I compliment him for his open-minded approach to what appeared initially to be a very difficult task. No doubt with that open‐minded approach we were able to introduce this measure which constitutes this legislation. It has been, as I indicated to the House, subject to ongoing debate for more than 20 years.

The legislative amendments provided in the bill are key elements of a multidimensional reform which, once implemented, will constitute a landmark change for all small business, will improve business conduct in Australia, will find a balance towards fair trading in the Australian economy and, together with the government's other initiative New deal: Fair deal will encourage businesses to deal with each other fairly and reasonably. The government's framework will build a sophisticated, innovative and strategic Australian industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 and the amendment, I should firstly lay a few ghosts to rest. The suggestion has been coming through over and over that there were 17 reports under the previous government and that nothing was done. The Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), knows that is not true. He is very aware of that. In fact, the report goes through a lot of the changes that were made. He also quite rightly paid tribute to a number committee members who worked quite hard on this inquiry, and I agree with him on that. I note that my colleague the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is on the speakers list. He is now becoming quite famous as the fatuous phantom from Paterson—fatuous because he trivialises most things he touches and phantom because he does not come to committee meetings. He attended one hearing. Of all the hearings we had, he came to one only because it was held in Canberra. If you look at his record, you will see that between September last year and February this year he did not come to one meeting at all. He missed virtually all the inquiries, yet he talks about what a great report the committee he is a part of produced. Phantom because he does not turn up; fatuous because he trivialises everything he touches. The fatuous phantom will be speaking later in the debate and we look forward to his comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us in the previous government who were involved in the inquiry in 1989-90 attempted to warn current government members what to watch out for. One of the things to watch out for was the word `unconscionable'; we had been got by it before. As the chairman of the committee well knows, the recommendations of the previous report, the Beddall report, were not adopted but they were modified. The spirit was picked up, as we were advised by the then bureaucracy.

What was asked for was not provided. What was provided was a new section on unconscionable conduct. Up until now, as the report demonstrates, that has not been able to be used. The committee very carefully, after a lot of advice and consultation, shifted to `unfair' because `unconscionable' does not work. It is a bit rich for the chairman to now tell us that `unconscionable' is okay. After going through all the discussions on that word, he knew that the bipartisan agreement was that `unconscionable' was not a goer. You have been tripped up by the bureaucracy again. And you have the gall to come in here and talk about previous governments and previous reports.

That report, which was a good report, had been gutted with your approval. Do not betray your own report. We were ignorant in 1996; we did not realise the implications of it. We are not lawyers and were not able to provide a legal response to it. We were advised that the word `unconscionable' was applicable when, in hindsight, it is clear that it was not and will not be in the future. The government's shifting of that one word is absolutely critical, as is the amendment to reinsert it. The adoption of the committee's report—the report which the chairman oversaw and spoke in favour of in the parliament when he introduced it back in May—is important.

It is also important to go to the next step and to understand a couple of things. Firstly, the nature of business has been changing dramatically in Australia and in various parts of the world. Governments and communities have responded in different ways, as have the states. We have seen the contraction of the traditional small corner store and the small retailer. Corner stores are almost a thing of the past. The advent of shopping centres has been one part of it, but more importantly there has been a taking over by large chains of the areas of business that were normally supplied by smaller operators.

An example is the expansion of Woolworths, Coles, Franklins, Bi-Lo, Jewel and the few others expanding into bakery products, confectionery and all kinds of things and opening, in some cases, for 24 hours a day seven days a week. That is changing the nature of business entirely and causing major problems, which is one of the reasons why the report recommended a national code of tenancy. Part of all of this is to do with who can sell what in what set‐up. Take, for example, a butcher in a shopping centre who discovers, out of nowhere, that Woolworths is suddenly selling meat, as is Coles, in the same centre. What is more, they are open 24 hours a day and selling it for less than he can buy it for.

In a similar situation, a shop that sells cigarettes and gifts finds that the Coles supermarket in the centre sells cigarettes at a lower price than it pays the suppliers, the manufacturers. In fact, in that one centre at Garden City at Kotara in Newcastle not only did that occur but also the shopping centre management allowed in a cut price cigarette retailer. So you had what was a reasonable business at one stage being cannibalised by the introduction of a competitor on a nation‐wide franchise buying at nation‐wide levels at a much better buying price than a sole trader. Subsequently, and partly in parallel, the chains operating in the same centre were selling at a lower price as well. So what has happened to that business? That business has suffered grievously. That is the kind of change that is occurring.

With the report and the inquiry, we were trying to change the rules a bit to ensure that the giants—whether they be the giant chains or the giant managers such as Lend Lease, Westfield or AMP—were not simply consuming the small traders. `Consuming' is a very appropriate word. It is not an exaggeration. In the last 10 years we have seen the conversion of goodwill into rent. It was put to us very clearly that a business now has a business for as long as the lease lasts. When the lease is finished, you are finished. That was made absolutely clear during the inquiry.

In many cases people have paid good money for a business which on the surface was excellent only to find out that after the two‐, three‐ or four‐year lease was up for renewal, either they have had to pay higher rent, or rent which is not affordable, or they have had to go. Cases have been brought to us. One example was given to us where a tenant attempted to sell the business and the buyer disappeared, but the buyer came back after they closed and went into that centre. We are seeing a conversion of what was goodwill into rent. The ratio of rent to turnover is increasing, and the figures on that are fairly evident. It may vary from centre to centre, but the overall trend is very clear.

Within that, we are also seeing a potential fraudulence in the value of these centres. Again, I do not say that lightly either. If we go to the Hansard and look at the evidence of the Australian Institute of Business Brokers and the Institute of Valuers, we see that, in both cases when asked if centres were overvalued, the answers were yes. In fact, the Institute of Valuers was asked, `What's going to happen? What will be the result?' The answer was, `Armageddon.' In other words, disaster.

There has been a factoring in of rents at the surface level, at the gross level, into the valuation of the centres. It is distorting quite seriously the actual value, which in turn is putting more pressure on centre managers and owners to extract more and more rent. On the one hand, we are seeing the chains saying, `Let us sell what we like for as long as we like and for as many hours of the day we want or else we will go and open our own centres.' On the other hand, we have clauses and turnover figures which demand ever increasing profitability out of the same centre.

For example, in Charlestown Square at Newcastle, we have a situation where the centre management and a number of the tenants are now locked in combat in the courts, would you believe. Tenants are paying lawyers to fight their landlord. There are a few examples of this, but perhaps the most controversial example is the attempt to convert part of what would be the public space, the open space, in a centre into a coffee lounge or eating area.

In these centres, the open space, the amount of free space in which people can congregate, walk, and feel some sense of spaciousness, is now being converted into more and more rentable space. The Lake Macquarie council rejected that application for 70‐square metres, so Lend Lease appealed to the land and environment court. In the mediation process the council offered a smaller figure of 50‐square metres. It was trying to seek a solution. That has been rejected by Lend Lease and they are back in court next week, I think.

Here we have the situation where tenants are paying lawyers to represent them against landlords. What kind of business are we in? What kind of mentality is it when people who have major investments for themselves and their families in these centres, and whose future depends on the success of the centres, are being forced into confrontation and legal battle with giants like Lend Lease? This did not happen last year. The events I am talking about now did not happen last year, before the inquiry, during the inquiry or four years ago. They are happening right now. Next week they will appear before an arbitrator in the land and environment court to make a judgment. The landlord versus the tenants—no-one wins.

There are other parts that concern me, and this is why I think these amendments are so important. It is important that there is a national code of tenancy. It is important that there are national standards because, quite frankly, in many cases the landlords are bigger than the states. The variations from state to state have always been a problem and always will be. It will be very difficult to get a uniform code across the country. We need to have a uniform code. We are, after all, one country, not eight.

The need for a national code was canvassed strongly in the report and was adopted unanimously. The fact that the government is not supporting it is a grievous weakness on its part. It has been rolled by the big end of town. The government that supports small business has been rolled by the big end of town by that part of the report, and for many people that is the only part. For many people out there, the tenancy laws are the only things that they have. That is all there is. All the rest is for nought. If the landlord can dictate the terms and cannot be trusted, then all the rest is worthless.

BREAK.PARA: In that context I have to explain that, having now spent quite a lot of time talking with landlords and with tenants, I no longer have confidence in the management of the centres that I represent. I believe I have been misled in those situations and I believe that the tenants are not getting a fair go. I personally cannot act on their behalf unless there are laws made by this parliament to empower me and my colleagues. All of us need a federal code and federal laws so that we can make representations to federal bodies and to federal ministers. I am sick and tired of being helpless, watching things happen which are unjust and having no-one to turn to because there are no laws covering it at this level.

An example of what is occurring right now happened in recent weeks. A particular tenant in Charlestown was having difficulty. The landlord was aware of that back in February or March this year. They spent a lot of time trying to improve that business and worked very hard at it. It was quite coincidental, but within a matter of days that tenant was visited by a prospective buyer who told him and his partner that, if he waited a fortnight, he would get the business for nothing, and that his fixtures and fittings were worth only $1,000—that was all he would get for them. He also had a letter from the landlord terminating his lease and a letter from his major supplier issuing a summons for unpaid accounts. So within days he had three major events.

I have talked to the landlord and I have talked to his major supplier and I accept that these things may have been coincidental. But I do not accept that, between May and now, when both the landlord and the tenant were trying to get that business to become successful, there were liabilities built up. When the tenant moved out, he gave a fortnight's notice, which was incorrect. The notice was extended for four or five days, almost a week, and they were charged an extra $3,000 for those days.

Having been in partnership since May, which we were all applauding, guess who pays the bill? The tenant was slugged for the whole lot. Those partners have no money. They have gone broke. They have had to walk out. But the landlord was getting a new tenant instantly, therefore he was not suffering. The whole months of experiment and testing were then put down to the tenant alone.

When the tenant put to his various creditors a repayment schedule offering particular cents in the dollar, having lost a lot of money himself in the meantime, guess who did not agree? The landlord. That means that the landlord, who has control, effectively has the potential to bankrupt these people. And for what? They have already lost their shirts. These are people with some pride and some dignity. They have been in a business and it failed. They have been punished more than enough.

What did the landlord say to me? He said, `I have got a duty to my trust holders.' I said, `Your trust holders have investments in an organisation which is almost certainly overvalued. What are you doing about that?' The same management had put to me some weeks back that they would be sensitive to these people's misfortune and that they were very mindful of the circumstances. Yes, their actions were pre‐emptory in the way it had been terminated and they had done things which could have been done better, if I can put it that way. When the departure occurred, the bill turned up for the full amount. Now they are settling for 50 per cent. These people have nothing.

The parliament may well hear some more about those matters because, between now and when this bill finally gets dealt with, we will see case after case brought forward—whether it be in Charlestown Square, Garden City or another centre in Australia. I am encouraging all my colleagues to keep this in mind because tenancy laws are fundamental.

This government cannot walk away from the most important part of the report. The bulk of the submissions were from tenants. The bulk of witnesses were tenants in centres. The bulk of the heartbreak was suffered by tenants. The bulk of the problems in small business that we were exposed to were to do with the need for a national tenancy code.

This government has done what it accuses us of doing. We may have been excused for that seven years ago because there were no examples. We put in place what the bureaucracy and the big end of town said would work. The report proves that it does not work. So what is the government doing? It is putting back unconscionable conduct, knocking out unfair trading from the report and not adopting a national tenancy code. Speaker after speaker has said how the report is being adopted in full. That is misleading—even more, it is deceitful. The report is not being adopted; bits of it are. The key part is not.

Do not think this is over. Tenants out there still want a national code. Tenants out there are still suffering. They will go on suffering until we end up with a decent national system that protects people who pay rent. These people are consumers and they are entitled to some protection. They are entitled to a uniform national system because they are all Australians. I am optimistic that the Senate will agree with us and adopt the report in full. Then the onus will be on those government members to come on board and support their own report. It was a good report. Let us not undo the good work by gutting it the way the minister has. If it is fully adopted, it will work. If it is only partly adopted, this battle and these troubles will go on and on. This is the one chance that many people will have and it must not be missed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be speaking on this very important bill, the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 . I want to cover a couple of points raised by the previous speaker, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). It was amazing to listen to the contributions of the first two speakers for the opposition: first, the shadow minister, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who spoke for some 30 minutes about retail tenancy; and then the member for Newcastle also spoke about retail tenancy. But the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Finding a balance is not only about retail tenancy.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the Labor Party is that they have no idea about small business: they have no idea about the small manufacturing businesses, the small distribution businesses and the small franchise businesses—they are only interested in retailers and in politicising this whole particular issue. The whole question about this legislation is the difference between hardball business and unconscionable conduct. That is what this bill is all about.

The previous speaker talked about retailers and how they are getting a bit stiff at the moment. One of the reasons why they are getting stiffed at the moment is that they are not making any money at all; they are not making any profits. If they were making money and they were making profits, they certainly would not be putting submissions into an inquiry. One of the reasons retailers are putting in submissions is that their customer base has been destroyed by the policies of the previous government. That is why, in a general sense, they were forced out of their previous jobs, given big payouts by their superannuation funds and have gone into business without any advice at all. Then they expect to make a big profit, a return on investment within two years of the lease, knowing that the lease expiry was in two or three years—just silly things associated with going into business and not seeking appropriate advice.

Hardball business is, in fact, legal. The area between hardball business and unconscionable conduct is grey and uncertain, which is the reason why the committee developed its report and why the government has responded on this particular issue. This piece of legislation going through at the moment is very important for small business. It will protect small businesses against the predatory conduct of those who have power above them—whether they be big business or other small businesses.

This bill shows how the Howard government has acted quickly in responding to small business needs, unlike the previous speaker who suggested that we are not. We have given small business tax cuts, we have cut the red tape and we have done a lot of things—yet business wants more from us. But what small business really needs is a bit of certainty and security of tenure. That is what a lot of small businesses do not have at the moment under the current regime. They want to go about their business without having to worry about others impacting unfairly on their business.

If you ask any small business out there at the moment, `What does unconscionable conduct mean to you?' they would put that at No. 100 out of 100, not thinking that it is important. But it is very important, especially when they become threatened by those using hardball, unconscionable conduct against them. That is why we need this legislation. That is why the government has responded to the committee's recommendations.

We are taking action on this issue—action that those opposite, when they were in power for 13 years, did not respond to after having 17 reports. In fact, in response to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Cadman) interjecting, `It didn't happen 18 months ago, though,' the member for Cunningham said in his speech on the second reading:

He is dead right. That is quite true. It did not happen. Minister Beddall, in the former Labor government, did have as an inquiry reference an examination made of the same issue. He put his recommendations forward and, as I am sure he will say in this place when he comments on this legislation, he was unhappy that the government of the day did not take them up. I regret as well and I have said that in many places.

He has said many times that the previous Labor government did not bring these things forward. This government has. The Labor government promise so much: they always promise, promise and promise, but never deliver. They deliver misery. There is a lack of seriousness on this particular issue. That is why I reject totally the second reading amendments being put forward by this opposition because they just do not understand small business. They have promised much in the past and never delivered; they were always promising, yet always never delivering. The member for Cunningham admitted so in his speech on the second reading.

Labor's attitude towards small business is what really motivated me into politics in the first place, which might disappoint the shadow minister, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who is at the table. Unfor tunately, his party's policies motivated me into politics: their IR, their tax, their compliance and their paperwork. Labor just demanded from small business and screwed small businesses into the ground. The reason I am in politics is their attitude towards small business.

Opposition members now want to delay and stop this from happening. Looking at the speakers list for this very important piece of legislation, what do we see? We see that there is no-one on it. There are only five members of the opposition on the speakers list, including former Minister Beddall, and not one of them has small business experience. Where are they all? All 40 of them should be in here speaking on the bill and supporting their amendments. But they do not care about small business. Looking at our speakers list, we have about 20 or 30 speakers because the government cares about small business. They do not. Just a quick little reference to the Parliamentary Handbook about this: how many of the Labor Party actually come from small business?

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us, come on. How many?

—I do not know, it was boring reading, but I think it was about one of them—in fact, none. Where was the current shadow minister, the member for Cunningham, when the Labor Party was giving us bad deficits and high debts? What was he saying to protect small business? Where was he when we had some bad recessions and weak recoveries? Where was he then, speaking up for small business? In fact, he was not speaking up for small business.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, Australia is committed to $9 billion a year in interest on debt which was run up by the member for Cunningham and his colleagues in the Labor Party. We have to pay $9 billion interest every year because of this party opposite that is against small business. This $9 billion bill, $9 billion of interest every year, could cut company tax in half if we did not have to pay it. It would get rid of the fuel excise tax; it would get rid of payroll tax—that tax against employment—yet Labor Party members ran up the bill. They got the interest rates going up. They do not care about small business.

Labor Party members are not good for business, particularly small business. They are destroyers, and they want to destroy this legislation. Small business wants this legislation to go through parliament quickly, yet what do those opposite want? The previous member said that he hopes it gets delayed and amended in the Senate. That will mean a Senate committee, which means that the legislation will be delayed for at least three or four months or maybe even six months. It may not even get in before the end of this election term.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said in a public meeting on 17 September that he would support our legislation if it reflected the report and that he would try to get it through before March. He also said that the tenancy agreements should be left to the states. That is what he said at the time. But the ALP members want to destroy this good intention. They have nothing and they will not do anything. They will say anything and they will not do anything, yet they promised everything. They said in government that Australia would continue with the process of economic reform, but now they are reversing reforms.

The Labor government said in government that tariff cuts help boost exports. They are now saying the opposite. Why would they say that? Just 18 months ago, they were saying one thing and now they are saying another. The reason is that they want the vote. They want to delay this because they are going for the vote of the retail tenancies. But the retail tenancies are smarter than the Labor Party. They realise that you cannot have a Corporations Law which covers trusts in Australia.

This may come as a shock to the member for Newcastle. He must have been asleep in the inquiry when we heard evidence on this. You cannot legislate Corporations Law over property trusts, as those opposite want to with their amendments. They are recommending that we should do that. There is delay, delay, delay and delay. What for? Because they are positioning themselves as some sort of all-conquering heroes when they are not. Who could ever forget the promises they never kept? In 1993, they said that they would never increase taxes, yet they increased taxes by $10 billion in the last three years.

Let us look at the amendments that the honourable member for Cunningham wants us to put forward. He challenges me and my colleagues to support his amendments. After looking through this book and after seeing the experience of my colleagues in this place, I wanted to know who has been a shopping centre manager. The honourable member for Forrest, Mr Geoff Prosser, is a shopping centre manager and so was I. How many franchise owners are there in this place? I do not know of many, but certainly I was a franchise owner. How many corporate managers in this place looked after franchisees? I was one of them. I do not know how many on the other side there were. So there are quite a few examples of my experience in this field.

The member for Cunningham talked about his experience. It came not only from an association with small business over a very long time but also from `having a family tie in small business'. He said that most of his family members are involved in it in one way or the other, whatever that means. Perhaps they bought some soap or something; I do not know. What is he saying? He wants me to cross the floor and vote with him on amendments that I do not agree with because I have experience. I can say with some conviction that the principles of the fair trading report have been delivered by the Howard government into legislation.
Let us go through the amendments that those opposite are talking about. The first amendment says:

(1) is of the opinion that the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled `Finding a balance: Towards fair trading in Australia' does not reflect the intent or recommendations of the Committee;
That is absolute humbug. The intention and principles are clearly in the legislation. The second amendment states:
(2) recommends the Bill be amended to incorporate the recommendations of the Committee;
Where has the member for Cunningham been? Of course the principles are in place. The third amendment states:
(3) considers the Government's response is inadequate and its rhetoric does not match either its election commitments or the committee's findings;

What a piece of humbug to have the Labor Party even suggesting minutely that we do not meet our election commitments. Of course we do. When it comes to small business and any other business area, we do. Those opposite do not, and they never have. They let the small business community down for many years. That is why it does not vote for them, and that is why it will never vote for them. With these approaches, they try to get that vote.

The fourth amendment calls on government members to cross the floor and support the recommendations. That is clearly not going to happen because the government members of the committee are very happy with this report. I am sure that the committee members from the other side who are speaking on this will support it. If they do not support my assertions on this, let them clearly articulate where they do not. I will look forward to their speeches.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are ignoring the whole of chapter 6.
—I will get to chapter 6 in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Cadman interjecting—

TALKER.NAME: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N. M. Dondas)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell and the parliamentary secretary will refrain from interjecting across the chamber.
—Hear, hear!
—I ask the honourable member for Batman to do the same and allow the honourable member to make his comments in a reasonable amount of silence.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. A media release dated 23 November—this will make you laugh—is headed `Labor's first down‐payment to small business'. After 17 reports in 13 years, this says `first down‐payment to small business.' The amendments mention utilising the term `unfair' instead of `unconscionable'. Do those opposite not understand that the Trade Practices Act involves not just small business but also big business? I do not know whether they have read the legislation. We have developed a new section 51AC, which deals specifically with small business. It covers this unfair and unconscionable part of it. If you take the word `unconscionable' out of section 51AA, you threaten contract law in Australia. Yet this is what they want to do. They want to take `unconscionable conduct' out of section 51AA and then threaten contract law in Australia. You cannot do that. We have given consumer law to small business in proposed section 51AC.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) suggested 51AC to me. Clause 51AC covers such things as:
when determining such a judgment, the court should be considering the relative strengths of the bargaining positions of the supplier and the business consumer.
It mentions:

whether, as a result of the conduct engaged in by the supplier, the business consumer was required to comply with conditions that were not reasonably necessary for the protection of the legitimate interests of the consumer;
It also goes on to say:
whether the business consumer was able to understand any documents relating to the supply or possible supply of goods or services;
Is that unfair? Is that unconscionable? I think it probably could be unfair or unconscionable, so it is covered. It says:
whether any undue influence or pressure was exerted on, or any unfair tactics were used against, the business consumer by the supplier;
Unfair or unconscionable, it is covered in 51AC. It continues:
the amount for which, and the circumstances under which, the business consumer could have acquired identical or equivalent goods or services from a person other than the supplier;
Unfair or unconscionable, that is covered in 51AC. The next one is:
the extent to which the supplier's conduct towards the business consumer was consistent with the supplier's conduct in similar transactions between the supplier and other business consumers;
That is covered by 51AC. The next one is the requirements of any applicable industry code, and that is also covered—unfair or unconscionable—by 51AC. To continue:

the extent to which the supplier unreasonably failed to disclose to the business consumer the intended conduct of the supplier that might affect the interests of the business consumer and any risks to the business consumer arising from the supplier's intended conduct;
Unfair or unconscionable, it is covered under 51AC. Next:
the extent to which the supplier was willing to negotiate the terms and conditions of any contract for supply;
Unfair or unconscionable? It could be, but it is covered under 51AC. Finally, it says:
the extent to which the supplier and the business consumer acted in good faith.
That is also covered under 51AC. Where are the principles of the Reid report? They are all covered under 51AC.

What was the next problem that the member for Cunningham had? He talked about amending the government's limit of $1 million transactions. Does the member for Cunningham understand small business? Does he want to have $10 million or $100 million transactions? Does he want to tie the courts up forever? He does not understand the principles of small business. In all my years of dealing with small business I have never had $1 million contracts.

If they are dealing with $1 million, that is really good. How many businesses have turnovers of $1 million? You are talking about a transaction—not the turnover for the year but a transaction of $1 million. The member for Cunningham also says that he wants to introduce a uniform tenancy code called URTC—it sounds like a training code for the army. Doesn't the opposition realise that constitutionally you cannot do that with Corporations Law? You cannot run roughshod, as you want to do, over trusts, because trusts are not covered under Corporations Law. You cannot do it.

The member for Cunningham also talked about lease renewal and extension. Doesn't he realise that at the end of the lease, that is it? It is renegotiation time. One thing about the inquiry that I changed my mind over was the issue of goodwill. I argued strongly in our deliberations that I do not believe there is goodwill. Goodwill is only as good as the end of the lease term, yet so many people came to us and said, `I bought the business 12 months out of the lease term expiry. I paid $400,000 for the business, so how come I can't extend my lease?' The owner of the lease can say, `Sorry, the lease has expired, you are out of here.' Is that the owner's fault? No. Whose fault is it? It is probably the fault of the advisers of the people going into it in the first place. You must return your investment within the lease period. There is no question about that.

We put forward some recommendations about the Tenancy Act to help overcome this problem so that when someone buys they actually get a new lease developed then and there, rather than extending the two years or whatever time is left on the lease. I would support that. However, it does not say here that that is what they want to do. This is typical of the Labor Party. They want to delay this bill. They know that the people who came to see us during the inquiry were keen to get this up.

In Melbourne on 17 September the Leader of the Opposition virtually promised that the bill would be through by March. I challenge him to support this bill and get it through by March. The Labor Party is not pro small business; the Liberal Party is. This legislation meets the principles of the report. I support it. A lot of good work was done by every member of the committee. There was a lot of goodwill. I am convinced that this legislation supports the principles of the committee report. (Time expired)
