TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) says that the Liberal Party is the friend of small business. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. In October, the report of the Inspector‐General of Bankruptcy was tabled in this House. It dealt with the period from 1 July 1996 to 30 June 1997, a period during which the Liberal Party—the friend of small business—was in government.

BREAK.PARA: That report said that a record number of people went bankrupt last year, and they blame tough economic conditions and high unemployment for their downfall. A record 17,324 bankruptcies occurred in Australia last year, up 23 per cent on the previous year, and well above the record set during the 1991 recession. Business bankruptcies numbered 4,773, up 19 per cent on the previous year. This is the record which this government has; this is the support they are giving to small business.

Since I was elected to this place in March of last year, this is the 10th speech I have given which has been devoted in whole or in part to the plight of retail tenants and franchisees. It is, regrettably, the first speech on a bill intended to do something in this area—the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 . In Australia today, if you have a lease, the question of what legal rights that lease confers on you depends, according to the Liberal‐National government, entirely on whether your lease is a pastoral lease or a retail lease.

The member for Cowan just told the House that, at the end of the lease, as far as he is concerned, that is it. There is no such thing as goodwill. If it is a pastoral lease, according to the government, you deserve every consideration. For that kind of lease, your legal right to lease renewal, to keep everyone else off the property, should be absolute. Listening to some government members talking about pastoral leases, you would think that those leases were hardly any different from freehold.The fact that those pastoralists do not have freehold is just a minor oversight. If you are a retail tenant, to have a lease is to have a very precarious thing indeed. You have no security of tenure at all. You cannot build up your business in the expectation of being able to renew your lease or sell your business to someone else.

Within large shopping centres you do not have any right to the space that you occupy. You can be forced to relocate somewhere else during the term of your lease at your own expense. If your business goes well, the landlord is likely to evict you and put in someone else at a higher rent in order to profit from your work. If your business goes badly, they will enforce the conditions of the contract to the letter, even if it costs you your house. Heads—the shopping centre owner wins; tails—the retail tenant loses.

In 1995 Labor introduced the Trade Practices (Better Business Conduct) Bill, which was to prevent harsh or oppressive conduct by retail landlords and franchisors, and which was to give the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission greater powers to stamp out such conduct. Let us be clear about the history of this. The Liberal opposition refused to pass this bill. The fair trading section of their small business policy, which was released prior to the last election, said:

Complex black letter law, as proposed by the Labor government, will stifle the dynamics of the small business sector and lead to greater uncertainty and cost. Therefore it is not seen as the most appropriate starting point to address current small business difficulties.
This approach is also not consistent with small business' repeated calls for less government interference with and regulation of the affairs of the sector.

So they would not support Labor's bill in government. So much for their claims that Labor did not act on this issue. Those claims are nonsense. And so it continued after the change of government. When Kim Beazley, as opposition leader, introduced a private member's bill in the same terms as Labor's original better business conduct bill, the Liberal government refused to pass it, nor would they put through their own bill. We would have been happy to support one if they were precious about the idea of who should claim the credit and be seen to be running the show. Instead, they said they would have an inquiry—the House of Representatives fair trading inquiry.

That inquiry did excellent work—no question about it. I made a submission to it; I appeared before it myself. The members of that committee, such as the member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), did an excellent job in a bipartisan way. I have praised them in the past for their work on this report and I am happy to praise them again. I, and other Labor members, fully support that committee's recommendations. The problem was whether or not the government would implement those recommendations. Under the previous small business minister, Geoff Prosser, the member for Forrest, part‐owner of Bunbury, that certainly would not have happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —A large part!

—A large part. The Labor Party did the small businesses of Australia an enormous service by exposing the conflicts of interest of this member and forcing his resignation, and the record has to show that. Following his resignation, retail tenants asked me, `What will the government do?' I said, `I think we have backed them into a corner. They now have to make a very public choice between their big business mates and small business. I think they will implement some of the report's recommendations with accompanying fanfare about how small business friendly they are, but they will leave enough loopholes to enable business as usual.' And so it has proved, although for a while we did see the small business minister feverishly working that small business constituency. We could even discuss him positioning himself as against the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who is manifestly more comfortable with the big end of town and invariably hostile to government action to solve any kind of problem whatsoever—P1 versus P2.
—With Count Yorga thrown in!

—I did not see him positioning himself. I did not notice him there in either sense. He does not appear in mirrors. The small business minister was sneaking into the enormous leadership vacuum which our ailing and failing Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has created.

BREAK.PARA: The more we looked at the government's response to the fair trading report, the less we could see. Now we have the bill before the House. It fails to implement key recommendations of the fair trading report and it will not solve the problems of retail tenants. In the first place, it does not provide for a uniform retail tenancy code. What the Liberal government has done is to handball this issue back to the states, and we all know how easy it is to get the states to agree on these things. How long did the national companies and securities legislation take—10 years? Half the nation's retail tenants could be out of business by the time we get a national uniform retail tenancy code. If you think that is an exaggeration, I will take you back to that recently released bankruptcy report and its figures on small business bankruptcies.

What is the government's excuse for not implementing a national code? It claims it does not have the constitutional power. I know it has troubles in the area of constitutional power, but what a lot of rubbish: subsection 51(xx), the power over corporations, clearly covers the Commonwealth Trade Practices Act and would cover its application in this area. Labor proposes an amendment to this bill to set up a uniform retail tenancy code. To avoid duplication, the code will be integrated with existing and developing state and territory legislation to create a federal safety net for small businesses. The provisions of this code would cover precisely the things that the committee came up with in its report. For example, upon lease, renewal or extension, the code would require an independent market rent review jointly financed by the lessor and the lessee; the code would include a pre‐contract disclosure statement, as per recommendation 2.5 of the fair trading report—disclosure would include disturbance to trading, retail tenancy mix, consultation with merchant associations, and a statement of outgoings; the code would provide for a step by step dispute resolution mechanism and also cover service stations.

These are all recommendations of that government appointed and established committee. When these amendments are voted on, I believe that the government members of that committee, in all conscience and all decency, should vote to support them. They have heard the evidence. They know these things are needed. So the members for Bendigo (Mr Reid), McEwen (Mrs Bailey), Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), Petrie (Ms Gambaro), Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) and Lowe (Mr Zammit) should all support these amendments.

The Liberal Party says its members can cross the floor if they choose and I note that the Prime Minister shrugged his shoulders when the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) and others moved amendments to his Wik legislation. He said something about them being good local members. I say to the members of the fair trading inquiry, `You represent your electorates too and you support these amendments.'

Our amendments will also use the term `unfair' instead of `unconscionable' in line with recommendation 6 of the fair trading report. This will significantly widen the number of situations in which retail tenants and franchisees can get legal redress. I noticed on Monday night the member for Bendigo said that `unconscionable' was okay because that was what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) had supported two years ago. That is the tragedy of this bill for the hundreds—I think in reality thousands—of retail tenants who have been done over during the past two years by avaricious shopping centre landlords and retail managers.

The Liberal Party would not pass the Beazley bill. They said they would have an inquiry instead. They had the inquiry and now they are back to the Beazley bill. I want to give the House one example of just what this means in practice. It comes from Pam Cleland, who set up a Granny May's business in Northland. In 1989, she put $180,000 into buying the franchise for Granny May's at Northland. In November 1992, she paid a further $74,000 for an enforced shop refit. She received no rent reduction while the shop was closed. In 1993, her trade was down 20 per cent despite a guarantee from Granny May's that this refit was going to improve the figures by 33 per cent. The business ran at a loss. She paid herself no wages but still she had the rental and outgoings put up by the traditional 8 per cent by Northland.

When she asked about rental relief, she was asked to produce a profit and loss statement. She paid to have that done. She still got no response from Northland. At the end of 1994, after a great deal of agonising, she renewed the franchise agreement and the lease. Now 1994 had been a better year but, if she did not renew, she would have had no business to sell and she had invested a large amount already. She was already risking a great deal of mon ey. In 1995, trade went down again. She stopped paying herself again and 1996 was a worse year for Northland generally. She still got no help from the franchisor. Fosseys, an important store just across the corridor from her, closed and that site was empty for three months. Trade at Franklins, another large store nearby, was down 33 per cent on the previous year and so was Granny May's. She got no assistance from Granny May's management or from Gandels.

In August 1996, she told Granny May's management she would have to walk away if no improvement was provided concerning her rent. They said, `We will pursue you for every penny you've got.' In July 1996, she put $50,000 of her own money into the business. It still made a loss of $50,000 that year anyway. She put her shop on the market and the franchise alliance told her the business was virtually unsaleable due to known Northland problems and known Granny May's problems.

This year in February, despite all retailing in Melbourne being down and despite the oversupply of shops, Northland began huge three‐storey extension building works at the Granny May's end. Indeed, work is still going on on this extension. There was no passing traffic. The place was in darkness, there were empty shops. At times there was complete closure with no access to that part of Northland. There was still no compensation from Gandels. They still passed on the rent increase. They began charging interest when she could not afford to pay it and now they have engaged legal action to recover rent owing.

In desperation, her solicitor wrote to both Gandels and Granny May's management and eventually forced a meeting. Granny May's management refused to attend the meeting with their solicitor present unless Pam Cleland paid for Granny May's solicitor to attend from Sydney. That conference produced rubbish from Gandels representative John O'Loughlin. For example, he said Best and Less, another store, were up $1 million on last year. In fact, Best and Less were not even there that year—the shop was empty.

Gandels offered to let Pam Cleland out of the lease—which was due to finish in the year 2000—without penalty, if they could not afford another $80,000 to $100,000 refit. Nor could they afford to move sites, which was being suggested should happen at Pam Cleland's expense. Both Gandels and Granny May's management were keen for that to happen.

I digress for a moment to perhaps ask the House: what is it with all these refits, renovations and relocations? I know from time to time retailer outlets have to have a facelift, but it cannot possibly be good for business for tenants to have to carry out incessant refits at their own expense and you have to ask the question: is this another way that shopping centre owners line their pockets with retail tenants' money? You wonder whether the shopping centre owners have related companies that carry out the building works, the refits, the renovations.

At that same meeting, Mr O'Loughlin assured Pam Cleland that compensation for the disruption caused by the building works was coming `for those down your end and should be there by the end of next week'. Pam Cleland has received nothing to this day. They were asked for yet another profit and loss statement at their expenses. Gandels blamed Granny May's management; Granny May's management blamed Gandels. Of course, Pam Cleland would never have entered into the new lease and franchise agreement had Gandels disclosed in 1994 that they intended to spend the whole of 1997 engaged in massive extensions, blocking off their end of the shopping centre and destroying their business.

Gandels said they wanted Pam Cleland to relocate so they could make the area all fashion shops. One week later, Gandels offered the site to Donut King—an interesting idea of fashion! That fruitless meeting cost Pam $2,000 in legal costs, to say nothing of accountant's time, staff to replace her in the shop and so on.

Before Christmas 1996, Granny May's stopped the production and distribution of seasonal catalogues throughout Melbourne via the popular newspapers and replaced them with smaller deliveries. They said too many franchisees were not paying the advertising levy—I guess that was just bad luck for those who were.

Pam Cleland's solicitor wrote to Granny May's management saying that, unless urgent help was received, they would have to close in May. They still got no response. They tried to deal with Gandels who replied that they could only legally deal with Granny May's management. That did not stop Gandels calling Pam Cleland when they wanted to.

In May, Pam was advised to give up. She was losing $1,000 a week. She had run out of money. She was working excessive hours and suffering medically, emotionally and physically from stress. Gandels and Granny May's management were advised in writing in May that the business would close on 4 July. On 26 May, Gandels representative O'Loughlin agreed with the accountant over the phone that he would not be charging any rent for the last month of trading as everything was 50 per cent off. Four weeks later Gandels called up the bank guarantee anyway to cover the rent for $13,000. Gandels denied that O'Loughlin had made that undertaking.

During that period—we are talking about a period in which people like the honourable for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and I were involved in discussions with Northland—Gandels suddenly offered a 25 per cent rent reduction three weeks before they closed with conditions: an annual rent increase, a bond increase and another immediate refit. There is the old refit again.

Where does all this leave Pam? All their savings are gone, they owe $200,000 in loans on the business and Granny May's management is claiming $155,000 from them in back rent, franchise fees, advertising levy and loss of future earnings. They owe the solicitor $1,500 and, if they have to defend the case and counter sue, they will incur further legal costs. Perhaps Pam was a poor businesswoman but, then again, maybe not. Seventeen Granny May's stores have closed in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland this year and not one store at the eastern end of Northland broke even this calendar year.

How does a terrible case like this relate to the bill before the House? There is nothing in the bill that makes it retrospective to cover this case, but if the government had passed the Labor bill, Kim Beazley's bill, two years ago it could have made the world of difference to Pam's situation. So it is for hundreds of retailers who have gone to the wall these past couple of years while the government worked up a report which it is now backing away from.

Labor dragged you kicking and screaming to include the good things that this bill contains for small business. Without our 1995 bill, Kim Beazley's private members bill, and our pursuit of Minister Prosser, this bill would not be here at all. It is still short of the mark for retail tenants, which is why we have moved the amendments we have. Everyone should support them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) might recall that the only kicking and screaming that has been going on about small business is the kicking and screaming the small business community directed at the Labor Party at the last election—and kicked they were and kicked they deserved to be. You might recall that it was the Labor Party that went to the last election without a small business policy. So concerned were they about the interests of small business they could not muster a few lines like they have mustered now on their platform for a small business policy—not even a few lines. That shows you the type of interest the Labor government had in small business during its 13 years in power.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not of the utmost hypocrisy for the member for Wills to talk about a Beazley bill two years ago? If the Beazley bill was available two years ago Beazley could have done something about it, because Labor was in office. Labor was at the end of a 13‐year term during which it did absolutely nothing to help the small business community other than conduct 17 inquiries. Very little came of them. There was inquiry upon inquiry and, at the end of the day, nothing at all for small business. The Labor Party do not understand small business. They have never understood small business. But the small business community understands that Labor's noises of interest and sympathy now are more about Labor believing it sees an opportunity to grab some votes.

If it was genuine interest, if it was interest from the heart, if it was interest from the old Labor that still represents the new Labor with a makeover, they would have done something about it during their 13 years in office. But they did nothing—absolutely nothing. It is on that strength that most of the small business community just listen to contributions like that of the member for Wills and the ranting and raving that he often goes on with and understands that if the opposition was genuine in their concerns they would have done something about it. This must simply be a ploy that they think will get them some votes—populism, whatever it takes, this is more of it from those opposite.

You might hear some thunder this evening, Mr Deputy Speaker. It reminds me of the sort of relief that citizens of Canberra and Melbourne will receive shortly; the thunder that brings the storm, the great relief. This is the sense the small business community had when the coalition was elected to government in March 1996. It was the storm that broke a very hot spell of disinterest, harshness and indifference by the Labor Party. Since that storm in March 1996 and the relief that came with the rain and the cool change, the small business community has seen a government in power, led by some very competent ministers, most particularly the minister who currently has responsibility for small business, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), who is interested in small business concerns and is actually doing something about it. He is acting on the concern that is being feigned by those opposite.

This side of politics has a genuine interest in small business. It has always had that concern. It has always worked for the small business constituency because it understands the importance of small business to our economy and to families. So many small businesses are family businesses. So many of the starts people get in their lives are through small business. Jobs growth into the future is going to rely upon the small business community. The coalition has always understood that and has always respected and actually celebrated the greatness of small business in a way that those opposite now seek to emulate. But everyone knows better because of the form of the opposition in these things.

The Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 may only consist of nine pages, but it is nine pages of substantive amendments to the Trade Practices Act. It is a bill that I wholeheartedly support because of its great significance to the vital small business sector; a sector so fundamentally important to our economy and to the electorate of Dunkley that I will always be out there cheering its cause and supporting its interests.

These reforms are not called `new deal, fair deal' for nothing. In fact, we are probably better off calling them `new deal, fabulous deal' because of the reform package that has been introduced under that banner of `new deal, fair deal'. As I said in my recent small business newsletter distributed to all small businesses in the Dunkley community:
For years we had a Labor government that just didn't understand small business—simple things like reducing tax and producing some real protection against unfair trading by the big end of town.

This package is about encouraging businesses to get along so they can get on, so everybody can profit from their endeavours, so there is a respect and a decency in the way transactions are conducted in commerce in this country and, at the end of the day, a very distinct understanding that in many respects small businesses are caught a little bit short when it comes to negotiating with the big end of town.
As my hardworking parliamentary colleague, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, said on September 30:
We are going to continue to be pro‐small business . . . The Government will listen . . . and if other things need to be done, we will do them . . .

There is an invitation to the small business community which says, `These are all the things'—and I will run through them later in my contribution—`that we have done for small business. If there are more, talk to us, because we are always interested, because our interest is sincere and we have a track record of interest in concerns to small business.' Contrast that with the disinterest and indifference of those opposite.

Unusually, because of the community's reaction to the package of small business reforms introduced by the coalition being so positive, Labor's spokesman on small business, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) has actually endorsed these changes. Labor was even forced to concede that the minister had been `able to achieve through his cabinet far more than we anticipated.' And what was left off there, though, is that the minister has been able to achieve through a coalition cabinet things that could never be achieved through a Labor Party cabinet.

The only criticism of the bill I could find from Labor was in a 14 October article in the Financial Review when the member for Cunningham claimed that the bill had not been listed in 1997. We are debating it today. As today's debate shows, this statement was also nonsense.

Of course, in their draft policy platform, Labor says that they will not have an integrated policy for small business. They also claim that industrial relations is not a core issue for small businesses. Yet these important employers provide jobs for over two million Australians. Where has the Labor Party been?

Industrial relations is a fundamentally significant issue for small business. That is why we are trying to introduce reforms in that area—that are being impeded by the Labor Party. Why do they think that the small business community will think that they are a good alternative to the coalition when they are not even planning an integrated policy for small business? They are just going to bolt bits on here and there throughout the rest of the platform. That is not a genuine interest in small business; that is an afterthought. That is not sincerity. That is just jingoism tacked on to the end of Labor Party rhetoric which, as we have discovered in the last week, has not amounted to anything.

So the small business community can see that old Labor, who were disinterested in their situation, continue to be disinterested but will try to cobble together some bits and pieces tacked on to other bits of their platform to make it look like they are interested. Fortu nately, the small business community knows better.

The Democrats spokesman, Senator Murray, described the changes as `fair and a good effort' on 30 September. The Australian's small business editor, Peter Switzer, summed up the situation well on 1 October by saying:

A fair go for small business has been a long time coming, but this offering from Peter Reith may prove to be worth the wait . . . if these changes had been implemented 10 years ago, the former owners of Cut Price Deli might still own their franchise . . . the Opposition is bound to find fault with these changes but Labor's record on small business was ineffectual . . .
And it sounds like it is going to continue to be that way.

This bill is part of a package that the Howard government intends to provide to deliver confidence and certainty for the future for the small business community and all those who work and transact with it. The coalition has listened to the small business community. With some 8,000 in the Dunkley electorate alone, the small business people themselves are a wonderful source of advice and of input.

Labor had 17 reviews into small business during 13 years of the Hawke‐Keating governments, but nothing was achieved. As I said earlier, if they had been sincere, if their concern and interest had been from the heart, they would have done something over 13 years. Heaven knows—anyone from the Labor Party who had 13 years to do something would have mustered just a little token of interest if they had had one ounce of sincerity about the small business community. But no, not a thing.

I would like to publicly thank the chairman of the House of Representatives inquiry into fair trading, the Hon. Bruce Reid, for taking such an interest in the Dunkley small business community, as I certainly do. In between numerous commitments in Bendigo, Castlemaine and all the other places Bruce represents, he found the time to join me at a meeting of small business operators from the Dunkley community that I convened at the Mount Eliza Community Centre. We dis cussed these issues with the people who have to live and work with them.

There was a good roll‐up of some 35 people that night, including visitors from as far away as Deer Park. I might suggest that some of those contributions from members opposite actually represent the Deer Park community. Well, they decided to drive for a good hour and a bit down to my community to get involved. The meeting provided a very strong message for us to take back to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business: small business wanted constructive measures from the coalition after the dry spell of 13 years of Labor inactivity. They wanted the relief that the cool change in Canberra and Melbourne that is happening right now is delivering to the fair folk of those two areas.

Retail traders at the meeting also expressed particular concerns. There was a good number of them, because the Dunkley community is the heartbeat of the retail community in the south‐eastern suburbs of Melbourne. It is the place to shop. It is an outstanding retail community that those people wishing to make Christmas purchases should certainly consider—whether it is the Karingal Hub centre, Frankston's multitude of retail outlets, down in the Mornington community or the many other smaller retail centres around my electorate.

These retail traders echoed the evidence presented to the Reid committee that smaller businesses often have to pay far more rent per square metre than larger tenants and were not able to get the sort of support that many of the larger anchor tenants enjoyed from centre management. There will always be some sort of premium on smaller space, but I wonder whether the in excess of 1,000 times quoted in the examples to the committee is fair. I do not think it is. Some of the community that I represent are also paying 35 per cent of their total sales in rent and outgoings. That is before they pay any wages, before they pay for their stock and the electricity and those sorts of things. They are paying 35 per cent of every dollar coming into their business as rent and outgoings to centre management. That is an extraordinary figure, but I hope that is not something that happens more widely through the retail sector.

In my media release of 30 September welcoming the government's release of the new deal fair deal small business package, I said that giving small businesses fair treatment in their dealings with landlords and other big businesses is one of the keys to creating more jobs in the Frankston, Langwarrin, Karingal and Mornington areas. As I said earlier, small business is fundamental to the economy of Dunkley.

Proposed new section 5lAC in this bill will prohibit unconscionable conduct by corporations against persons, other than listed public companies, or by persons against corporations, with the same exception. Effectively, the existing protections available to consumers under section 51AB of the Trade Practices Act will be extend to small businesses. The coalition government is undertaking these steps because small businesses and their situation are, in our view, analogous to that of consumers.

In considering whether conduct is unconscionable, the Federal Court will have regard to such matters as whether the supplier's conduct was the same to other like business consumers, whether there was good faith inherent in the transaction, whether conditions were sought by the supplier that were not reasonably necessary and whether undue influence, pressure or unfair tactics were exerted upon or used against the business consumer. That sounds like a comprehensive package to me. It is real and it is sincere.

The new rights are limited to business transactions under $1 million. I want to stress that most corporate citizens, large or small, act honourably. However, with around 900,000 small businesses in Australia today, even .01 per cent of contracting parties acting unethically or unconscionably means almost 1,000 potentially serious disputes—serious disputes that can put people's investments, enterprises and, in many cases, their homes and family situations at risk.

The Reid fair trading inquiry received over 200 written submissions regarding unfair commercial conduct on the part of large firms. The committee found that harsh busi ness conduct within a commercial relationship does not just have economic costs, but social costs as well. Marriage breakdown, poor health, suicide and stress are some of the possible consequences. As many of us in this place know, with banking institutions not being prepared to provide financial accommodation on business plans and sales performances alone, many of these small business people have put their homes, family savings and many of their other assets on the line to be entrepreneurial and to get involved in the small business community. The consequences of small business failure can reverberate right through many aspects of people's lives, across many family members and into the wider community.

There is an existing body of case law on unconscionable conduct. While the Reid report recommended the prohibition of unfair conduct in the Trade Practices Act, the government viewed this as a recipe for uncertainty because this legal term has not yet been defined by the courts. So what we are talking about is a reform, a practical measure, with certainty involved. That is a sensible compromise in my view. As the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry correctly warned, an attempt to define unfair conduct would only land businesses, both small and large, in court. Billable hours for lawyers is the last outcome I would like to see from my contribution in this place.

The government's overriding objective is to force a change in business culture and behaviour. It will encourage compliance rather than a reliance on litigation, which was a risk if the Reid committee's recommendations had been adopted in the manner proposed. There will also be $480,000 a year in funding made available to the ACCC to conduct test cases on small business matters, again strengthening that body of law. This will further encourage a business environment of certainty which will help small businesses to have the confidence to expand in an environment of rising retail spending—and I am pleased to add that Victoria is leading the way across the country, and certainly in the Dunkley electorate—low interest rates and small business lending costs starting to tumble with groups like Aussie Home Loans offering small business finance and established players like the National Australia Bank realising that this is a very important sector. This additional protection will enhance rather than detract from the marketplace. It is not in the best interests of Australia for one group to have massive power while another is virtually powerless.

The other major step forward in this bill is the underpinning of business codes of conduct. While the Reid committee suggested the insertion of a new section in the act for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to approve codes covering matters such as franchising, their recommendation was based around the words `unfair conduct'. That, as I explained earlier, would have created some legal uncertainty.

On balance, the government has decided through this bill to insert a new part 9B and a new section 51AD in the act which will cover industry codes. These codes may be either mandatory or voluntary and can be specified by regulation. This will give the opportunity for industry to have substantial involvement in determining what is an appropriate level of regulation within their sector. The new codes of conduct enforcement unit will be established within the ACCC to offer educational explanatory material on prescribed codes, as well as assisting in carrying out those test cases I mentioned earlier. The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs will have policy responsibility for the development of codes.

Because all proposed codes will have to be subject to a legislative instrument proposed under the Legislative Instruments Bill , a rigorous cost‐benefit analysis will be mandatory. There will also be a five‐year sunset clause applicable. These twin safeguards will allay the unfounded fears of some groups that the government is introducing excessive `black letter' law. I believe the coalition has found an appropriate balance.

I am delighted that the Property Council of Australia and the Australian Retailers Association have agreed on a framework for better state laws for retail tenants. Allied with this bill is the government's determination to see a better deal for small business on retail tenancies. I regard this as one of the most important areas of change. The minister is working diligently to encourage state jurisdictions to improve the standards of existing legislation. We are taking a leadership role in encouraging ministers like Victoria's Louise Asher to propose a fairer deal for small businesses. Why? As mentioned earlier, we would have to rely upon the corporations power ourselves to directly intervene legislatively in this area and, as many of us in this place know—and for the interest, I trust, of those on the opposite side of this House—these shopping centres are more often than not state listed property trusts. They are outside the jurisdictional reach of the Commonwealth. That is something that seems to have been lost in the debate that has been going on, particularly in the offerings from that side of the House.

With the Small Business Advisory Network in Victoria led by Noel Johnson, I have been lobbying to ensure that other sensible changes, such as the core hour concept that is already available in South Australia and Queensland, are looked at for the Victorian jurisdiction. It is unfair for a few tenants to trade all night in a shopping centre and expect other tenants to be involved in contributing to the outgoings during those hours. Show me a more liberal concept that says to the small business community, `Get together within a shopping centre and agree on what is a spread of hours that everybody will undertake to be open. We can market the shopping centre as being fully operational at that time across those core hours and then, if it suits you to open beyond those core hours, do so, but you carry the commercial costs that go with that.' If the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) and I happened to operate a florist shop and on the eve of Valentine's Day think that there would be a lot of lovesick males trying to make the right move towards the ones they are fond of and we will stay open just so that everyone can buy some roses, then that is a call we can make. But that is a call we make on our commercial terms and, therefore, we do not impose our judgments, business acumen and decisions on other people. So I encourage the Victorian government to look closely at that.

BREAK.PARA: Adequate disclosure, the discontinuance of ratchet clauses, the introduction of landlord liability for reasonable tenant relocation costs during the term of a lease and the availability of complete information on a confidential basis to valuers when undertaking independent rent reviews are some of the changes the federal government is encouraging. I have much more I could say about the small business community. I enjoy talking about the small business community because they are fundamentally important to the electorate I represent.

I would like to outline to this House that there have been more than 25 to 30 specific, tangible, practical and positive initiatives that this coalition has introduced to help small business. That is our record. That is form that shows we have a genuine and sincere interest. Contrast that with the inactivity of those opposite and you will understand the shallowness of their words about the small business community. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised to learn that the government is agreeing to all the amendments. It was my understanding that there was still an area of difference involving the issue of interest on those members who fail to provide their tax file numbers when the first opportunity has passed and therefore are required to pay the full 15 per cent superannuation surcharge.
—That is No. 7.
—So this is a matter that is coming up later?
—Yes.

—The amendments that have been agreed to in the Senate cover the issues which we raised concerning, firstly, deferral of the application of the allocated surplus amounts from 20 August 1996 to 1 July 1997. Secondly, we moved to ensure consistent future treatment of golden handshake payments regardless of whether they are rolled over or taken in cash with rolled‐over payments exempt from 20 August 1996 to 1 July 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say this was a matter of great concern amongst a number of people around Australia who had taken golden handshake payments in good faith and based on the statement made by the Treasurer at the time had rolled them over only to find that they were going to be subject to the surcharge whereas those who had taken them in cash were not going to be subject to the surcharge. So that was causing them great concern. In the interests of keeping the Treasurer honest, an important objective at any time, we supported these amendments in the Senate.

We also moved to insert a surcharge tax anti-avoidance measure and to allow for a superannuation fund to object to surcharge tax assessment based on the tax officer's calculation of the adjusted taxable income of the member who incurs the liability. I am pleased to see that the government is not opposing those amendments and that enables us to make progress. I do make the point that we continue to believe that the collection method adopted by the government for the superannuation surcharge tax is a very poor collection method, leading to a great deal of administrative inefficiency and concern within the superannuation industry.
