SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendments Nos 1 to 6 be agreed to.

I note the House of Representatives is being asked to consider a number of amendments by the Senate to the government's package of superannuation contribution surcharge legislation. The government will be accepting Senate amendments Nos 1 to 6 on this bill. I will briefly cover these amendments.

Amendment No. 1 proposes to amend the operative date of a provision which was introduced as a revenue protection measure after significant consultation with the industry. The operative date is being deferred from 20 August 1996 to 1 July 1997. It is not anticipated that many funds will be affected by the provision and the government will therefore accept the amendment.

To prevent the use of golden handshakes as a means of surcharge avoidance, the government provided for the application of the surcharge to excessive termination payments. Amendments Nos 2 and 3 seek to apply a consistent treatment for golden handshakes whether taken as cash or rolled over after 1 July 1997.

Amendment No. 4 was moved by the government in the Senate and corrects the minor cross-referencing errors resulting from an amendment made by the bill. Amendment No. 5 provides for a superannuation provider to be able to object to an assessment. The government does not believe this amendment is necessary as the trustee can contact the Commissioner of Taxation before the due date for payment to resolve the concern.

Amendment No. 6 is intended to discourage the use of anti-avoidance arrangements with respect to the surcharge. The government questioned the effectiveness of this provision. We support these amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendment No. 7 be disagreed to.

First of all, the government cannot accept penalty rates of interest as will be the case if the amendment is accepted. It is not accepted by the government for that reason and the following reasons. The amendment would result in inconsistent consequences for the failure to quote a tax file number. In other legislation administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, interest is not applied to amended assessments after the quotation of a tax file number. The legislation already imposes significant requirements on the commissioner to identify members of superannuation funds before issuing a surcharge assessment on the basis of a non‐quotation of a tax file number.

BREAK.PARA: In addition, the legislation provides that certain superannuation accounts are to be assessed at a nil rate of surcharge where a tax file number has not been quoted. The effect of this amendment is effectively to provide encouragement for people not to quote their tax file number for surcharge purposes. There are, therefore, no reasonable grounds for this amendment to be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the government's motion to reject this amendment. What the amendment is endeavouring to do is to ensure that those superannuation funds that are entitled to a tax refund from the Australian Taxation Office because an individual taxpayer did not provide their tax file number and was hit with the full rate of surcharge tax will get the value of interest for the tax office holding those funds for a period. The need for this amendment in the first place highlights the absolute stupidity of the government's superannuation surcharge tax collection method. To illustrate how dopey and complex this collection method is, let me explain again how this tax is supposed to work.

SPEECH.PARA: As a general proposition, this is a tax on a third party—a superannuation fund—resulting from the actions of a superannuation fund member. The tax is assessed based on the adjusted taxable income of the member by the Australian Taxation Office which advises the super fund of its tax liability. The member is also advised of the tax liability by the tax office, but the member does not have to pay the tax. That is a problem for the super fund. The super fund then pays the tax to the tax office and may choose to pass the tax on to the member, but it may not choose to pass the liability on to the member. In some cases, it will not be able to pass it on to the member meaning the fund will have to carry the liability itself. In that case, you will see all members of the superannuation fund paying the tax regardless of their income level.

In the situation where the member does not provide their tax file number to the fund the tax office will levy the full amount of the surcharge tax—that is, 15 per cent of surchargable contributions on the fund. That means that low and middle income earners who do not provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund will pay the full 15 per cent of the surcharge tax. This is a terrible situation. As an example, someone from the emergency services superannuation fund said to me that he has about 23,000 fund members. He has to do all the calculations when 60 members end up being liable for the surcharge. If others in the fund do not provide their tax file number, they will end up paying the 15 per cent surcharge.

If the situation that I have described does occur, the member can subsequently provide their tax file number to the tax office and the tax office may reassess the tax liability on the super fund. This amendment is designed to bring some justice to the situation. Where a reassessment of the super fund's liability is made by the tax office after receiving the tax file number of the fund member, the fund may be entitled to a refund from the tax office of the amount of surcharge tax overpaid. This amendment will require the tax office to pay interest on the refunded amount.

In the eyes of the opposition, that is fair and that is reasonable. The refund should include interest on that amount which the tax office was holding unnecessarily as a result of the government's complex collection method. It would have been earning interest had it stayed in the member's superannuation fund account. Again, the complexity of the government's collection method is still apparent in what the fund should do with the refund if it got the money. The superannuation fund paid the tax to the tax office but may or may not have passed the tax on to the member. If it did pass it on, then the fund should give the money back to the member. If it did not pass it on, then the fund can keep the money itself, but what to do with the interest payment? Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) might like to respond to that.

The government is telling us that low and middle income earners can avoid paying the surcharge tax simply by giving their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund. It is also telling us that the collection of tax file numbers is going well, with Senator Kemp telling the other place when these bills were debated yesterday that:
. . . collection rates of tax file numbers are currently in line with expectations at this stage of the process.

I am not sure what `expectations' are, but that is contrary to the advice which some other superannuation funds are saying, which is that only a small number of people are providing their tax file numbers meaning that their superannuation provider will be subject to a tax liability which they will pass on to all those individual fund members who are not high income earners. Even if we ignore that advice from the superannuation funds and take the government at its word, which is a risk at any time, then what do we see in respect of the collection of tax file numbers? Reportedly, there are six million individual taxpayers in Australia who are covered by superannuation. That comes from the Senate Economics Legislation Committee hearing of 26 February this year.

If the collection rate for tax file numbers is as high as 65 per cent, which is the figure given by the tax office, we still have over 2,100,000 people unaccounted for. (Extension of time granted) The tax office assures us that it can locate another two‐thirds—that appeared in the Financial Review of 21 November—leaving 700,000 people unknown. If those people are earning average weekly earnings—$35,000 a year—they would be liable for a surcharge per person of around $315. The total surcharge collected by the tax office from low income earners on this basis would be some $220 million in the first year alone. Some 700,000 people may end up paying the 15 per cent surcharge which they should not have to pay because they have not provided their tax file number.

So our amendment will go some way towards limiting the impact that the surcharge tax will have on low and middle income earners. There will be a higher compliance cost to the tax office in processing the plethora of claims for the refund and the interest of surcharge tax payments that will certainly arise next year. The fact that low and middle income earners are going to pay this tax is an inevitable consequence of the bizarre collec tion method which this government has chosen to adopt.

Labor believes that the amendment we have here will provide low and middle income earners with some justice for having to pay the surcharge tax provided that superannuation providers pass the interest payments and the refund onto the individuals. For those reasons, we support the Senate amendment, and we hope that the government will be gracious enough to do so as well.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —People have a choice to put in their tax file number and avoid this problem. If they do not do it, you are arguing this case. It really is a matter of choice, and that is pretty reasonable really. I just want to point out the fact that people do have a choice of putting in their tax file number. If they do that, everything sort of runs very smoothly and they will not have the 15 per cent surcharge. It is a matter of choice. If people do not want to do it, okay, but it is a pretty reasonable proposition and it is up to people. If they put in their tax file number, as they do for many other things, everything flows smoothly. If they do not, there are some consequences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the evidence coming before us suggests that many low and middle income earners will end up not submitting their tax file numbers and, as a result, being liable for the 15 per cent surcharge. When the government introduced the 15 per cent surcharge, it said, `This is a great equity measure. This is going to affect high income earners—those over $85,000. This shows that this is a government which supports low and middle income earners.' But in fact we are going to have a situation where quite a number of them do not provide the tax file number through inadvertence and a whole array of reasons. As a result, they will be hit with the 15 per cent surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not think that is a fair situation. It has come about because of the collection method they have chosen to adopt. If they had used the group certificates, or a different collection method, it would not have come to this. But we think requiring the superannuation funds to get hold of tax file numbers, which they do not have customarily as part of their information, is a silly situation. It is bound to leave some people being taxed on their superannuation for the surcharge which they should not be liable for. That is why we have moved the amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Miles) agreed to:
That Mr Bob Baldwin, Mr Hardgrave and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendment No. 7 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendment No. 7 of the Senate, I present the reasons, which are being circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons read as follows—
Senate Amendment No. 7

The amendment proposes the insertion of a new Part IIF into the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments and Early Payments) Act 1983, to provide for the payment of interest on overpayments of surcharge which result from a person's failure to provide a tax file number. The House of Representatives does not accept this amendment which would result in inconsistent consequences for the failure to quote a tax file number. In other legislation administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, interest is not applied to amended assessments after the quotation of a tax file number. The legislation already imposes significant requirements on the Commissioner to identify members of superannuation funds before issuing a surcharge assessment on the basis of non-quotation of a tax file number. In addition, the legislation provides that certain superannuation accounts are to be assessed at a nil rate of surcharge where a tax file number has not been quoted.
Motion (by Mr Miles) agreed to:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 . This bill is a small step in the right direction for small business across Australia. As a former minister for small business, I know first hand the frustrations felt by many small businessmen and women. In particular, they feel powerless in their dealings with big business. The report into fair trading was the most significant inquiry for small business since the same House of Representatives committee brought down a report in 1990, which I had the honour to chair.
—So well chaired.

—Thank you very much. The 1990 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology's inquiry into small business in Australia was entitled Challenges, problems and opportunities . I am delighted to say, as many members would know, that this became known as the Beddall report. I am also delighted to see the tradition has continued with the fair trading inquiry report becoming rightly known as the Reid report.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990 report has laid the framework for much of the policy that is now before the House. When you read the fine print of the glossy literature of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) and look beyond the rhetoric, it is not as clear, as this minister would have us believe, that change has in fact happened. The legislation, unfortunately, does not go far enough. The small business people out there are looking for help and for some justice.

As a result, the Labor Party has moved a number of important key amendments, which I wholeheartedly support. The Labor opposition amendments moved by the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) seek to implement the recommendations of the report, which was entitled Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia. I was honoured to be the deputy chair of that committee, and I am someone in this parliament who is pleased to be able to say that I have taken an active interest in the small business sector over a number of years.

BREAK.PARA: The government's bill that we are debating tonight is very similar to the Trade Practices Amendment (Better Business Conduct) Bill 1995 introduced by my colleague the then Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Chris Schacht. This proposed a new section 51AC to deal with the concept of harsh and oppressive conduct. Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, also moved a similar motion in this House in May of this year.

As we have heard from Mr Martin, the shadow minister, the Labor Party will be giving swift passage through both houses to any changes which will benefit this important sector of the community. The government's bill that we are debating amends the Trade Practices Act 1974 to prohibit unconscionable conduct with respect to certain small business versus big business transactions. It also allows for industry codes of practice and, where necessary, to have those enforced as mandatory codes.

As has already been outlined, the bill adopts the frequently heard `unconscionable' under the new section 51AC. These provisions apply only to small business and to transactions that do not exceed $1 million. The bill also extends regulation power to cover the declaration of the industry codes under a new section 51AE of the Trade Practices Act. To determine whether a breach of a mandatory industry code is unconscionable, a new section has been added—51AD.

No-one who was a member of this parliamentary committee could have been left untouched by some of the evidence given about the complete and utter disproportionate power that is being used against many small businesses in Australia today. It must be remembered by this House that many small businesses—in fact, some 50 per cent—are operations run by one or two people and primarily they are members of the same family.

We heard many moving stories of business people being unfairly treated, particularly by large shopping centre management. The most disturbing examples were those of shoddy tenancy agreements being made and the `take it or leave it' approach used by many of the centre managers employed by these large companies. The increase in rents and the personal family stresses were also continually mentioned by witnesses to the inquiry. For me, it was perhaps the most salient reminder that, whilst the economy is perceived to be growing, it is growing too slowly and many small business proprietors are feeling the enormous strain of that lack of growth.

We have heard much from the government and in particular from the minister that, when we were a government in power, we should have done more. I can assure the House that we are still addressing the concerns of the small business sector, albeit from the opposition benches. A great deal of support from the small business community was delivered to the coalition at the last election. This government has been put on notice by small business that they are still waiting for the economic growth I mentioned and that was promised to them by this government.

Most of all, however, small business want protection. As we have heard from the report, they want a balance between small business and big business. They want to be able to exercise their right to earn a living not dominated by large organisations which exercise enormous economic power against them.

The government's bill is moderate in its desire to help small business. It is also moderate in its implementation of the recommendations of the fair trading report. The Labor amendments will strengthen the bill and make it a better piece of legislation. Primarily, our amendments utilise the term `unfair' instead of `unconscionable' in line with recommendation 6 of the Reid report. This will have the very beneficial effect of widening the catchment of small business, enabling them to utilise the legal mechanisms in seeking redress when the balance of power moves against them. That is why it is such an important amendment. Some people may say it is semantics, but ask those small businesses and they will tell you that it is a very important change that needs to be made. It is not being done because big business has got to the minister and made sure that the net is as narrow as possible.

I would like to add my concerns of the government's greatest failure in passing the buck for responsibility for retail tenancy. Of all the evidence our committee received, the evidence on retail tenancy was the most compelling. The minister says the solution is to gather together the states and territories to get a common solution. However, it is common knowledge that the states and territories will be unlikely to agree on a national uniform retail tenancy code. I wish the minister well, but I tell him from bitter experience that what will happen is that all the states will agree to a national retail tenancy code and then all of them will say you have to adopt that particular state's model. Therefore, you will get no outcome.

This is clearly an area which cries out for national uniform legislation. It is now time to act and to impose a solution upon the states. It has been nine years since we first tried to address this issue and nothing has happened—in fact, it has got worse. Voluntary solutions have been tried before, as I said, and the minister is fooling himself and the small business sector if he believes that the states and territories will be able to agree on common ground. This is simply and utterly a nonsense.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business claims to be providing national leadership on retail tenancy. Unfortunately, the legislation does not follow those words. The opposition amendments moved by the member for Cunningham will seek to introduce a retail tenancy code utilising the Commonwealth's corporations powers under section 51 of the Australian constitution.

The code will require an independent market review jointly financed by the lessor and lessee. In line with recommendations of the Reid report, the code will include a precontract disclosure statement—one of the most important recommendations of the Reid report. Many people sign lease agreements without having adequate knowledge in order to make a considered judgment about entering into a lease.

Further to the recommendations, the amendments will seek to ensure that, if there is a dispute, a step by step conciliation process will be available. It is important to note that we recognise that the onus is on the lessor to fix the conflict, ensuring a balance of power between the lessor and the lessee.

The government, as I have already outlined, appears to have watered down its approach to these issues. The Labor Party recognises the importance of the small business sector to the community, and the weak approach taken by the government is not the answer. We often hear members opposite talking about the small business sector being the engine room of the economy. This is the micro business sector that they should be looking after.

The government's bill is moderate in its implementation of the recommendations, to say the least. The minister is often quick to criticise but, unfortunately, not so quick to deliver. There are many things in the response to the Reid report where the government—and I am quite keen to say this—has done the right thing but, in retail tenancy, they have squibbed it. The minister continues to claim that Labor squibbed the hard decisions. Here is the hard decision for him because, as I have said, he squibbed the issue of retail tenancy. For far too long the small business sector has been ignored. Now is the time, as the report said, to restore the balance.

The amendments moved by the opposition are reasonable and well judged. They are what the small business community requested. Therefore, I urge all members to support not only the bill but also the amendments moved by the shadow minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1996 election campaign, the coalition said that small business had an important role to play in the creation of employment opportunities. With almost 97 per cent of Australian businesses being small business, it is important that their contribution to employment growth be facilitated. Small business created 65 per cent of the new jobs in 1995-96.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first few months after taking office, the government moved quickly to reduce the red tape on small business through the small business deregulation task force. The government saw the need to form a policy and draw up legislation that would deliver more respon sible business conduct, while offering small business real protection.

Small business makes a substantial contribution to manufacturing and service exports. The Australian economy is increasingly involved and meshed in with the whole of the trading world. Globalisation of markets and technological change are escalating at an incredible rate. Business is faced with a barrage of information and regulation with the subsequent need to properly manage information and understand the regulatory framework within which business is conducted.

With these considerations in mind, the government established the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry into fair trading, which was chaired by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Bendigo, Bruce Reid MP. Small business indicated they were concerned with existing trade practices and commercial standards, particularly in the franchising and retailing sectors. Many small business operators were, and still are, suffering.

The fair trading inquiry quickly identified serious problems for small business in franchising, retail tenancies, petroleum distribution, dealing with financial institutions and access to justice. The overall conclusion from small business was that many business practices were unfair. I will give an example of just how serious some of these problems were—and still are today.

A Shell franchisee in my electorate was quoted the following prices for fuel for full load deliveries made from 30 September to 3 October 1997: for unleaded motor spirit, Liberty Oil quoted 66.9c per litre and Shell, whom he is contracted to, quoted 72.16c per litre; for leaded motor spirit, Liberty Oil wanted 69.07c per litre and Shell wanted 74.33c per litre; and, for diesel, Liberty wanted 65.8c per litre and Shell wanted 72.14c per litre. How on earth do you expect that franchisee to operate and be able to give the consumers in his small town a fair break? Many friends of mine who live in that township of Emerald, one of the most magnificent, beautiful townships in our country—I say to the Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government (Mr Somlyay), who is at the table, that is Emerald in Victoria and not Emerald in Queensland—have complained to me about the high price of fuel in Emerald. So they need to drive to Dandenong, Boronia, Ferntree Gully or somewhere else to get their petrol, which does not help the franchisee who is also my friend.

In order to address the concerns raised, it was necessary to establish what indeed is `unfair business conduct'. Current common law does not recognise specifically the concept of unfair conduct. There is a general understanding that concepts such as misrepresentation, undue influence, duress and unconscionable conduct would fall into the unfair category.

At this point in my contribution to this debate, I should declare a personal interest in that I have in the past been a lessee and I am currently a lessor of several commercial properties—not, I might add, in a major shopping centre. After considering the Reid report, the government took the view that the Trade Practices Act should be amended to protect small business against unconscionable conduct in relation to certain small business transactions. This bill is not about protecting small business from the ordinary forces and commercial risks that are part of the cut and thrust of a competitive free marketplace.

The bill is designed to bring about a change in large corporations' dealings with small business that will level out the playing field to provide a more equitable basis for business transactions across the business world. It balances fair trading with free trading. The definition of `unconscionable' may be determined by taking into account the factors set out in section 51AC. It includes those matters currently listed in existing section 51AB, which prohibits unconscionable conduct by corporations against consumers. In effect, small business will have similar rights to that of a consumer in their dealings with a large corporation. The bill does not remove from small business the obligation to do their homework before entering into a business contract. For many people, moving into a small business is simply buying themselves a job.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that over the years small business has often been the milch cow for the banks and financial institutions, with homes securing business loans and overdraft interest rates at the top of the scale. But many small businesses are also not aware that banks can be negotiated with not just when a loan is required but at any time during a contract. How many small businesses, for example, contact their bank manager when sales are down and cash flows start to dry up? They usually wait in fear and trepidation for the bank manager to ring them. In fact, the best way to deal with the ebbs and flows of business is to have a forward plan, be hard-nosed about expected income streams, read all contractual documentation carefully and closely, including the fine print, always consider the worst possible scenario and communicate with your financial organisation.

Flexibility and the ability to change direction are two of the advantages that small business has over big business if, and only if, the small business undertakes ownership of them and uses these tools to best advantage. The explanatory memorandum to the bill states:
The objective of this Bill is to address, or ameliorate the effect on small business of:
. information asymmetries in negotiation of contracts;
. inability to understand documents;
. unfair contract terms;
. unfair conduct within commercial relationships; and
. difficulties in resolving disputes in a time and cost-efficient manner.

The bill does not provide relief for bad business decisions. A difference in bargaining power between parties is not on its own cause for claiming special disadvantage and invoking a case for unconscionable conduct. Small business will, though, have access to protections readily available to consumers but without being limited to the supply of goods and services.

The Reid committee identified a number of problems in their consultation with small business, including inadequate disclosure, inadequate negotiations, lack of good faith and the need to be covered by industry codes of practice. The bill will address these problems to ensure that the Trade Practices Act covers these areas in which most concerns have been expressed, including retail tenancy transactions, financing and security transactions and franchising transactions. Because retail tenancies are generally within the legislative domain of the states and territories, it is up to those governments to amend their legislation to provide greater protection for retail tenants against unfair conduct.

I note in this respect that the member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), a former minister for small business and a member whom I greatly respect in this place, said in his contribution that we should have national uniform legislation. I have to point out to the House that the former minister had years worth of opportunity to bring in this national legislation and we have yet to see the first of it.

The member for Rankin is a good, honest man. I think he probably did every bit of negotiating that he could with members of cabinet to try to get something up that would give relief to small traders, small business people in shopping centres and franchisees who have to deal with large franchising organisations and are really powerless to affect the outcomes of their contract. I suspect that he tried to address the way that banks treat small businesses, because he brought down a very significant report in this place. Many of us spoke about that report again and again, because nothing ever happened. I suspect that he went to cabinet on more than one occasion with proposals to address the same issues that the Reid committee came up with.

The member for Rankin was deputy chair of the committee under the direction of my colleague Bruce Reid. After having been a minister for small business, he now supports those measures. What disappoints me is that he has said he wants uniform national legislation. The problem is that he does not know how to get it. He did not know how to get it in the early half of the 1990s when his side of politics was in government and he does not know how to get it today. It is not possible, because the states have control over these issues. We are not going to turn the constitu tion upside down and all of a sudden invoke the external affairs power of the constitution in order to try to protect small business against the few. Not all major businesses or major shopping centres give small business a rough time. It is not true that they do. There are a few bad eggs in every basket, and it is those few bad eggs that cause the problems. It is not the many, because they deal fairly and reasonably. But there are a few bad ones. Once they get going, they have so much power that they make the whole industry look bad.

The member for Rankin knows that. He has asked for uniform national legislation to legislate against these matters. He knows that it is not possible, but he has no choice. Caucus decided that it would back the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) in the big amendments he wanted to make to this terrific bill brought down by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). The member for Rankin has no choice but to follow the party line. The Labor Party, unlike the Liberal Party and the National Party, does not allow dissent. Once caucus makes a decision, that is it; you are locked in for now, today, tomorrow and the day after.

The Commonwealth government is working closely with the state and territory governments to develop a national set of principles to provide minimum standards for retail tenancy legislation. That is an important issue. We will work closely with them. The minister has experience in negotiating with the states in order to get consistency across jurisdictions with respect to the workplace relations legislation, which came into force on 1 January last year. I believe that his success in those negotiations will prove to be success in this issue as well, excepting that New South Wales—

TALK.START.PARA: —What state was that?
—New South Wales will probably continue to be a problem because the Carr government has an ideological problem in dealing in a fair manner with the Liberal Party and the National Party. What a shame.

BREAK.PARA: Some of the issues to be discussed with the states include pre‐contractual disclosures, rental ratchet clauses, relocation and demolition, rent reviews, outgoings, lease assignments, disclosure of rental, plain English leases, and low cost dispute resolution procedures. These issues largely deal with the big regional shopping centres.

I said before that I own a few shops. In the last few years, my tenants have not had a rent rise of any kind whatsoever—none, zilch, zip. They will tell you that I have not asked them for a rent increase. Why? Because trading conditions are tough. The profit margins for small business are down. We know that life is difficult, and I felt an obligation to try to help their businesses survive, and that meant that I continued to get rent. I thought that was important. I am not saying that I am some paragon of virtue. Sure, I would like more money for the leases, but I am aware of the difficulties.

A constituent of mine has a retail tenancy, a franchise operation, in a strip shopping centre and another one in a huge regional shopping centre. The difference in the negotiations he has with his two landlords is black and white. In recent negotiations, the big regional shopping centre wanted a 45 per cent increase in rent in one year. His negotiations with his local landlord are very amicable, with no problems whatsoever.

A special ministerial meeting with state and territory ministers responsible for retail tenancy will be held in December this year to discuss national standards. Funding has been allocated to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to undertake test cases and representative actions on the new law. A franchising code of practice will be established, underpinned by and enforceable under the Trade Practices Act.

A franchising policy council will be established to advise on the franchising code of practice, with dispute resolution mechanisms introduced into the code to minimise litigation and legal costs. A dispute resolution adviser will be appointed for the franchising industry to assist parties in resolving disputes, with a view to minimising—I repeat: minimising—litigation and legal costs. Those costs often prove to be a barrier to small business seeking legal redress for unfair trading, and they always will be. The cost of legal action is beyond many small business traders.

For many small business people, trading is simply their transferred PAYE income. Instead of working for an employer, they work for themselves, and frequently their income is less than it might be had they worked for an employer. They choose to work for themselves and they help to make this nation greater by doing so, but there are many times when life is pretty tough for them. When you trade with negative income for a while and have to live off retained earnings or borrow from a bank in order to eat, life ain't easy!

In order to facilitate the process of businesses seeking redress, the government will develop an information kit for small business to promote alternative dispute resolution procedures. I am very supportive of the government's view that the Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman and the banking code of practice should be extended to cover all small businesses, whether incorporated or unincorporated.

That is one of the most important issues addressed in this legislation. It is very important that the banking industry take some responsibility for small business. Take the bloke who has a little business while his wife stays at home to take care of the kids. He operates his small business out of his home and the bank takes his house under a mortgage in order to give him working capital to run the business. But the bank does not charge him the normal mortgage interest rate. The bank hikes it up four or five per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a risk loading.

—Yes, but on top of that, if he gets in a bit of trouble and needs a bit of help, the bank turns the thumbscrews, and it does not matter what you do, it knows he cannot afford to go to court. He cannot afford the legal expense in order to solve his problem. The banks need the Ombudsman to sort out these problems for small business traders, just as though they were individual householders.

BREAK.PARA: This government is working closely with small business in formulating a package of reforms that will bring more balance back into the way business is conducted in this country. We believe absolutely in the freedom to conduct business in an open and fair marketplace with minimal government intervention. We have taken the responsibility to provide a legislative framework within which business can operate with confidence and certainty, in the knowledge that it is based on a fair go all round.

The Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 will provide real protection for small business against unconscionable business conduct of large corporations and provide the encouragement necessary for business to grow and generate job opportunities for Australians. I conclude by congratulating my colleague the member for Bendigo and my colleague the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business on an outstanding job—well done!
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand tonight to appeal to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) to show us that he can be a hero to the 800,000 Australian unemployed. Next week the Commonwealth Employment Service will shut down after 50 years of loyal and dedicated service to Australia. It will be replaced by what I fear will be a shambles. To try and convince us all that this is not a shambles, the government is about to embark on an $8 million advertising campaign with a theme song—wait for it—urging the unemployed to `search for the hero inside yourself'. Can you imagine the minister parading himself in front of the mirror repeating, as if it is a mantra from a New Age guru, `search for the hero inside yourself'?

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose Senator Vanstone was waiting for the drought to break, when she was the employment minister, to solve the unemployment problem. Maybe Dr Kemp hopes that by repeating this mantra the job numbers prob lem will be resolved. It is not a question of the government doing anything but merely repeating a mantra: `Search for the hero inside yourself'. Maybe the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has consulted one of those kooky New Age Californian gurus while he was over at APEC and found this mantra as a solution to his leadership failures. Can't you imagine the Prime Minister, on the flight back from the US, walking up and down the centre of the plane singing to himself: search for the hero inside yourself? Perhaps the Prime Minister even thinks that this mantra will save his leadership, be it from Peter Costello or Peter Reith, or in more recent times I read in the Melbourne Age, even Dr Kemp. I will give you a tip: the way those polls are going, no Californian guru's mantra or whiz‐kid advertising jingle will help the Prime Minister's leadership. The polls speak for themselves.

I must admit I have not seen the campaign yet, but the theme lines from this song suggest that once again we have a conservative administration laying the blame on the individuals: the unemployed and their families. Minister, why do you not search for the hero inside yourself by doing something to actually to try and reduce unemployment instead of cutting jobs and services, and wasting money on songs and self‐promotion. That is what it is about: songs and self‐promotion.

Trend long‐term unemployment is now one in three and it has risen every consecutive month since May of last year, when they cut into the jobs programs that were put in place by the Labor administration. This government refuses to take any responsibility for the state of the economy. This government refuses to intervene in the economy to obviously try and kick‐start it to get some confidence out there and get some job growth. This government will not grow the economy. The government will not create new jobs by sitting on its hands waiting for the market alone. The government will not grow the economy. The government will not create jobs by singing ditties about searching for the hero inside yourself. That is all it offers at the moment, a new song: `Search for the hero inside yourself'.

BREAK.PARA: Dr Kemp has inherited from his predecessor—the minister he stabbed in the back, Senator Vanstone—a shambles in the new employment arrangements with significant private sector job placement providers refusing to take part in the scheme which starts in an interim form next Monday. More job losses for regional Australia—that is the end result of this proposal. I suggest to the House that Dr Kemp can be a hero to the 800,000 Australians by admitting there are problems with the privatisation of the CES, taking a deep breath and calling not for another theme song but for a review of all the new jobs programs to make sure that they will work and make sure that it is all legal.

Dr Kemp, it is about time that you took a deep breath and repeated after me: `I will be a hero to Australia's unemployed; I will not leave them in the lurch with a silly jobs placement program; I will review my predecessor's handiwork—Senator Vanstone, the minister I stabbed in the back.' Dr Kemp, it is about time that you searched for the hero inside yourself rather than pointing the finger at and blaming Australia's unemployed and their families, rather than withdrawing services to the unemployed from regional Australia, rather than putting, as from next Monday, another 3,500 workers and their families on the unemployment queues. One in three long‐term unemployed is a disgrace. The CES will be in a shambles. There will be no decent employment services and all the minister can offer is a theme song, `Search for the hero inside yourself'. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Close Encounters: The Truth Is Out There

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Aliens, Mr Speaker—they are out there! If you see me in the parliament or you see me on TV saying this, it will mean that I have been taken. My brain is now computer chip driven by aliens in the guise of my senior adviser, Mr David Young Paddock. I have decided to share my thoughts on this and come clean because they are coming to get me and take me to another world. My fear is that it will be one in which it will be necessary to think before speaking. That is why I am speaking here tonight. I want my follower and supporter to carry on any good and important work that I have been doing. And where one or more gather in my name, let there be fish and chips.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go, Mr Speaker, I want once and for all to leave my last medical testimony to this House: there is no medical or scientific evidence to support this nonsense that says breathing in fried fish fumes can affect intellectual processes, create feelings of insecurity, resentment of people you don't understand, and paranoia—no truth! But to my followers and those who think like me—other Australians—I say this to him: if my name appears in UFO Anonymous, if the sun rises on the first day of the month six months in a row, and if Channel 7's Witness program has a break for Christmas, you will know certain things that I now predict will happen: the United Nations will meet next year, migrants will come to Australia, and Aboriginals will say they are sick and tired of dying young.

I speak the truth, Mr Speaker. But do not ask me to please explain. Please explain? This is me. It is not a figment. I think it is me; it may not be me in the future. If you see me on TV, aliens have my body. No‐one will get my mind—no‐one—because my adviser, Mr Young Paddock, has it safely secured in a micro‐microchip with the Ten Network. When technology is available that would allow such a small thing to be divided, Mr Young Paddock will release it to the media. As I am fading now I must go. But I speak the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the House do now adjourn. And may the Force be with you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago in his address to the Senate Economics Committee, Mr Brian Patterson, a partner with Coopers and Lybrand, produced a copy of the recently released Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. He predicted that many accountants and staff of the Australian Taxation Office would return to using the tax act for the first time in years, as opposed to the Australian Master Tax Guide, as a result of the TLIP rewrite. However, he qualified his comment by noting that they would do so only until legislation like the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997 is enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Mr Patterson, the trust loss provisions are a `massive retrograde step' that will `set back the rewrite to 1936' because of their length and complexity. Comments like that are not unique. In fact, in the 40 months since the introduction of TLIP, similar criticisms have been voiced with increasing regularity by the tax community.

From the beginning, critics of TLIP have questioned the value in committing thousands of man‐hours and millions of dollars to a rewrite of the tax act if it is to be made redundant by the eventual overhaul of the tax system. We know that tax reform is very much in the air and that the present government is committed to it—and more power to them.

Equally as valid is the perception that the rewrite project will amount to nothing more than a white elephant if tax legislation which undermines the simplification process continues to be introduced into this parliament, as it has been only this week. When speaking of the rewrite of capital works legislation in the first TLIP instalment, Mr Geoffrey Lehmann of Price Waterhouse noted that the rewritten legislation was `intended to be read by machines and not by human beings.'

Soon afterwards, Mr Richard Humphry, Managing Director of the Stock Exchange, spoke publicly about the simplification of the Corporations Law. It was his opinion that the newly rewritten and supposedly improved Corporations Law `would not stand up to any form of competitive analysis against international law' because of its complexity.

In December last year, the government released legislation that would see substantial change to the capital gains tax regime. While the legislation represented a significant win for the small business sector, the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry noted that `it came at the expense of some 25 pages of brain numbing legislative amendments'. Mr Samuel went on to ponder why the Australian Taxation Office continued to sponsor TLIP, given its incapacity to `staunch the flow of legislative gobbledegook' in one single bill. It is widely agreed that the principles of simplicity, efficiency and equity are all essential ingredients in a tax system that accommodates the simple collection of revenue, whilst encouraging business profitability and efficient economic activity.

The fact that every one of the abovementioned examples has been characterised as cumbersome and unnecessarily complex makes a farce of the entire TLIP project. In a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review in May this year, an academic from the Communication Research Institute of Australia observed:
Since 1987, the ATO, in an attempt to contain its own costs, has had a deliberate policy of passing the burden of information complexity management onto the taxpayer.

If his observation is indeed accurate—and I believe it is—and such a mind‐set has embedded itself into the machinations of the ATO, then it is probable that we will continue to grapple with complex tax legislation like that of trust losses, capital gains tax and the Corporations Law. TLIP will not address the problem of our shrinking indirect tax base, nor will it make any inroads into the heavy compliance costs associated with it. It will not bring about any change to a system which falls most heavily on the PAYE taxpayer, nor will it reform our system which fails to effectively tax modern financial markets. However, it is likely that TLIP will improve the reading of the tax act and in this respect it should be supported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mount Dandenong Primary School: `Fly the Mountain'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly tonight about one of the really great primary schools in my electorate: Mount Dandenong Primary School. All my primary schools do a terrific job with their young students and I commend all of them.

SPEECH.PARA: On Sunday 16 November, the Mount Dandenong Primary School, in conjunction with Jayrow Helicopters Pty Ltd, conducted a helicopter joy flight event designated as `Fly the Mountain'. Three helicopters operating from Kalorama Recreation Reserve transported 632 passengers over an eight‐hour period, creating a new Australian and world record for passenger joy flights in a single day.

The event was organised as a special Mount Dandenong Centenary activity and fundraiser. It was successful on both counts with the majority of community members availing themselves of the opportunity to see the mountain from the air and also achieving the fantastic fundraising total of $15,000. The day was a great local tourist promotion as well, with many businesses reporting that there was a great buzz. Planning for the event began early in 1997 and its success was due to the hard work of the helicopter subcommittee which was coordinated by Terry Swanson and comprised Judy Lambden, David Osborne, Ian Bowley, Greg Boot and Geoff Rowell. Local businesses assisted with sponsorship, and service groups such as the CFA and Victoria Police helped with security and crowd control on the day.

School community involvement was at record levels with many parents, staff and students freely volunteering to assist with the erection and packing up of marquees, the transporting of materials and the selling of tickets and refreshments. The event was a truly unifying school community activity and a credit to all participants. Part of an article in a local newspaper said:

One of the celebration highlights, seats on the helicopter joy ride shuttle service were sold out long before the event. Jayrow Helicopter's Brian Smith, one of four pilots flying during the day, said that in 35 years in business, the previous best Jayrow had ever done was lift about 250 people in a single day.
I am sure his boss and my friend, Jack Rose, was absolutely delighted with the event. Jayrow, in communication back to Mount Dandenong Primary School and everyone else who was involved, said:
We wish to express our appreciation for the very professional manner in which the "fly the mountain" day was conducted.

We have been involved in many varied projects ranging from operations in the desert areas to the depths of Antarctica, and we found that very few would proceed as smoothly as did the "fly the mountain" day.
We congratulate you on your successful day and we commend you for the efforts of everybody involved. Absolutely first class.
We will also claim a record for a one day event. We have made inquiries around the industry and we are unable to find another operator who can beat the mammoth task which was carried out on Sunday.
Again thank you very much.
Best regards
Brian Smith
General Manager—Operations

May I say it was a fantastic day. The skies above Mount Dandenong were awash with rotor blades. I am sure that the parents, the students, the principal, the teachers and everyone involved, particularly the school council at Mount Dandenong Primary School, are proud of their effort. I am sure they hope that it will be replicated in the year 2097. Good luck to them. They have done a fantastic job. I know that we all wish them well in the future. Hooray for a world record!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I read into Hansard my letter to BHP's Dr John Burgess relating to BHP's 1997 environmental report on Belmont wetlands. The response I received yesterday was not from Dr Burgess but from Graham Evans, who is the Group General Manager, BHP External Affairs and Company Identity. I am fascinated with his title, but the point I am making is that I wrote to the environment manager about an environment report and I received a reply from a different division altogether. It does remind me of Sir Humphrey, as I said last evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to deal with some aspects of the reply that came back from Mr Evans. One section of his letter which I read into Hansard last night said:
At the same time, we have also had to take into account the interests of our shareholders because of the commercial potential of the site.

This is the long section of wetlands between Belmont and Redhead in my electorate. As I have said previously, they are unique coastal wetlands that have been devastated over some five decades by BHP. They did not do it themselves; they presided over the devastation.

BREAK.PARA: BHP gained the mining rights to that area in 1923. They gained the surface rights in about 1963—and, as the older residents tell me, in dubious circumstances—for a peppercorn rental. I know from direct discussions with BHP that the land and the wetlands in question are not shown at any value in their books. They have got a zoning that does not enable anything to be done there, so it does not show at any value. Any gain from that site is fortuitous.

I want to make the point that large corporations like BHP—not just BHP, but all those corporations—do have community responsibilities. They, more than government, have to be seen to be doing the right thing in respect of our environment. I find it quite incongruous that BHP publishes a glossy environment report telling the world how wonderful they are in respect of the environment. When I think back to what I have seen on the television screen about Ok Tedi—and it comes back to my mind quite regularly—and what I see in my own area, I can see that what BHP is effectively doing is playing off the city of Newcastle against the city of Lake Macquarie.

The wetlands area is in the city of Lake Macquarie, but BHP donates money to beautifying its own works in Newcastle; the wetlands at Kooragang, which are riverine wetlands off Newcastle harbour; and the Shortland wetlands, which are in the suburb of Shortland, not the electorate of Shortland. The Shortland wetlands is really a refurbished garbage dump; it was a garbage dump which was converted into a freshwater wetland.

At the same time, BHP say they have to take into account the interests of their shareholders because of the commercial potential of the site. I ask: just how much interest must the shareholders get? They mined underground, they have royalties from rutile mining above ground, they have had revenues all the way through from the sale of sand and they are now seeking an exploration licence to re‐search the area for heavy minerals. Another division of BHP is also trying to have the whole area rezoned for residential development. Mr Evans went on to say:

What we have been trying to do, therefore, is to find a solution that accommodates all these interests squarely within the framework of the Company's core principles and policies that require us to act in a socially and environmentally responsible manner.

I appeal to them in the strongest terms that I am able to utter: yes, please do that. Please have regard to the dividends that you have extracted year after year, decade after decade from this patch of unique coastal wetlands and make a contribution back to the community in that area from which you have drawn so much.

The development that they are proposing to put in there is in response to them being able to hand over the area to open space. In that area involved they calculated out about 130 hectares overall that would go back to public use. What they are really counting is the high‐water mark of the beach. The beach is several kilometres long and, because of the old AA act, the land title went down to the high‐water mark.

To suggest that the beach, the dunes and the area behind them are some generous gift from BHP is beyond comprehension. It is misrepresenting the situation completely. It is improper of BHP. The beach and its surrounds are public areas and belong to the people of that region. Through an anachronism they appear on the title of the original land grant back in the 19th century. BHP are actually giving nothing away. I repeat my appeal, as I will continue to do, and express myself in every way possible, that this area is unique. It can be refurbished to an international standard and we want it back. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Kerry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I opened one of my local newspapers to find an article from the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) questioning my position on the Badgerys Creek airport proposal. While I appreciate her interest in an issue which obviously affects her constituents I was not impressed by her eagerness to come slinking into my electorate to try to score a couple of cheap political points, particularly considering the consistency of my opposition to the airport.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, I wonder why the member for Prospect has not been so enthusiastic in attacking her own colleagues, who in fact have been very vocal in their support for Badgerys Creek airport. Why was she silent, for instance, when the member for Chifley (Mr Price) spoke of `the magnificence of the decision to build Badgerys Creek' and said it was `something I have been seeking for a long time'?

Why was she silent when the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) repeatedly berated the current government for not moving ahead quickly to build Badgerys Creek, or when the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) repeatedly stated his commitment to Badgerys Creek airport?

Why did she not respond when the members for Barton (Mr McClelland) and Blaxland (Mr Hatton) on a number of occasions over the past year criticised the government for delaying Badgerys Creek, themselves urging the government to get moving on Badgerys Creek?

Why was she not critical of the repeated support of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) for an international airport at Badgerys Creek, for curfew free operations? And why was she not critical of him for then criticising this government for delaying the airport through conducting an EIS?

Labor's position on this has been all over the place like a dog's breakfast. Particularly hypocritical have been local Labor MPs, ex‐MPs and would-be MPs, who took one position when Labor was in government but a different one now that they are in opposition.

Despite repeated statements by Labor's transport minister over the years that they were planning a full international, no‐curfew airport for Badgerys Creek, these same MPs are now deceitfully claiming they were thinking of something different. This is typical of Labor's cheap opportunism, typical of its lack of principle, typical of its cynical treatment of local communities.

BREAK.PARA: I have been consistent in my opposition to the Badgerys Creek airport proposal, both prior to the last election and since. I have repeatedly urged a consideration of other options and will continue to do so. If there is any chance of finding a more viable alternative, it must be given serious consideration. I have received close to 500 letters and a 5,000‐signature petition from concerned residents. I have met with local residents groups and have faithfully relayed their concerns to the relevant ministers. I will continue to do so.

However, it needs to be noted that in contrast to the position of Labor, the coalition has been consistent in its position with regard to Sydney's second airport. It promised a full, independent EIS, and that is exactly what it has been delivering. Further, for the first time in any Australian environmental impact statement, it has appointed an independent auditor to ensure the transparency, thoroughness and validity of the EIS process, a step that the former government would not even have dreamed of.

Compare this with Labor's arrogance, with the comments of the then transport minister, who said that Badgerys Creek would go ahead regardless of the findings of an EIS. Labor's position on this issue has been the same as it is on most issues, that is, they are, as usual, confused, chaotic and contradictory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express my outrage and, I hope, the outrage of all members of the House at the comments of the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) as reported on the front page of his local paper in Queensland today.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when we are having discussions about the need for Aboriginal reconciliation with post‐European settlement, I think it is really an outrage that a member of this House said, `We should have settled with the Aboriginals for $20 and a packet of Jatz.' That is the sort of disgraceful performance which I thought that the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) might have actually distanced himself from.

To his credit, the Acting Prime Minister as the Leader of the National Party reprimanded the comments of Bob Katter during the election campaign in the lead‐up to 2 March 1996. I think that the Acting Prime Minister has also shown in his stance on guns and on other issues such as racism that he is prepared to speak out. He has shown a commitment to speak out against the comments of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

Unfortunately, however, maybe there is something that goes with being the current Prime Minister. Maybe, whilst he is Acting Prime Minister, he does not want to intervene in case he upsets the current Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), because the current Prime Minister has consistently refused to oppose the comments of the member for Oxley after her first speech. In fact, the Prime Minister gave a speech in Brisbane about the principle of freedom of speech.

Perhaps we are seeing that it is a disease which is contagious and that it is now acceptable for members of the government such as the member for Capricornia to speak about giving the original inhabitants of this nation $20 and a packet of Jatz. The original inhabitants of this nation in 40,000 years looked after this country in terms of its environment and the societies which they and their nations built up. I think it is an absolute outrage that we have a member of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs standing committee of this parliament making such a statement.

It is that sort of statement which does damage to every one of us. We are all diminished by that sort of racist statement. And it is not just we as a parliament but we as a nation who are diminished, because the eyes of the world are on us whilst we have the debate about native title. I believe that there are very few people in this House who would agree with those sorts of sentiments. But the time is right for leadership, and I call upon those in the government to reprimand the member for Capricornia and expel him as they expelled the member for Oxley from the government parties.
