SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is part of a process of response to two disasters in civil aviation that occurred in 1993 and 1994, the first of which was the Monarch disaster and the second of which was the Seaview crash. Of course, a very substantial number of people lost their lives in those disasters and they have had a profound impact on the debate about aviation safety in this country. This legislation provides for certain changes, essentially technical, to the regulation of carriers' liability on matters regarding insurance and how that liability should be enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth considering some of the issues in the context of this legislation, some of the issues that have brought us to this point and some recent developments in the administration of aviation safety in Australia, because this piece of legislation, relatively limited and technical as it is, is part of a broader picture of political and legislative response to some of these very vexed issues that have troubled the administration of aviation safety in this country for six or seven years and to which, realistically, there is probably no immediate end in sight.

The disasters that I referred to have been subject to inquiries but a recent coroner's inquiry is still continuing with respect to the Seaview disaster, so the analysis of these two disasters is yet to be fully completed. But it is very clear that substantial deficiencies in the administration and implementation of aviation safety in Australia were revealed as a result of these two crashes and also that there were some deficiencies in the law—for example, with respect to the entitlements of de factos under insurance policies for people who are killed in aviation disasters. So, as I have indicated, this is part of an overall process of response to those problems, and there are substantial disagreements between the government and the opposition on precisely how these issues should be dealt with.

I wanted in passing to refer to some recent events in this area which give me some cause for concern. On 22 September this year, it was revealed by the opposition that the former minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), had requested new appointees to boards such as Air Services Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the like, to sign a statement which said in effect, `Notwithstanding anything in the act under which I am appointed, I hereby agree to resign if, at any time, for any reason, I am asked to do so by the minister', thereby effectively negating the impact of the act, which specifies in each case that the minister can only dismiss a member of the independent statutory board, be it the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board or the Air Services board, in certain specified circumstances, such as manifest incompetence, poor performance and the like.

When this matter was first raised by me in parliament, the minister affected not to know what was being referred to and indicated that he did not have details available at the time and would report subsequently to the House. He had not reported by question time on the following day, so I asked again and at that point he revealed that most of the people he had appointed to various boards, including the two boards I have mentioned, had signed documents of this nature. He then accused me of scaremongering about the issue and possible legal doubts with respect to the composition of those boards as a result of his actions.

I also asked the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) a question in relation to this issue and the Prime Minister stated in response that he had immense confidence in the then minister for transport and that the minister enjoyed his total support. Of course, less than 24 hours later, he asked the minister for his resignation with respect to other matters. The legal advice that the opposition received on this issue indicated that the actions of the minister in seeking these secret resignation agreements were ultra vires his powers under the act which, as I indicated, specified special circumstances in which he can seek to dismiss individual board members.

We recall the attempt by the then minister, in January and February of this year, to dismiss the entire board, as it was then constituted, of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. People on all sides would agree that it is not an easy matter to dismiss board members from an independent statutory authority. The minister ultimately did not persist with that particular attempt. Clearly, his asking his own appointees to sign an agreement to resign whenever he asked them, was intended to get around the perceived problems.

How extraordinary it is that he actually felt the need to ask people whom he was appointing to sign this letter. It is understandable that a minister may have some concerns about appointees to statutory boards who were appointed by a previous government of a different political persuasion, but it is extraordinary that a minister would want to seek to have his own appointees sign some sort of statement indicating their preparedness to resign at any time if he so asks them.

In any event, the opposition's legal advice indicated that there was a serious risk that any board which included a person who had signed such a statement could potentially be vulnerable to legal challenge on the basis that it was improperly constituted. There may have been what is technically termed a perceived apprehension of bias or, indeed, the perception of external control over board members who are intended to be autonomous and independent in the exercise of their judgment.

These boards make controversial decisions of some significance, such as the Air Services Board which deals with immensely controversial issues like flight paths and operational arrangements at Sydney airport—which are rarely off the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. Of course the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board also has to make a variety of major decisions which, as we have seen, are of considerable controversy. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that these sorts of matters can end up in court, with various aggrieved parties seeking to challenge a decision of the authority and to overturn it. Therefore, any doubt over the composition of the board clearly presents at least a potential legal avenue for an aggrieved party to pursue. Although nobody is certain about what the outcome of that would be, it is certainly an unwise thing to do.

It was part of a broader response by the then minister to the problems that had emerged in the Civil Aviation Authority, as it then was, and which were perceived to have carried on to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority—one of its two successor bodies. I think it is worth reflecting on this issue just for a moment. I would be interested to know the Prime Minister's view on the issue and whether he regards this sort of behaviour by a minister as acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is one of relevance. I have been very patient. The legislation before us today relates to enforcement of insurance procedures. The honourable member for Melbourne is discussing other issues that are not related to this bill.
—I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory and I encourage the honourable member for Melbourne to relate his remarks to the contents of the bill.

—I will move on. I think I have made my point on that matter. I return to the specifics of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the legislation. We have now seen a dramatic change occur in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. On 25 September—in events that can only be described as rather extraordinary—the director of aviation safety, Mr Leroy Keith, was the subject of a motion of no confidence by the board, as it was then constituted, which was upheld by four votes to three. He was one of the three, of course—and the other two board members were appointed by the previous government, including the chairman, Justice Fisher—who then promptly resigned. No substantive reasons were given at the time or subsequently. I think it is a great pity that this occurred.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting to note that, throughout the whole debate we had about the Monarch and Seaview issues, the issues in the legislation today and the former minister's approach to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and reforming aviation safety in Australia, the former minister continued to express confidence, along with me, in Mr Keith as the director of aviation safety. He is a person with a background of many years in the equivalent organisation in the United States. He is highly respected and, certainly from every observation I had made, he had been making substantial progress in improving the situation in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, where clearly improvement was very much required.

Unfortunately, we then had what I have described as a bit of a wild west shoot-out. All of a sudden, there was no longer a director of aviation safety and two board members had disappeared, and we now have an acting chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in Dick Smith. Time will tell what the consequences of this wild west shoot-out will be, but it certainly does raise some concerns about the administration of aviation safety in Australia. We have to reserve judgment on what impact these events will have, but I certainly am very disturbed about the impact they will have on our reputation internationally. It does not look good amongst aviation safety administrators in other parts of the world to have these sorts of events occur, and certainly Mr Keith had an international reputation and unsullied standing of the highest order. I have no doubt there are people in the aviation safety administration area in other countries scratching their heads a bit about this and asking, `What on earth is going on in Australia?'

Nonetheless, we have to judge the organisation and the government on their merits and on what actually eventuates from these events. Now that we have a new Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile), we have to judge the actions of the new minister on their merits. I am extremely disturbed by these events and fear that the administration of aviation safety is in some serious turmoil now, and it will be increasingly difficult for CASA and its staff to go about doing their job when you have these sorts of extraordinary events occurring at the top level. It is always very difficult for anybody in a large organisation to remain unaffected by these events.

Nonetheless, the legislation that is before us today is welcomed. It is part of an overall process where, in many respects, there is agreement between the government and the opposition on dealing with some of the issues that have emerged from the Monarch and Seaview disasters and how we ought to as a society approach the issue of aviation safety regulation.

In conclusion, I will make a couple of points about the broad philosophical approach that is required here. The first is to emphasise just how critical it is to have rigorous and unbiased administration of aviation safety. All of us who represent Australian people in this parliament fly quite a lot for one reason or another—some more than others, but we all fly quite a lot. We are all accustomed, I think, to more or less taking for granted the safety of flying in Australia. Some of us get a bit nervous when we hop in a nine‐seater Piper Navaho or whatever. I am sure the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) does a fair bit of flying and there are plenty of circumstances when you look out the window and think, `Oh. I don't know about this.'

TALK.START.PARA: —When you hear the rivets pop!

—That is right. Generally speaking though, we tend to take for granted that our skies are fundamentally safe. It is worth reflecting on the fact that a lot of benefits—a lot of economic benefits and a lot of social benefits—flow from the fact that in spite of these problems, Australia still has very safe skies compared with the rest of the world. It is a benefit that we should protect as much as possible. We should ensure that the administration of aviation safety is never in question in the way that it has been in the past.

BREAK.PARA: So regardless of whose is the correct approach—and clearly there are very substantial differences between the government and the opposition on these issues—it is of fundamental importance to the proper functioning of our society, both economically and socially, that we protect aviation safety and maintain it at the highest possible level. It is an important part of Australia's competitive advantage with respect to the rest of the world. For example, we have a growing pilot training industry in this country, which is one of the many services exports that are starting to become quite prominent in Australia's overall export effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —And profitable.

—That is right. I have visited a number of the places that are engaged in this. Most of the larger general aviation airports in Australia have pilot training courses to which predominantly people from Asia come, paying substantial sums of money in order to undertake pilot training.

BREAK.PARA: One of the key reasons why we have a great competitive advantage in this area is that we have a reputation for safety. Clearly, Australia is seen by the rest of the world as a very good place for people to come and train as pilots because, amongst other things, our skies are comparatively safe compared with most of the rest of the world. That is just one specific example of how important it is to maintain a proper level of aviation safety in this country, leaving aside the obvious consideration that we do not want people dying in plane crashes, which hardly needs to be stated. But there are a lot of indirect ways that economic and social activity is affected by aviation safety that tend not to be acknowledged or recognised unless a plane falls out of the sky and people die. Then, of course, it is too late.

The final comment I will make on the broader philosophical issue relates to the perspective from which aviation safety administration should be approached by a regulator. On this matter there is some degree of philosophical difference between ourselves and the government, although pinning it down and defining it may not be easy. It was encapsulated very well by the former chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Justice Bill Fisher, in the midst of the debate that occurred earlier this year: CASA is not there to serve the industry as its customers; CASA is there to regulate the industry. It is the policeman; it is not there to facilitate or foster aviation. We did have a piece of legislation earlier in the parliament whereby a change to the objectives was made with us recording our disquiet at the particular change, even though we did not in the end seek to knock the legislation off.

The objectives of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority should not be to foster, facilitate or promote aviation. That should be a role that is performed by others. The objectives of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority should be essentially to regulate the industry, to protect passengers and to protect people on the ground who may in some way be affected by accidents or aviation activities. That is a fundamental philosophical difference between ourselves and the government. I do not think it is particularly germane to the current piece of legislation that is before us, but it is worth noting that, ultimately, all issues in this area do come back to a philosophical base of difference about precisely what sort of role or approach we should be taking to the question of aviation safety administration. I commend the bill to the Main Committee. The opposition supports the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 . This bill finally puts in place amendments which ensure proper administration and enforcement procedures required by all domestic and Australian international carriers to have continuous passenger liability insurance. As a representative of a large remote electorate, I welcome the government's advances in the area of aircraft safety.

SPEECH.PARA: The air charter industry, in particular, is important to both the economic and social fabric of the Northern Territory and it is important that charter operators and their customers are aware of their obligations and rights. It is also important to ensure that large domestic airlines operating around the country are subject to stringent safety standards and compensation measures. No‐one can forget the horrors of the recent air crashes involving small operators. The Seaview plane which crashed in 1994 en route to Lord Howe Island claimed nine lives. The Monarch plane which crashed near Young in New South Wales killed seven people. Four lives were lost just recently in Katherine. These shocking and avoidable accidents highlight some of the problems of the system, particularly in relation to air safety standards and compensation claims. The families of the victims of these crashes face long and complex proceedings in order to access what was very limited compensation for their loss. A number of initiatives have been introduced in the past three years to address these deficiencies.

The coalition, since coming to office last year, has worked hard to improve air safety standards. Improvements include an increase in the passenger liability through regulations, and the principal act has been amended to require that all airline operators take out mandatory no-fault insurance.

The former transport minister, John Sharp, started the review of the role and structure of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, ensuring that the board had a membership of people with solid aviation experience. I commend the former minister's actions in this regard. I know that he was a well‐respected minister of the aviation industry.

In October 1994, by the regulations under the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959, the limit of passenger liability was raised from $180,000 to $500,000 for domestic carriers. In later regulations, a $500,000 limit was also imposed on Australian international carriers and foreign carriers whose states of registry were not parties to the Warsaw convention.

Under the terms of international obligations contained in the Warsaw convention, Australia is unable to legally impose higher liability limits in respect of international carriers from countries which are party to the convention. However, such carriers were asked to raise their liability limit voluntarily to $500,000.

With the commencement of the Transport Legislation Amendment Act (No.2) 1995, compulsory no‐fault insurance cover was introduced. This ensures that operators are unable to carry passengers unless they have appropriate insurance cover.

The minister for transport currently has the authority to demand that operators provide evidence of insurance arrangements consistent with the requirements under the act. Currently, this authority is delegated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, CASA, which acts on the minister's behalf to enforce this requirement, along with its normal responsibilities of administering carrier liability arrangements. The states have agreed to implement complementary legislation, on a uniform basis, within their own jurisdictions.

Clause 1 of the bill repeals and replaces section 7 of the principal act, which effectively extends this binding legislation to the governments of the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island. I have been advised that the Northern Territory government is satisfied with this arrangement.

The bill before the House today contains provisions to streamline the administration and strengthen the enforcement of these arrangements. CASA will be directly responsible for the administration of the Commonwealth and state legislation rather than, as is presently the case, as delegated by and on behalf of the minister for transport.

The bill will also place conditions on air operators' certificates, AOCs, which will require operators to hold continuous, mandatory non‐voidable passenger liability. Insurance is required under the carriers' liability act. Our amendments will ensure that CASA would then have the power to suspend or cancel AOCs if this condition were breached. AOCs are used by CASA to regulate safety in the aviation industry. CASA issues an AOC only if it is of the opinion that the aircraft's operations, maintenance and airworthiness are of the high standard deemed necessary in the interest of air safety.

The bill also permits the states to confer functions and powers on Commonwealth officers under their own mandatory passenger liability legislation, allowing for prosecutions for offences against state legislation as if they were offences against Commonwealth legislation.

This bill would allow Australian governments to self-insure against risks under the carriers' liability act, in the event that they operate a government run air service, just as they self-insure against many other risks. However, governments must also satisfy CASA that the appropriate arrangements have been made to cover passenger liability in the event of an accident.

I have a great interest in the liberalisation of the development of the charter industry in this country. As I have said on many occasions, the air charter industry is of great importance in an electorate like the Northern Territory. There are currently about 60 air charter businesses in the Northern Territory providing a variety of services to remote Australians.

Whether they are used to carry supplies out to people living in remote areas not serviced by roads, or when roads are under water for long periods of time as a result of the wet season, or whether they are used to carry tourists to the many famous natural attractions in the territory, the charter industry is very important. The Top End of the territory, in areas like Kakadu, is at its best during the wet season, and charter flights over the park to view the waterfalls and the escarpment are very popular.

In fact, the Northern Territory Tourist Commission has had a promotion over the last few years suggesting that tourists see the territory in the wet, because the wet season has many wonders and a natural grace in the different climatic conditions. I suppose a lot of people in the southern capitals think, `We can't go to the Northern Territory because it rains every day during the wet season,' but that is not quite right. We are almost into the wet season in the territory now, and today it will have a clear blue sky and a temperature of some 30 degrees. The humidity might be about 82 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! —Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept your intervention in the manner in which it was given. SPEECH.PARA: It is also virtually impossible in the Top End during the wet season to travel by road because the roads are usually flooded by the monsoonal rains, and air charter is the only way to go about your day‐to‐day business. If I may elaborate a little further, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the member for the Northern Territory I have to use charter services to get into the very remote areas of the territory that are probably some five to six hours away from major communities. TALK.START.PARA: —And you are very concerned for your constituents.

—And I am very concerned for my constituents, who rely on air charter services for food supplies and for clothing and household goods. Health and community workers, building contractors and medical evacuations also rely on air charter services. I welcomed in June 1996 the introduction of updated guidelines for charter flights in Australia. Charter airlines in remote Australia have the potential to provide some healthy competition to scheduled airlines, particularly in the area of tourism. There are operators in the territory looking at expanding their services into tourism, and this legislation will ensure consumers can have every confidence in their safety.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also particularly excited by the potential for expansion of tourism in Central Australia. Alice Springs is a two‐hour flight from all Australian capital cities, and with the natural beauty of the area there is scope for increased charter services. While this bill essentially makes only mechanical changes to carriers' liability insurance arrangements, it will strengthen enforcement of the scheme and streamline its administration by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. This legislation will ensure that passengers can feel confident that carriers in this very competitive industry are now required to uphold a higher standard of safety enforceable by larger fines or suspension, and that they can access adequate levels of compensation in the event of an accident. TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who I am certain will be absolutely assiduous in sticking to the content of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Without doubt. I am so pleased, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you have so much confidence in me. I am sure I will not betray that confidence. Like the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), I want to support the measure in the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 which essentially mandates a level of insurance of some $500,000 for passengers of charter planes. SPEECH.PARA: I have to report to the House that this aspect of insurance was not one of the issues that was a subject of their lobbying, although I must say that the Horsley Park airfield is not that far from my electorate. It has never been in my electorate but, of course, it is not far from my electorate—it is probably the closest airport that would affect my constituents in Chifley. Schofields, of course, is no longer operational, and I certainly had plenty of representations about that.

In fact, the subject of their lobbying involving civil aviation was Badgerys Creek airport. It is true to say that if Badgerys Creek were to go ahead then planes coming under the provisions of this act would be required to have that level of mandatory insurance per passenger. Just the other day I had an answer to a question from the Minister for Education, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), confirming that, by using a methodology that is not disclosed, some 63 schools would be affected if Badgerys Creek were to go ahead under one of the options. I need to say, because the methodology is not disclosed, that I suspect that the figure of 63 schools is very, very conservative.

We have in the Main Committee today the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), a person who takes a great deal of interest in educational issues. I do not have to convince him that students in the western suburbs of Sydney already suffer educational disadvantage and that the challenge of providing them with an equality of opportunity is great enough under present circumstances without another overlay. I am sure he would be horrified if in the city of Adelaide there was a measure that would add educational disadvantage to 35,000 students.

My concern is that the people who now strongly advocate an airport at Badgerys Creek and who want this legislation to come into effect for passengers who might alight at Badgerys Creek are in the main from the inner city area or from North Sydney. What I find most objectionable in their approach is that while they tell the House repeatedly about the disadvantage that they suffer in terms of noise and air pollution as a result of operations at Kingsford Smith airport, they have the temerity to tell us in the western suburbs of Sydney what we should accept in terms of noise pollution, air pollution, or even educational disadvantage.

I also put on notice a question to the member for Gwydir, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) as the minister representing the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), about air pollution and, more particularly, the standards relating to fine particle pollution. Some may say, `So what', but fine particle pollution is that matter in the atmosphere that lodges in people's lungs that they are unable to discharge.

It is not like smoking where, providing the person is sufficiently young, if you give up smoking there is a chance that the lungs may not further degenerate and indeed they may to some extent recover. With fine particle pollution, what lodges in the lungs stays there forever. In the western suburbs of Sydney, we not only have a treasury of young people—Australia's future citizens—but we have an extraordinarily high level of asthma sufferers amongst those children and indeed amongst the adults.

If, given that situation, fine particle pollution is increased amongst the population much longer‐term health problems are going to be caused. Although this bill offers $500,000 in the event of a passenger dying as a result of an accident, there is no compensation being offered to those children or adults as a result of any fine particle pollution. This is an area, too, that is in a sense relatively new amongst the public health experts. For example, there is really not an international standard in terms of trying to ensure that fine particle pollution does not exceed a certain level—in fact, the World Health Organisation stresses that it is only guidelines. Probably the United States has the toughest regime and, whilst Australia at federal and state government levels is trying to work through some Australian standards, it is the case that those standards have yet to be set for Australia and therefore for the EIS at Badgerys Creek.

I have said on a number of occasions in this place that I am very much opposed to an airport at Badgerys Creek. I suppose I could argue that I merely reflect the views of my constituents but I would be remiss in not mentioning the two councils—Blacktown City Council and Penrith City Council—and all the state members who are in the western suburbs of Sydney, not only in my own area but broadly across the western suburbs of Sydney. They include quite a number of ministers in the Labor state government.

The EIS is due for release in December and we have got a three‐month period in which people can respond. I think it is also fair to say that when you release something in December you are really hitting the silly season. People are focusing on Christmas and the holiday period and really do not function again until about February. This poses a real problem if we are to get meaningful participation in the EIS process which I think is absolutely critical. I sincerely hope—and indeed that is what I was talking to the alliance about—that our biggest challenge really is not particularly lobbying federal ministers or the coalition members, who I wish would stand up and be counted, or the opposition who live in or represent the western suburbs of Sydney seats. The real issue for us in the EIS is ensuring that the mums and dads of western Sydney really understand the issues involved.

Perhaps I could finish my contribution on this note, and that is to compliment the primary school students of Clairgate Primary School, obviously one of the 63 schools that will be affected by the airport. I went there, and it is one of my pleasures—and I think it is a pleasure that all federal members enjoy—to go to a school and talk to young schoolchildren. Rather than it being a one‐way conversation, I always ensure that the students have plenty of opportunities to question me about the issues that are of most concern to them.

I have to say quite frankly to you that I was really taken aback by the level of knowledge and awareness of these primary school students about Badgerys Creek and by all the questions that they banged into me about Badgerys Creek. I always say that, when you speak to young children, they are a much tougher audience than are adults, because their questions are so direct. I congratulate them on that. I also congratulate the school on preparing a petition about Badgerys Creek and getting it signed. I have always said, if we want to just set aside the issue, that our young Australians are much more aware and knowledgeable than we were at their age. I think that is a wonderful thing for our future.

In commending Clairgate, I ask all the students and particularly the teachers and the parents—and I have written to all 55 schools in my electorate, asking them this—whether, given that the EIS nominates 63 schools that will be affected, they believe they are going to be affected by the airport. Do you see yourselves being affected? I want to place on record my appreciation to those schools for responding. Could I suggest, whether you are in favour or against, that you all take a leaf out of Clairgate Primary School's book? I hope you become as knowledgeable—and, hopefully, as concerned—about the implications of the Badgerys Creek airport as those students at Clairgate Primary School are.

I want to return to the bill and say that I welcome it. I welcome the mandatory provision of compensation to a maximum amount, that all charter operators will now be required to pay, of $500,000 for death or injury. In relation to Badgerys Creek, as I said before, I hope that we never see anyone making such a claim, because I hope not to see the airport go ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is intended to make the administration of the nationwide scheme simpler. There are three ways in which the bill will do this. The first is by authorising the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to administer directly both the Commonwealth Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act and complementary state legislation rather than be under delegation from the Commonwealth and state ministers responsible for transport. The second is by allowing Australian governments to self‐insure their risks under the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act instead of requiring them to take out commercial insurance. The third is by imposing conditions upon air operator certificates, which require that the operators continue to hold a mandatory non‐voidable passenger liability insurance required by the carriers' liability act, and empowering CASA to suspend or cancel air operator certificates for breach of those conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that in the second reading speech, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) makes a statement which perhaps was unintentionally ambivalent, and perhaps this should be clarified. He said in his second reading speech:
This requirement means that, in the event of an air accident, passengers, or their relatives, are assured as far as possible—
I emphasise those words, `as far as possible'—
of receiving compensation to the amount of $500,000 per passenger for their death or injury.

If that indicates any weakness in the legislation, I would hope that such weakness would be looked at before the bill is passed. If it is referring to the question of whether the amount of $500,000 is payable in a quantum sense for survivors and/or their families, that is a different question, and I accept the qualification. That is a matter I was a little perturbed about when I looked at it.

It is true that the terrible Monarch crash in Young in 1993 highlighted some extraordinary difficulties that arise in relation to obtaining compensation for people who have been bereaved by the loss of loved ones and also who have suffered loss and damage consequent upon the deaths of people who were killed in that very sad crash in 1993. It is only too true that, time and again over the years, insurers have avoided liability in this area by pleading technicalities, by arguing that the airline concerned had violated safety regulations, sometimes on very technical grounds, sometimes on much more overtly and obviously unsafe grounds.

This is a real area of avoidance mechanisms for insurers. It certainly did insurers no credit over the years, in my view, in the way that they have avoided liability and pleaded various technicalities to avoid paying just compensation to people affected. We do not have, fortunately, many crashes in Australia. Indeed, given that there are 40 million passenger movements every year, international and domestic, we have a remarkably good safety record.

BREAK.PARA: This morning, I picked up my ticket to return to Brisbane and looked at the back of the ticket. I took some copies of it. I have never read the conditions on the back—I dare say most of us rarely have—but when you look at those conditions, you find some very interesting fine print. I think one area where perhaps some future international action is required is in relation to international passengers. There, the limit of liability, including costs, is $75,000. Here, we are talking about half a million dollars.

I think that that is not having regard to costs either, so we have costs on top of that. But here, including costs, is a limit of liability of US$75,000, which is just extraordinarily absurd, and a figure in relation to a matter involving loss of life and consequent loss to relatives and dependants of people who are killed in accidents. It is certainly something that needs to be looked at and done at an international level to bring some reality into those sorts of figures. I would imagine there would rarely be anyone who would take legal action on where costs were not added on to an amount as low as that. Seventy‐five thousand dollars is what you would be bound to pay in costs before really blinking on an action like that, so I think it is really absurd when one looks at that. Perhaps that is something that we should look at in the future.

I was going to mention too the question of air safety and the change in routes and how that can affect electorates. Recently, I had a meeting with officials responsible for air traffic control in Brisbane, arising out of some complaints I received from my electorate, where there had been a shifting of aircraft routes. That involved aircraft as they were coming into Brisbane, as they were descending. Previously, a couple of years ago, they were passing through the electorate of the honourable member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro) and further out east of that—in fact, over Deception Bay and into Brisbane that way—where there was little effect.

But because of changes in the last couple of years, the route now—the tracking of those aircraft coming in—has moved it into areas such as Bray Park and Warner, and that has occasioned a lot of personal anguish by people living in the area. I say this from the point of view of people who have bought properties on the basis that there is not an air traffic noise problem; they now find themselves with an air traffic noise problem, a devaluation of their properties.

I understand the air safety implications of these things, that there is the need to shift these tracks from time to time. But what I would urge upon those responsible for air safety is to set up a register whereby people who are buying properties could search a register that would be maintained by air safety authorities or CASA itself to determine whether or not properties were affected by air traffic. It is not just the air traffic noise. There is also a potential danger, a remote one, of aircraft coming down and causing havoc on the ground. So it is important that a register be set up so that people buying properties can have their solicitors search a register to determine whether particular areas are going to be subject to air path travel. That is something we should look at.

I understand that after the meeting with those officials, because of concern in my electorate, a committee was in existence where people could make complaints to the particular committees about traffic movements. I did notice, however, when looking at the committee, that there was no representative from the Pine Rivers Shire Council in my electorate on that committee, which I found quite extraordinary because this particular path is now going straight through my electorate and it does not touch certain areas where there are representatives on the committee. I thought that was an inequity. I call upon the minister to look into this matter. In fact, I have had some preliminary discussions with his office about it already. That is a matter that has to be looked at in terms of overall safety, both in the air and also on the ground.

The issue of air safety is one where Australia can justly be proud, but it is obviously one where we can never rest on our laurels. We must ensure that those people who travel are adequately protected, more particularly their relatives because, as of course it is fairly trite to say, very few people do survive air crashes. Air crashes are obviously most serious and survival rates are extremely low. The families of the victims are often left in dire positions because of those incidents, as the Monarch and the Seaview crashes demonstrated recently. We have to make sure that our legislation is designed to ensure that people who travel—the 40 million who travel on our routes in Australia every year—feel good and feel safe in terms of the compensation side of things for their families, as well as those who are looking to ensure that their safety in the air is protected by the great safety record that we do have in this country.

Putting all of that together, this legislation is useful legislation, with the reservation that I have made, which may not be one that need concern us too much; it may be a matter that will be explained fairly simply. I would urge the minister to consider very urgently that question of a register for people who live on affected ground. I know that members in the Main Committee today are also very concerned about air traffic movements and so forth. It may be something that, as a concerted effort, we can look at so that people who purchase properties are given notice of where air traffic is going to be and where it is perhaps even likely to be, because changes can also have a great effect, as was shown in my own electorate. I commend this legislation to the House and would urge that all members support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 which is essentially about giving insurance to people on planes. But there is a second group of people who should not be excluded, and they are the people on the ground that the planes fly over. In my electorate of Grayndler, which is the most densely populated area in Australia and the most aircraft noise affected area in Australia, the residents I represent would want me to make a contribution on the issue of aviation safety and the impact of aircraft continually flying above their homes, schools and communities.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of points in particular because the long‐term operating plan of Sydney airport comes into being on 4 December of this year. It is the result of substantial community consultation, but I think that it will also raise some considerable disappointment from some of my constituents. In terms of the plan, I do not suggest that runways should be closed; I do not suggest that one section of the community should be subject to the totality of the noise. I certainly acknowledge that the chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum, Joe Hockey, the member for North Sydney, has worked quite hard in listening to people's concerns.

Nonetheless, the major problem with the plan, as I have continually pointed out, is the number of take‐offs to the north on the main runway. BREAK.PARA: The people who will suffer after 4 December have a right to question why this is the case. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member for Grayndler to refer to the bill at some stage during your debate.

—I will, of course, come back to the bill, Madam Deputy Speaker, as I note every other speaker in this chamber so far has referred to the bill in a minor way. Because previous speakers have raised Badgerys Creek, I want to conclude by saying this: the Labor Party's policy was, and is, to support an airport at Badgerys Creek, subject to an environmental impact statement. Governments have backed away from actually building it, but it has been on the plans since 1986 when the Labor Party made its decision.

I do not call for the closure of Sydney airport because of the jobs that Sydney airport creates and because I am realistic. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is perhaps no matter of greater concern to the travelling public than the issue of aviation safety. In a country where the tyranny of distance has been subdued only by the aeroplane, the concern for safety of air transport is felt by almost every Australian at one time or another.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is determined to ensure that the people of Australia can rely on the highest standards in aviation safety regulation and that those in charge of that regulatory function have the appropriate qualifications. This government is presently involved in a fundamental and comprehensive review of civil aviation in Australia. The review involves the full participation of the industry itself through a series of technical committees which have as their focus the rewriting of rules to ensure that they are comprehensible and consistent.

This government also demands full accountability from our airline operators, and the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 addresses the issue of aviation consumer protection by enhancing the scheme, providing uniform, non‐voidable national insurance coverage for fare paying aircraft passengers and including intrastate as well as international and interstate air travel.

The full purpose of this legislation is to amend the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959, the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and other aviation related legislation to allow this initiative to take the fullest possible force in the protection of aviation consumers anywhere in Australia. This is a national initiative and it will make it mandatory for all commercial airline operators—international, domestic and now intrastate—to carry non‐voidable passenger liability insurance of $500,000 per passenger.

These amendments will also ensure that the administration of this important national initiative will be simple and uncomplicated so that the government's objective of mandatory non‐voidable liability insurance will be fully effective. These amendments will also allow the uniform application of complementary state legislation which will then ensure that the Commonwealth's non‐voidable insurance requirements will operate to cover all commercial flights in Australia.

Prior to 1996 there was no mandatory requirement for airline operators to carry insurance cover for passengers. Even worse, where passengers did have insurance cover, an insurer could refuse compensation if the airline operator had violated aviation safety regulations.

The lack of non‐voidable insurance cover for aircraft passengers was raised as a serious issue in the national consciousness by the two tragic events in commuter airline operations in New South Wales in recent years. Referred to as the Monarch and Seaview aircraft crashes, these two aircraft accidents seized public attention. As the stories unfolded, the situation with the insurance cover of the operators became known and there was considerable public sympathy for the plight of the victims' families.

BREAK.PARA: In his ministerial statement to this House on 25 June 1996, the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), said:

. . . insurance arrangements should be changed so that unscrupulous insurance firms cannot weasel their way out of their obligations by claiming that the operator breached safety regulations, thus voiding the policy at the expense of the victims.
This is exactly what this amendment addresses.

Before Monarch, the dependants of one of the victims of one of Australia's worst aircraft crashes had to fight for over 14 years to obtain an insurance payout, only to finally receive around $20,000 after legal fees were paid. This tragedy occurred in February 1980 when 12 passengers on board an Advance Airlines of Australia commuter flight from Sydney to Temora died when their aircraft crashed just after take‐off at Mascot airport. The Beech Super King Air twin aircraft lost all power to one engine and crashed into a seawall on an attempted emergency landing.

At the time, the maximum insurance cover for aircraft passengers was limited to $45,000. According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 November 1994, three young sisters—Tracey, Kerrie and Rachel Henderson, who were then aged 10, 12 and two—were tragically orphaned by the crash, and 14 other Australian children lost one parent.

The details of the lives of the victims' families after the Advance Airline crash show very clearly the need for this legislation and the importance of non‐voidable insurance cover for all aircraft passengers. The Sydney Morning Herald reported that the Henderson girls, who were subsequently raised by their widowed grandmother, Mrs Rene Holt, received a total of $90,000 for losing both parents. Their two-week-old brother, Adam, had also died in the crash. Mrs Holt said that after legal fees, the sisters received $70,000. Tracey and Kerrie had since married but she still looked after Rachel. Mrs Holt said:
It is very hard trying to bring up the girls on my widow's pension and a bit of child allowance. There were many times when I thought we'd never make ends meet.

No amount of money will ever bring back a family member, but had this legislation been in place at that time, the significant hardships and sacrifice by this family alone would have been avoided and their lives, already touched by the deepest loss imaginable, would not have been further blighted by severe financial struggle and uncertainty.

On a later occasion, on the night of 11 June 1993, flying in poor weather to Young airport in New South Wales, a Piper Chieftain flying for Monarch Airlines on flight 301 from Sydney crashed into a hill on approach to the airport killing all seven people on board.

At the inquest, the New South Wales Deputy Coroner, Mr Peter Gould, found `persistent and overwhelming evidence of breaches of safety regulations' by the now defunct Monarch Airlines and he quoted the intention of section 6(3) of the Air Transport Act 1987, which provides:

.. that the Minister consider the following additional matters which particularly take account of the concerns of consumers: adequate insurance of the aircraft, operator, pilots and passengers; and the ownership of or extent of the applicant's right to operate the aircraft used by the licensed applicant. This will assist the Minister in determining the bona fide intentions of applicants to provide viable passenger services.
The coroner stated on page 116 of the coronial inquest report that:

The only matter which the Air Transport Council says it had regard to under section 6(3) when issuing the Monarch licence was whether it was adequately insured, yet it did not get any evidence of that insurance until after the aircraft crashed.
The coroner went on to say:

The insurer claims that the insurance obtained was voided in respect of the deaths because of the unsafe conditions of the aircraft. How the Air Transport Council could disregard that matter is difficult to conceive, unless one could say that it is in the interests of consumers to leave it to the dictates of the market.
He then highlighted the sentiments not only of the families of the victims of the Monarch crash but of every member of the air travelling public in Australia when he said:

Adequate insurance is not just a matter of providing compensation for death or injury. Non‐voidable insurance enhances public safety because an operator would not be likely to get that insurance unless he satisfied the insurer that he was fit and suitable to operate RPT services safely. If a person cannot legally drive a motor vehicle without a green slip, why then should the Minister, or his delegate, not consider it inappropriate to provide the same insurance cover for passengers and pilots?

The extent of public concern on this issue focused on the news report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 November 1994 in which it was made clear that the underwriter who had insured Monarch Airlines stated he believed he would never have to make a payout for the families of the victims of that tragedy. This case makes it very clear to the public that an airline's insurers can refuse claims for compensation if it is held that the aircraft was operated contrary to the conditions of the insurance policy. It was also made abundantly clear at this time that, in any event, the total insurance liability forthcoming from any underwriter was limited to $180,000 a victim.
A formal recommendation regarding the kind of insurance cover necessary was defined by Coroner Gould at the inquest in the coronial report:

That the Minister determine, pursuant to section 6(3)(h), that only non‐voidable insurance for passengers and pilots be deemed adequate and the proof of such insurance in an appropriate amount be furnished before any licence is granted or renewed.
In his ministerial statement already referred to, the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume, said:

The coroner has made several recommendations, some of which, such as those relating to insurance, have already been implemented. It is now mandatory for aviation operators carrying passengers for financial reward to have non‐voidable insurance for their passengers. That has not helped the victims of the Monarch crash, who are still waiting for acknowledgment and settlement of their claims against the insurer of the operator. The changes to the legislation were made largely necessary because of the disgraceful treatment they have suffered, and still suffer, at the hands of the Monarch's insurer.

This bill is a further important part of the government's ongoing commitment towards the protection of all Australians who travel by air across our vast country. In January 1996, the government made a legislative requirement for all domestic and international airline operators to have non‐voidable passenger insurance cover of $500,000 a passenger. However, only interstate and international travel was covered by that legislation. Later in 1996 the states, actively encouraged by the federal government, passed legislation to extend the protection to passengers on intrastate travel.

This amendment is relatively minor in nature but it will make the administration of this national initiative simpler and therefore it will ensure its full effect and compliance. It expands the initiative by providing uniform national insurance coverage for all aircraft passengers which requires all commercial airlines in Australia to insure passengers travelling by air in Australia for the total amount of $500,000. These new amendments will authorise the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to directly administer the act on behalf of the Commonwealth and state ministers rather than under delegated authority from the Commonwealth and state transport ministers.

The legislation requires that all airline operators subject to the act must have a certificate of compliance from CASA testifying that the insurance requirements of the act have been fully and totally observed. In addition, offences under the state legislation will be dealt with as Commonwealth offences and will be investigated and prosecuted by the Commonwealth government.

The bill reflects the fulfilment of the government's concern and commitment to ensuring the fullest possible protection of the entitlement of adequate compensation, in the event of an aircraft accident, for the travelling public of Australia and their families. This means international, interstate, and now intrastate, travel. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 amends the civil aviation legislative regime, and its purpose is to amend the mandatory passenger liability insurance regime that is imposed upon the operators of aircraft in Australia. As a consequence, in general terms, it is linked to safety and passenger safety; but the notion of civil aviation also throws up the contrast which can be made with military aviation. I would like to make some general comments today in respect of civil aviation and Western Australia—in particular, Perth airport, and the operation of military aircraft in Western Australia, particularly from the RAAF base in Pearce.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a connection with this bill, because it has as its substance the notion of passenger safety. For members of this house from Western Australia who may be familiar with the operation of Perth airport, Perth airport is immediately to the south of the RAAF Pearce base. One of the difficulties that air traffic controllers have in the operation of Perth airport—as that goes to the amelioration of noise, the safety of passengers, and the safety of civil aviation—is with the configuration of the Perth air space for civil aviation and the RAAF Pearce military air space.

In recent years, since I became the member for Perth, I have drawn to the attention of the Civil Aviation Authority the difficulty that the juxtaposition of that airspace causes for residents in the suburb of Beechboro. As a consequence, we have seen, in recent years, efforts made to improve the configuration of airspace between Perth airport with its civil airspace and the RAAF Pearce air base airspace.
I was very pleased recently to see a press release issued by the Civil Aviation Authority, now of course known as Airservices Australia, which was in the following terms:
Agreement reached on Perth airspace
Airservices Australia and the RAAF today announced a milestone agreement for the future use of airspace over and around Perth.
Airservices General Manager Air Traffic Services, Peter Evans, said the agreement would provide significant benefits to airspace users, the aviation community and the general public.

`This agreement on airspace availability and usage was necessary because of continuing growth of civilian aircraft traffic and the growing strategic importance of nearby defence facilities,' Mr Evans said.
The agreement will provide:
. significantly enhanced levels of safety with improved flight paths for heavy jets;
. increased efficiency, with arriving and departing aircraft able to be more effectively sequenced;
. savings to industry with more efficient tracks, resulting in less fuel burn;
. the potential for significant reductions in noise from heavy jets; and
. protection and enhancement of critical defence training capabilities, particularly off the West Australian coastline for both the Royal Australian Air Force and Royal Australian Navy.
Mr Evans said the agreement followed continuing successful consultation and negotiation between Airservices Australia, Defence Forces, airspace users and the aviation community.

`The Perth/Pearce Airspace Review Committee was jointly initiated by Airservices Australia and the RAAF, and included RAN, Civil Aviation Safety Authority, QANTAS (heavy jet transport), Ansett (inter and intrastate regular passenger carriers), the Regional Airspace Users Advisory Committee (mid level operators) and the Royal Aero Club of Western Australia (general aviation training and private operators).
`The extensive ground work undertaken by this group was then subjected to extensive analysis and detailed ratification by a specialist group from Airservices Australia and the RAAF.
`The Air Co‐ordinating Committee which has ultimate responsibility for civil and defence airspace issues applauds the sound work which has been achieved with this agreement,' Mr Evans said.
This latest agreement represents a third major milestone achieved through close consultation and negotiation over the past 10 years.
`Ten years ago most of the airspace around Perth was controlled by defence,' Mr Evans said.
`Then major concessions were achieved to the south east to cater for the enormous growth in aviation.

`Around five years ago the second milestone was achieved with agreement on airspace use to the north‐east of Perth airport and now today's agreement which provides sustainable, safer and more efficient routes to and from Perth Airport,' he said.
Mr Evans said as aviation traffic continued to grow and new civil and military air traffic control systems come on line, further refinements will be possible.

`In fact we have already agreed to review the airspace requirements as traffic levels increase at Perth Airport and to commence discussion on sharing of defence and civilian air traffic control equipment,' Mr Evans said.
Consultation with State and local government and the general community on the agreement, will commence shortly.

I was very pleased to see that release issued by Airservices Australia as the culmination of a number of years and months of close work with the RAAF. I regard that very much as the start of the process, not the end of the process, because, as Mr Evans said in his press release:
Consultation with State and local government and the general community on the agreement, will commence shortly.

A reconfiguration of the airspace between Perth and Pearce does have great potential to improve the usage of Perth airport and to ameliorate adverse noise consequences for those residents who live around Perth airport, particularly to the north and the north‐east.

Aircraft that now depart on the main Perth airport runway—runway 01—to the north, which occurs more often in the summer with the north‐easterly wind prevailing in Perth, are now forced, because of the configuration of the Perth‐Pearce airspace, to veer to the west immediately after the suburb of Beechboro. A better configuration which will arise, hopefully, out of this agreement will see there no longer being a need for aircraft taking off to the north to deviate to the west. As a consequence, that will leave the suburb of Beechboro in a much better situation so far as aircraft noise is concerned.

Close consultation with local government is required, because Perth airport does have the advantage of a very well‐developed Perth Municipalities Airport Group, which is made up of representatives of a number of relevant local authorities. The ones that I mention today include the city of Bayswater, the town of Bassendean and the shire of Swan, all of whom represent suburbs to the east, the north or the north‐west of the airport. For suburbs such as Midland, Midvale and Bellevue, to the north‐east of the airport, this particular agreement may well have repercussions and, as a consequence, consultation is required with the Shire of Swan local authority on this matter.

It may also be the case that the residents of the suburbs of South Guildford and Guildford, who are, in very many respects, those residents of the suburbs around Perth airport to the north of the airport most adversely affected by airport noise, may well see some slight amelioration of aircraft noise as a consequence of these prospective changes. I regard this as a good development but very much as the start of the process.

I look forward to those detailed consultations, which I hope will have the effect of improving the operation of civil aviation around Perth airport and the operations of military aircraft around Pearce military RAAF base. Also, in the context of this legislation, it should have a good impact so far as the safety of the operation of those respective aircraft is concerned. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), the opposition spokesman on these matters, has made clear our general support of these provisions. I commend the bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is basically to rectify deficiencies that exist in relation to the protection of those travelling and, of course, for the families of passengers on commercial aircraft. This bill fixes a problem that has existed in the country for far too long. Everybody who is a fare‐paying passenger on an aircraft has the right to expect safe conduct of the flight and to arrive at the destination safely with minimal risk to life and limb, and as efficiently as operationally possible.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill addresses one of the many areas that need to be addressed to make aviation safer and efficient for all. These amendments are necessary because of the lack of attention paid to aviation by the previous Labor government. Aviation is a vital and necessary facet of the Australian way of life. Most Australians have used and will use the major airlines in this country to travel during their lives.

To get to the heart of the matter, it is one thing to say that it is unfortunate that we need to have a passenger carrying aircraft crash before we see the inadequacies of the current passenger liability insurance arrangements fixed, but it is bordering on criminal to allow the problem not only to continue but to allow further aircraft accidents to happen without taking any legislative or regulatory action. This is what the previous Labor government allowed to happen. The Monarch Airlines crash at Young in New South Wales in 1993 killed seven people. We could discuss whether the aircraft was airworthy, but that is not the purpose of this amendment and has been canvassed in this place on many previous occasions.

What makes this negligence by the former Labor government even more despicable is that the then shadow minister, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), made the then Labor minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), fully aware of the consequences of non‐action, and that more might die. Guess what happened next? After the Monarch crash in 1993, we saw the Seaview crash on 2 October 1994. The then Labor government was made fully aware from sources all over the country, and in this very chamber, that these crashes were likely to happen.

In this modern era, it takes more than just being a well‐meaning person with a good heart to be involved in making decisions. We need to have the capacity and technical competence to grasp the complexities of aviation. This is where the former Labor government fell short by appointing non‐aviation people to the CASA—the Civil Aviation Safety Authority—board. Not only did it mean that the board did not have people who were able to make value judgments on aviation, but it sent the wrong message to the aviation community, that the government did not take aviation seriously.

What the coalition has done is appointed people to the board who are sufficiently qualified—people like Mr Dick Smith. Mr Dick Smith was not appointed because he was a nice bloke or a mate—this was not a job for the boys, as happened under the previous Labor government—but because he had sufficient aviation experience. I commend the appointment of Mr Dick Smith to the position. Not only is he an experienced pilot; he is a person who has the willingness and the capacity to make difficult decisions.

What this amendment is about is ensuring that passengers of regular public transport can have the benefit of increased passenger liability insurance. During the Labor years, until October 1994, the maximum amount of cover for death or injury would have been $180,000. I ask you: what would $180,000 do for a family losing a breadwinner or facing the economic cost incurred in losing a home maker? If the surviving family invested $180,000 at bank interest of, say, five per cent, then the interest income would be $9,000 a year, or $180 a week. No‐one could be expected to live on that. It was as a result of the efforts of the member for Hume, John Sharp, in particular and of the conservative parties in general during 1994 that the limit was increased to $500,000. Further, in 1995 legislation introduced mandatory no‐fault insurance cover.

It is the general approach and attitude of this government to consult and consider the opinion of all the stakeholders who are affected by legislation. In keeping with this philosophy, we have contacted the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. Mr Bart Beech, who is the executive officer of AOPA, has made us fully aware of some of the anomalies that this amendment may cause. I think it is only fair enough, if we are going to introduce legislation, that we ensure that it has been put across the community, and consultation and comment has been given.

Although everybody involved in the aviation industry is positive about this amendment, there are some complications that occur because of the nature of the aviation industry. It is important to understand that in many cases the owner of the aircraft is not the operator and the provider of the passenger services. Many times the aircraft is hired to the operator by the owner, and the operator conducts the charter or the airline business. So there is an anomaly as to who, in effect, should be the holder of the insurance. Should it be the owner of the aircraft, or the provider of the passenger service?

The interpretation given by regulators of the act, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, is that the carrier is the provider of the passenger service and that that person has the responsibility of providing insurance. This could cause the need for both the owner and the operator to hold separate insurance policies for the same cover. In fact, at time of claim, since there would only be one claim, it is possible that the insurance companies could have a legal battle between themselves as to who is going to actually pay the claim. As Bart Beech says:
There is one aspect of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act which is causing considerable problems to many operators and which is not addressed in the amendments . . .
and he alludes in detail to this anomaly. He goes further to add:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the spirit of the Act which is to ensure passengers are carried by non voidable insurance . . . and the actual requirement of the Act for carriers to hold insurance.

The problem is that it is usual for the aircraft owner to hold the insurance, and this could cause real problems. If the owner who already has in place an appropriate insurance on the aircraft hires that aircraft to the carrier, the current interpretation by CASA is that the holder of the passenger liability insurance should be held by the carrier. The reality is that this may not be possible. The problem could simply be solved if there were a slight change in the wording, such as `It is a requirement for the insurance to be in place—not necessarily to be contracted by the carrier, but simply so that the carrier is responsible to ensure that the non‐voidable insurance is in place.'

I return to the matter of the amount of $500,000 insurance. Although the Labor government increased the insurance, I wonder how the government actually came about the figure of $500,000. It sounds impressive—it is half a million dollars—but does it provide for the family of the victims of aircraft accidents so that they could maintain the lifestyle that would have been in existence if the passenger were still alive and providing for the family? If we invested half a million dollars at bank interest at, say, five per cent, we would get an investment income of $25,000 per annum. This does not take into account any personal or home loans that may need to be paid out, the cost of education, or allowances for increases in the cost of living. I find it timely to encourage people to consider their financial needs in case of death or injury, and to seek advice on how best to protect themselves, whether by insurance or financial investment, because the likelihood exists that there could be a higher financial need than the amendment actually provides for.

Furthermore, it would be important that passengers recognise their common law rights and have the right to take further legal action against the airline operator. I have the view that the amendment should include a clause which allows for regular increases in the cost of living without the need to change the legislation. It is quite a task to get legislation to recognise that need exists for continual adjustment. As time changes, legislation needs to change, as well. A good example of this is to look back and see how long it has actually taken this amendment to come before the House. It would be more efficient to include, for the people in charge of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority or whichever department is going to be responsible for regulating this legislation, the option that the level of mandatory insurance be increased in step with the consumer price index. My reading of the amendment is that the level of cover of $500,000 is the maximum ceiling for death or injury and may mean that in the case of injury, the full $500,000 may not be paid. In the case of total disablement, there is not only the loss of income and saving capacity, but also the extra cost required for ongoing care and use of facilities.

The legislation needs to clarify exactly what amounts are paid, under what circumstances and at what level of injury, with the option that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority can alter the requirements as circumstances arise. Although the need for insurance is very necessary, it is quite simply a fall back or last resort situation. I would prefer that the occasion never came about where my wife collected the insurance money, because that would mean that I could be at best injured or at worst dead.

As a pilot, I have studied many aircraft accidents where the aircraft have hit the deck. There is not much give because the aircraft hit at such a fast pace. If an aircraft is in an uncontrolled descent, people do not often walk away.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't bounce!

—That's right, they don't bounce. It has been expressed by Mr Dick Smith that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority's level of surveillance at Sydney is below target, as they are focusing resources in areas other than those revolving around fare paying passengers.

BREAK.PARA: The general public may think you cannot get safety to be efficient and cost‐effective at the same time but, as a pilot, I can tell you that safety is not always about cost. Cost is a part of it, fair enough, but it is more about attitude, diligence, applying the rules and, frankly, what we pilots call `airmanship'.

The member for Hume, in his capacity as shadow minister for transport while the Labor government was in office, on many occasions in this place alluded to instances where, under the old Civil Aviation Authority, certain airworthiness inspectors were not as diligent in their duties as the law provided and, in some cases, they flouted the law. This was an obstruction to air safety, despite all the funds and all the infrastructure that was in place.

It takes more than a change of name and some restructuring to make an effective Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It takes the right people, with the right expertise and the right attitude. To get that, you need the right leadership. The Labor government was not about providing the right leadership.

Although many may think this amendment is a simple formality, in reality it is more than that. It is sending a message that we are serious about aviation and about providing leadership. From a private flying and small carrier perspective, one of the biggest threats to aviation safety is the high cost of flying, which prevents pilots from being able to fly enough hours to maintain competency. People not involved in aviation assume that flying aeroplanes is naturally a costly exercise. This does not need to be so.

I will give some examples of things which unnecessarily add to the cost of flying. Firstly, there are some burdensome airworthiness directives and certification requirements required by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, which are already completed in other countries, particularly in the USA, from where most small aircraft are imported. So the work has already been done, but we are doing it again. This is nothing but an unnecessary, burdensome, administrative duplication of regulation.

Secondly, we have overly complex and restrictive regulations which require the widespread issue of exemptions. These exemptions are granted on an individual basis, giving enormous power to CASA officers. I believe that there is room to simplify the regulations without compromising safety. In fact, I would be prepared to say that making the act more complex and complicated could jeopardise safety.

Thirdly, we have a legislative monopoly in the provision of aviation services. If these services could be exposed to competition, it may be that we would have reduced costs, with increased efficiencies and effectiveness as well.

Finally, Australia has a vast amount of military airspace which causes aircraft to divert, and this adds unnecessarily to the high cost of flight. We need to consistently review the existing regulations with a more focused, more results orientated approach. The review must be undertaken by people who know what they are basically doing. Obviously, the review must be undertaken by people who do not have vested interests in maintaining their jobs and by people who understand aviation. The objective must be safety and efficiency. In 20 months, this coalition government has just touched the surface. There is a long way to go, but I am confident that this government will get it right.

SPEECH.PARA: Members who have been following debates relating to air transport and airports in this country, particularly in the Sydney region, would know that time and time again I have made it my business to represent my constituents on these subjects whenever such a piece of legislation makes its way into the parliament. I ask the member for Prospect to stick as close as possible to the main aspect of the bill.
