I believe in those related purposes—particularly when you are talking about aviation and the insurance of people and the liability of airport carriers—other concerns should also be mentioned, especially when in this particular debate the legislation has not gone far enough. That is why I believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when I put forward concerns that have been expressed both in this place and in the other house about the anxieties of people in western Sydney, I have a right, as my constituents would ask and demand, to be heard accordingly.
—But tell them that the Labor Party supports Badgerys Creek.

—I am convinced that those people in the Main Committee who are now objecting to this bill—and others who aren't present—believe that people in the western suburbs have crawled out of some primeval swamp. Why else would we choose to make our homes in western Sydney? Perhaps the member for North Sydney would agree with me: why should I live in western Sydney rather than in some renovated pad in swinging North Sydney? I made that choice.
—Swinging? We don't swing in North Sydney.

—The people in western Sydney are not asking for any special favours either in this bill before the House today or in other considerations but they would like their concerns expressed very clearly. I believe, as their representative, I have that right before this Main Committee as well as in the House of Representatives unless we are just trying to stop all debate on any issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I have tried repeatedly, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are well aware, to get the message across to people on both sides of the parliament that what the people of western Sydney want is perfectly reasonable. My constituents want to be shown the same consideration as has already been exhibited to the people in the inner city areas.

All the people of western Sydney are asking for is that the sins which have been brought about the noise and health problems which currently surround Kingsford Smith airport, for example, are not visited upon them with an airport at Badgerys Creek. As the plans now stand, this is the only thing we can see happening. We will see a 24‐hour international airport with the capacity to handle 360,000 operations per year built on the doorstep of Sydney's most populous region, and it is only going to bring the same terrible side effects now commonly associated with Kingsford Smith.

These are our concerns. Why is it so hard for the member for North Sydney to understand, appreciate or take those concerns on board? I believe I have continually shown respect to those whose opinions differ from mine. I will continue to do that. When we have a bill such as the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 before the House and when we are concerned about the rights of those people utilising air transport, surely the members who have constituents aggrieved by noise problems created by Kingsford Smith airport do not—I emphasise—want to inflict similar problems on a 24‐hour‐a‐day basis on the people living in my community or in your community, Mr Deputy Speaker, or in any of the communities in western Sydney.
Mr Hockey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for North Sydney to order.

—Who in their right mind would want to do that? That is the question I offer to the member for North Sydney: who would want to repeat the mistakes of the past? But the member for North Sydney, followed by his colleague the member for Lowe, and people of their ilk, just do not seem to care. Their prejudices and their contempt have been nailed firmly to the mast. There is even a greater problem for these two particular gentlemen. How can we expect the member for North Sydney and the member for Lowe—and I am glad the member for North Sydney is here—in their capacity on the Howard government's Sydney Airport Community Forum, to offer unbiased advice to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) on Sydney's second airport which, let us not forget, is a major part of the role of the board, when we know how little they care about the effect building an international airport is going to have on the lifestyles, happiness and health of those of us who live in western Sydney?

SPEECH.PARA: In September, the member for Lowe stood in parliament and said:

. . . no‐one should be under any misapprehension that the Howard government is anything but firmly and decisively committed to a new 24 hour international airport in the Sydney basin, and that is at Badgerys Creek. The die is cast. There is no going back. It is all systems go.

The member for North Sydney has not been very far behind, making similar comments both in and outside the House advertising his single‐minded determination to build Badgerys Creek. He has vehemently attacked those who would question his conviction and has poured scorn on our concerns. I am sure he appreciates those words. He is sitting here.

I am sure that the member for North Sydney and the member for Lowe are very proud of their words. I am sure they do not shrink from them. I am sure they are very determined in the way in which they go about their business. They think that comments such as these will win them basic support in their electorates. I am sure of that. I believe that others making similar calls think that. However, the fact that they do not resile from their prejudices, even in their most public of statements, really serves my point perfectly.

Surely the people of western Sydney have a right to expect the Howard government is being advised about Badgerys Creek in a manner that is sensitive to their needs and concerns. The people of western Sydney have a right to expect that, just as airport passengers have liability insurance covered—as this bill outlines correctly and astutely—those who have the ear of our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development will display at least a modicum of consideration as to how an international airport will affect their lives so dramatically.
Judging by the comments here today and elsewhere by the member for North Sydney and the continuing comments by the member for Lowe, the Howard government does not think we deserve that right.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the member for Grayndler? What about the member for Kingsford‐Smith?

—We may well be debating liability insurance for airline passengers. Where is the insurance for my constituents to protect them against the ruthless single‐mindedness of the members for North Sydney and Lowe in getting Badgerys Creek international airport built with no thought for the consequences? The EIS process regarding Badgerys Creek, flawed as I believe it is, has not yet been completed, yet the members for North Sydney and Lowe would have the bulldozers and the concrete mixers out there by lunchtime if they could. Never mind the EIS.
—It means 60,000 jobs. You've got no interest in jobs, Janice.

—If they could, they would have the whole operation finished by Christmas. In particular, the form of the member for North Sydney on this issue has been really concerning and should not pass without closer scrutiny. He recently made some virulent attacks on colleagues of mine in the Labor Party who have shown the good sense to take a step back on Badgerys Creek and look at the issue from a new angle. Make no mistake, the member for North Sydney has castigated—I repeat, castigated—those people from pillar to post simply because they had the courage to stand up and speak about the change of heart which has occurred among their constituents over Badgerys Creek during the last few years.

SPEECH.PARA: This founding member of the John Stuart Mill Society, a man who likes to be seen as championing the cause of small `l' liberalism in Australia, is an arch authoritarian on this issue. He wants us to blindly follow his view that we should build that airport at Badgerys Creek and that we should do it now. The member for North Sydney has exposed himself and sitting here today has shown us time and again the hypocrite he is on this issue. He ridicules colleagues of mine on this side of politics for rethinking their positions, for concluding that Badgerys Creek is not an appropriate site for an international airport, when underneath all the vitriol, behind the very hairy‐chested performances in and outside the House, he knows what they are saying is the truth.

In August last year, the member for North Sydney was not as gung‐ho for Badgerys Creek as he is now. In an interview with the Australian newspaper on 31 August 1996, he was asked whether Sydney's second international airport should be built at Holsworthy or Badgerys Creek. The member for North Sydney answered:
I personally do favour Holsworthy over Badgerys Creek because primarily Badgerys Creek is a land‐locked airport.
We did not actually have the liability insurance even before us at that time. He was further quoted:

One of the advantages of (the existing Kingsford Smith airport) is for half the airport (aircraft) fly over water and that is the same with Holsworthy where half the airport runs off to national park or into the sea.
Badgerys Creek, no matter where you fly, at some stage you'll be flying over residential homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call the House to order. I have been fairly lenient. It is a wide ranging debate. The member is probably transgressing somewhat, but no more than other members have. I call the members on the government side to stop interjecting and I ask the member for Prospect to address her remarks through the chair.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and as always, I address my remarks through the chair, particularly on a bill such as this. We have for some time now been saying that the civil aviation legislation is something we support and is something we welcome coming into the parliament. Of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you have said, it is a wide‐ranging debate. It has been pursued by previous speakers in this debate in some wide‐ranging comments which I would like to avail myself of as well. In speaking to the legislation, I could not let it go without making further comments. Obviously the member for North Sydney forgets what he said but I would like to keep on reminding him. My guess is that he would like to forget because he has his eyes on a prize such as a step up the rung, perhaps for a more senior position in his party—God forbid they should win the next election—or perhaps he has his heart on some other political bauble. Whatever it is, the member for North Sydney has been exposed, I believe, as a politician willing to betray his own principles and his own belief that Badgerys Creek is an inferior site for an international airport, stated clearly and unambiguously to the Australian newspaper, for the sake of getting ahead in Canberra. He has said it repeatedly. Worse still, in doing so he is willing to sell the futures of 1.4 million people living in western Sydney down the river because of that lack of principle. He deserves strong condemnation for that fact.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. That is an outright lie. That is wrong. I never made that allegation and I ask the member for Prospect to withdraw that.
—If offence has been taken, I would ask the member for Prospect to give consideration to withdrawing that statement.

—I will withdraw anything that I have said that may offend the member for North Sydney, Mr Deputy Speaker. Everything I have said about the member for North Sydney, he has said himself in public news media. I withdraw it.
—Order! I ask the member for Prospect also, as we are getting close to the end of the debate, to stick strictly to the legislation that we are debating.

—I withdraw. I completely withdraw because I would not like to offend the member for North Sydney by reiterating, in this debate today regarding civil aviation legislation amendments, the comments that he has made. I am talking about 31 August 1996. I am not talking about two years ago. But I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker, most unreservedly. I would not like to offend the member for North Sydney in any way, shape or form if he feels that by the comments that he has made in the past to the public press and media he does not sell the people that live in western Sydney down the drain. I would certainly never offend the member for North Sydney by even implying that those comments about Holsworthy being the number one site for him, because Badgerys Creek is—
—Order! The member for Prospect, take your seat. Point of order, Parliamentary Secretary.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, we have had nearly 18 minutes of this prattle. Would you ask the honourable member please to return to something that is fundamental to the safety of people flying in this country and ask her just to really give us all a big surprise and spend two minutes talking about this bill.
—Order! I will ask the member for Prospect to confine her remarks to the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 .

—I take your remarks on board. I would say to the parliamentary secretary (Mr Ronaldson) presently at the table that I have repeatedly referred back to the bill. You overlook this fact by your point of order. You have just come back in. But if you would like to read the Hansard on my opening remarks—I do not intend repeating them—I have stated repeatedly that, while we are supporting the bill, previous speakers have used the vehicle as an avenue in which to bring the concerns of their constituents forward to this parliament. I am saying in this debate that the parliamentary secretary, the member for North Sydney and their ilk do not grant the same right to the people representing western Sydney to bring their constituents' concerns before the parliament. I will continue to raise them whether I upset, annoy or intrigue the honourable members. I will also, in this bill—
—Order! I would ask all members to make their remarks through the chair and not to each other.

—Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will continue in every piece of legislation dealing with our airports, the structure of our airports or the insurance liability of our airport passengers to bring the concerns of my constituents forward in this parliament. I am elected to do that. If that offends any member, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, including the member for North Sydney, they have got a long row to hoe because I will continually be here to remind them of the public statements they make repeatedly about Holsworthy being a better choice because Badgerys Creek is landlocked.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be there continually to remind them, when they bring up insurance legislation, that there is no mention of any insurance liabilities to the people whose lives are going to be so dramatically changed by the decision to build an airport at Badgerys Creek. If the member for North Sydney, or the member for Lowe, or anyone sitting on the government benches finds that offensive, I am sorry but they are going to continue to be offended, because I will not shut up and I will continue to represent my constituents in this place. SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—What about the bill?

This bill is an important step forward in ensuring that we have a fairer, more efficient and, of course, safer environment in which aviation can proceed in Australia. The first point, and the main point, is that it is the policy of the Australian Labor Party to put in place an international airport at Badgerys Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Stick to the bill. Where's your bill?
—I think it is terribly important that we recognise that there are huge inconsistencies—

But of course safety is the primary concern when there are changes to flight paths put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The flight paths which start on 4 December are a result of over 18 months of community consultation with thousands and thousands of submissions from the broader community, and we overlaid on those submissions the concepts and principles that we went to the last election promising: that is, a fair sharing of the noise—of course safety was the primary concern—trying to increase the number of movements over non‐residential areas and water and, importantly, providing respite. That is what we promised, and it is a vital concern. I reiterate that safety is laid on top of that. I would like to publicly thank CASA for their support in the drafting and the preparations for the flight paths that come into effect on 4 December.

But the fundamental problem is that the congestion at Kingsford Smith airport is increasing. The fact is that there are more planes coming in. With that result, all we are doing as a government is putting in place what was Labor policy—that is, the commitment to a second airport at Badgerys Creek. TITLE.XREF: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND FOOD AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALKER.NAME: Ms WORTH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

In reading this very brief speech, I mention the cooperation that I have received from the opposition, the shadow minister and his counterpart in the Senate, Senator Forshaw, in ensuring that this legislation is debated in this session, so that ANZFA can get on with some very important business. We have just experienced a bit of heat in this chamber. Normally legislation is debated here without disagreement. I am pleased that is the case in the debate on this bill.

This bill makes a number of technical and minor policy amendments to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991. These amendments support this government's regulatory reform agenda as they help the authority take control of its business and prioritise its agenda. The amendments proposed in this bill also improve the management structure and capacity of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority in splitting the roles of chairperson and chief executive.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority is a Commonwealth statutory authority which develops uniform food standards for Australia and New Zealand and undertakes related functions. It operates under a unique Commonwealth, New Zealand, state and territory partnership arrangement based upon a 1991 cooperative agreement in Australia and a 1995 treaty with New Zealand. These arrangements see standards, developed through the Authority's statutory processes, uniformly adopted by reference and without amendment into state, territory and New Zealand laws.

The amendments seek to facilitate the cooperative arrangements between the governments and, at the same time, retain the community consultation, accountability, openness, transparency and timeliness which characterise the authority's operations. They give the authority greater flexibility in its operations, simplify and clarify its procedures, and confer powers appropriate to a modern statutory authority.

These amendments have a long history. They have been proposed in a number of internal and external reviews of the authority's processes over a number of years. While they are essentially administrative housekeeping, they are important in giving effect to this government's commitment to its regulatory reform agenda.

The authority currently has a full‐time chairperson who is also the chief executive. Amendments proposed in this bill will separate these two roles into a part‐time chair and a full‐time chief executive. This improved management structure will bring more accountability to the authority's operations and will enhance its capacity to provide leadership within the cooperative Commonwealth, New Zealand, state and territory food partnership.

The reforms in this bill, while relatively minor, will smooth the way for the authority as it undertakes its important regulatory reform program over the next few years. The amendments are about simplicity and clarity. They are about flexibility and modern management. They streamline and replace prescription with guidance. They support better government. These are matters which this government will continue to hold dear. I present the explanatory memorandum and the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in rising today to support the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . The purpose of the bill is to simplify the procedures and broaden the approach of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. The proposed amendments will provide to this important statutory body the flexibility to implement modern management practices so it can continue its regulatory reform program.

SPEECH.PARA: As the legislation stands, the authority is labouring under administrative obligations which determine the assessment process of variations to the Food Standards Code. In the past there have been complex processes used to handle food standards applications from industry. The authority's progress in reform has been impeded by the lack of flexibility to manage its resources. The proposed amendments will change the regulations which govern the authority, to streamline the assessment process as well as expand its powers and function.

The authority was established in 1991 to provide a national focus for the setting of food standards and food safety. The main goals of the authority are to ensure that there is uniformity in food standards across Australia through cooperation between governments, industry and the community in developing a safe and wholesome food supply.

In 1995 this role was expanded when parliament passed amending legislation which enabled New Zealand to be represented on the board of the authority and within the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, and so the Australia New Zealand Food Authority was born. It operates under a unique Commonwealth, New Zealand, state and territory partnership arrangement which sees a joint food standards setting system which accepts without variation the recommendations of the authority.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority plays a key role in our food industry by developing food standards, coordinating national food surveillance and recall systems, conducting research and assessing policies about imported food, and developing codes of practice within industry. It is the work of the authority which is largely responsible for Australia having one of the highest food safety records in the world. Our reputation for safe, clean and healthy food has been built up over a long period of time and is envied by many of our trading partners.

The issue of food standards and the way they are determined is paramount to my electorate of McEwen, where the food industry is the cornerstone of many local communities. McEwen is fortunate to have a strong and diverse food industry, which includes wine and grape growing, horticulture, sheep, poultry, beef, dairy industries and aquaculture. Any measures to streamline the operations of the authority and simplify procedures will have a direct benefit for producers within these industries, especially those in the electorate of McEwen.

The Australia New Zealand National Food Authority Act 1991 governs how the authority operates. Under its provisions the authority is required to follow complex processes for handling food standard applications. Anyone can make an application to the authority for a change to a standard. When an application is received, the authority embarks on a lengthy procedure which involves a preliminary assessment, public submissions, a full assessment and inquiry. It then makes a recommendation to its council of Commonwealth, state, territory and New Zealand ministers, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council. It can take up to a year from the time of application until a recommendation is made. Once ministerial approval is granted, the variation to the standard is gazetted and it becomes part of the Food Standards Code.

The procedures to vary the Food Standards Code are complex and arduous. Under current legislation, the authority has to commit all available resources necessary to complete the assessments within the required 12-month period, without taking into account the relative public or commercial importance or value of each application. In practice, this has meant valuable resources have been diverted from important reform tasks such as the review of the Food Standards Code.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority is embarking on three major tasks as part of its regulatory reform program. It is conducting a three‐year standards review work program which aims to set priorities for reviewing food standards up to the year 2000, when a joint Australia‐New Zealand standards code is due to be completed.

The new code is planned to be simplified and more generic, moving away from the prescriptive standards of the present system which are so detailed that variations based on safe innovations in food require new standards to be continually set up. For example, there is one standard for jam, one for jelly, one for spreads, et cetera. Under the review, wherever possible, the authority will replace standards regulating individual foods with standards which apply across classes of food. In addition, the authority is working towards the introduction of uniform hygiene standards and a review of food regulation across federal, state and local government.

These reforms are clearly an important priority, especially following the recent series of major lapses in industry hygiene. We all remember the headlines which littered the press earlier this year referring to salmonella outbreaks and food poisoning. Recently, there was another food scare in Melbourne where nearly 60 people became ill.
Despite the urgency for these reforms to be completed, the authority is bogged down in tedious, drawn out procedures to vary standards. Authority chairperson, Ms McCaughey, has said:

The processes or the obligations that are specified in the current ANZFA Act mean that the very infinite resources of the authority must in all cases be devoted to assessing applications to vary the food standards code ahead of the other important reform tasks, irrespective of priority or merit.

This can no longer be allowed to continue if Australia is to maintain its reputation as having one of the highest standards of food safety in the world. The proposed amendments in this bill will allow the authority to plan, manage and prioritise its workload, smoothing the way for it to continue its all important reform program.

The amendments streamline the administration of applications to vary the code by moving away from process for process's sake. The bill aims to simplify the directions for information required to support an application, giving applications more guidance and flexibility.

The bill also proposes to streamline the procedure for giving the reasons why proposed new food standards have been rejected. Under present legislation, this automatically requires a formal, lengthy statement to be gazetted. The amendments will require the authority to publish only the means to obtain a statement. The statement may not need to be prepared unless it has been requested, therefore saving the authority time and resources but still retaining openness and transparency, which characterise the authority's operations.

In order to further reduce the time taken to develop new standards, the bill proposes that the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council must make a decision within six months of receiving a recommendation from the food authority. The time period could be extended if the council requires more information from the authority. At the moment there is no such time limit for the council, and decisions frequently take longer than six months. According to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee's report, the worst delay so far encountered has been an extraordinary 23 months. The need for change is obvious and welcomed by industry and the authority alike.

The amendments will also give the authority the flexibility to extend the 12‐month time limit where decisions are challenged, with an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal providing an important safeguard. Finalising applications to change the food code will be further streamlined by allowing the authority to use an assessment, technical information or, where applicable, evidence obtained from public inquiries which is supplied by government agencies in making a decision. This will fast‐track applications where a suitable resource of reliable information has already been prepared, once again saving time and resources.

The bill updates the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act to broaden the powers and functions of the authority as a modern statutory body. Under the bill, the authority will be given scope for greater involvement in food matters. The authority will be able to increase its role in relation to food education and in relation to the important issues of labelling and nutrition. The authority will also be given the ability to market its expertise commercially.

These amendments simplify and clarify the procedures to vary the food code by allowing the authority the ability to prioritise its work and to fast‐track applications. The bill smooths the way for the authority to dedicate its important resources to its regulatory reforms.

In the lead‐up to the year 2000, the authority must be given the opportunity to dedicate its attention to its work in reviewing food standards, introducing uniform hygiene standards and reforming food regulations across federal, state and local governments. This bill represents a commitment from this government to the authority's reform agenda and protects Australian's reputation as having one of the highest standards of food safety in the world. This is a reputation which is vital to food processors, such as those within my electorate of McEwen, many of whom depend on this reputation for their livelihoods. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition agreed to treat the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 as non‐controversial after the government agreed to drop proposed amendments relating to employment conditions and fee charging powers. The bill involves a number of administrative changes, including a recent government amendment which establishes the position of a full‐time chief executive officer and allows for the chair to become a part‐time position as a consequence. The opposition do not oppose these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The main change to the original bill, which the government has accepted, is that it must abandon its attempts to undermine the employment conditions for employees of the food authority. The original explanatory memorandum stated that the bill would allow the food authority to employ staff on its own terms and conditions. That might be standard Howard government code for bypassing the existing terms and conditions of public sector staff.

The opposition has made it clear that it will not accept these sorts of attacks on public servants, so we are particularly pleased that the government has now agreed to drop its plans to allow the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to ignore standard public sector terms and conditions for its employees. The government has also agreed to drop a number of proposed amendments relating to the powers of the food authority to charge fees. The opposition is pleased that the government has apparently responded to our concerns that the fee charging powers were not sufficiently specific and could, in the worse case situation, allow the government to withdraw its funding to ANZFA and force the food authority to pick up the shortfall through higher charges. As a result of the government's agreement to make these changes in these amendments, the opposition is happy to allow passage of the bill.

I conclude by stating that I am very grateful for the detailed work my colleague Senator Michael Forshaw has contributed in dealing with this piece of legislation on behalf of the opposition. As I indicated at the beginning, the opposition has agreed to treat the bill as non‐controversial and will support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow the good example of my colleague the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and keep my remarks brief. I believe if I do so it might be possible for us to have this legislation passed this morning. I will endeavour to achieve just that end.
—It will be early this afternoon.

—I beg your pardon. I thank the member for Dobell. It will be early this afternoon. As all speakers have indicated, this is a non‐controversial piece of legislation. We are dealing with the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill. This is a statutory authority. The changes that are proposed in the bill before the House are both of an administrative and housekeeping nature, as outlined by the shadow minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important, however, to recognise that this organisation and the changes that this bill introduces allow a great deal of cooperation to exist between both Australia and New Zealand, particularly on the question of food standards. The member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) made much of the importance of food standards. I think it is repetitious for me to venture into that area this afternoon, but the bottom line remains that food standards are of the utmost importance to every Australian producer and processor and much of our reputation as an effective exporter has been built on the image that we have as a clean and green country.

It is almost two years since the treaty between Australia and New Zealand was signed on 5 December 1995. The treaty, which is the background to this legislation, had bipartisan support and provided for the establishment of a joint standards agency, the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, with officers and operations in both Australia and New Zealand. This was a landmark achievement which will set standards across two countries and, by removing regulatory barriers to trade in food, work towards creating a larger single market. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority unites the nine governments of Australia and New Zealand in open, consultative and efficient processes for setting and revising national, and now bilateral, food standards.

The creation of the authority has led to food standards that are nationally uniform and are becoming gradually less prescriptive and more open to modern food technologies. The authority is currently in the process of building a completely revised food standards code to move us towards fewer, simpler, more generic standards to better meet industry and consumer needs and harmonise food standards between Australia and New Zealand. Standards developed by the new authority are now recommended to a joint council of health ministers known as the Australia New Zealand Foods Standards Council. It comprises ministers from the Commonwealth, New Zealand and the states and territories. When food standards are adopted by the council they will be published in both countries and be adopted by reference and without amendment into the food legislation in Australia and New Zealand. It is a model that has attracted worldwide attention.

Of particular significance, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that the model removes a number of trade access issues which have been frustrating Australian exporters, reduces compliance costs and provides for a larger and more secure market in processed foods. The system will ensure that closer economic relations with New Zealand remain at the cutting edge of trade policy. It provides a worthy example for similar processes of trade facilitation in the APEC region and in the wider multilateral context.

It is in this area of removing trade barriers and increasing trade access that I want to make a brief comment before concluding my remarks. As the representative of a largely horticulturally focused electorate, I have had instances of producers, particularly of mandarins, having difficulty gaining access to New Zealand. It is true to say that the New Zealanders have been bound by the arrangements entered into under our various trade protocols but that they have in fact frustrated my exporters by using a number of non‐tariff barriers and by slowing down the rate at which these mandarin processors gain access to New Zealand. The particular group I have in mind is just over the border outside my electorate in Victoria and has therefore been deemed to be in a fruit fly threatened area although in reality fruit fly has never entered that area. The nearest outbreak would be at least 120 kilometres away but for all of that they found it difficult to gain access. I think the level of cooperation that ought to have been extended by our trans‐Tasman neighbours has not been extended and I would therefore challenge the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to look at not only the standards of our food but also the way in which non‐tariff barriers have been used to frustrate some Australian growers.

I am also aware of an instance in the electorate represented by the member for Murray (Mrs Stone), who is not now participating in the debate, where protocols for tomatoes to be exported from Australia to New Zealand had in fact not reflected the modern tomato growing standards that apply in Australia and where, in a number of instances, tomato growers had found difficulty getting access because the protocols had been established for varieties that have now been superseded.

I would join previous speakers, Mr Deputy Speaker, in commending this bill to the House, indicating the support of the parliament for these changes and wishing the authority every success as it enhances the reputation that Australians have as the processors and producers of quality food.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is not controversial in any shape or form but it does provide the opportunity to focus on the role of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority and the role that it plays between governments, industry and the community in developing a safe and wholesome food supply. I recently had the privilege to launch national food safety awareness week in my electorate at the opening of the Barton TAFE office in Bendigo which is putting on programs for the safe, competent and efficient handling of food products in the Bendigo region.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the responsibility for food safety awareness is highlighted. The work of the Food Safety Campaign Group—which brings together a wide range of groups representing all levels of government, industry and consumers, with a common purpose of raising broad community awareness about food safety—is particularly important, in view of recent occurrences in Victoria, where people have suffered as a result of contaminated food which, in one instance there, led to the death of some people. That really did highlight how important it is to be aware of the need to have clean and safe food, particularly in the production of it but also in the handling of it. The responsibility for keeping Australia's food supply safe is one that we all share: primary producers, manufacturers, restaurateurs, food outlet owners, regulators, and even household cooks—as I try to be at times in my own home—need to know how important it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a sensitive new age guy.

—Truly, I am trying to be. But it is important. With all of the matters that are coming under the authority of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, it is important to remember just how serious these outbreaks of food poisoning and food contamination can be. We had an unfortunate series of happenings in Australia recently, of which every consumer and every producer should take note. Anyone who has any role in the food industry should take note of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to highlight the key messages of National Food Safety Awareness Week. They are simple but they are important. You should always keep hot food steaming hot and keep cold food refrigerated under 4 degrees centigrade. You should wash your hands thoroughly. My wife, who was formerly a nurse, and my eldest daughter, who is a nurse, say that the most important point is to wash hands thoroughly on every occasion, when handling food or in any other matter related to health.

Keep kitchen utensils clean and cook food properly. Consumers have a real and important role to play in the food safety effort. It is estimated that 20 per cent of food poisoning incidents in Australia can be attributed to the mishandling of food in the home: not reheating food to the correct temperature, or cutting up cooked and raw food using the same chopping board or the same knife. It is important that people are aware of the importance of food safety and that they apply those principles in their daily lives.
Debate (on motion by Mr Nairn) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government provide funding to the aged care industry to enable all facilities to meet on‐costs for employee matters rather than the existing funding arrangements for accommodation and funding categories 1 to 4.
(2) Will facilities incur deficits if they are required to meet the additional costs themselves.
(3) Will the Government enable facilities to set fees to cover the costs referred to in part (1).
(4) Will groups be able to claim an exempt status, opt out of the system and charge fees as they see fit; if so, does this concern the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Government funding for residential aged care is a contribution to the cost of care. Under the previous nursing home system, providers were fully reimbursed for the salary on‐costs they incurred—provided they kept full records and submitted a detailed annual claim form. This form, which was used to reconcile nursing and personal care staff costs as well as salary on‐costs, ran to more than 30 pages.

In contrast, under the previous hostel system, funding for salary on‐costs was fully integrated into the overall rates structure. Subsidies were not acquitted and providers did not have to put up with such a burden of red tape and form filling.

The Government has simplified the administration of all residential care funding. Funding for all levels of care is paid as a straightforward, non‐acquitted subsidy that addresses all the costs of delivering care for all categories of need. In the transition from the old system, funds that would have been paid to nursing homes to reimburse their salary on‐costs have been incorporated into the rates for higher levels of care. The rates for lower levels of care continue to address salary on‐costs in the same way as hostel subsidies did previously.

(2) Salary on‐costs are addressed in every category of the rates structure. They are not additional costs. Funding is paid continuously, as the costs are incurred. Former nursing homes will be protected from excessive deficits in the transition from full cost reimbursement by a system of capping losses. These caps will be initially set to protect the 5 per cent of homes with the highest costs, with the proportion protected reducing over 5 years as the caps are phased out.
(3) No. All residents pay the same basic fee and additional fees are determined under an income test based solely on the capacity of a resident to pay additional charges.

(4) It is open to service providers to withdraw from Commonwealth funding and regulatory arrangements and operate independently, as they see fit. This would necessitate opting out of the whole system, not single elements of it. There, would, of course, be consequences in such a decision for the approval of care places that they hold. It would be unlikely, however, for service providers to make such a decision, especially nursing home providers whose residents are mostly at the high care levels. The average Commonwealth subsidy for a nursing home is about $30,000 per place per year.

Opting out may be a more realistic option for providers at the very low care levels (for example, there are significant numbers of supported accommodation houses, some of whom offer a level of personal care, outside Commonwealth funding arrangements). However, any reduction in the number of Commonwealth funded places in an area of need would be addressed by the planning system which controls the allocation of new places.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a speech by the Commissioner of Taxation in which the Commissioner indicated a strong desire to crack down on tax avoidance through the use of trusts.
(2) Does he support the views expressed by the Commissioner of Taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) I am aware of the speech given by the Commissioner of Taxation on 10 September 1997 that discussed the taxation treatment of trusts.

(2) As I indicated in a personal explanation to the House on 30 September 1997, the Government is always prepared to take appropriate action against abuses within the tax system, including through trusts.

In the 1997‐98 Budget, the Government announced that it would review the taxation of trusts to ensure that the taxation system deals with the modern day usage of trusts in an appropriate manner, and does not permit tax avoidance or undue tax minimisation. The Government also announced that before such a review the Treasury and Australian Taxation Office would release a discussion paper outlining the relevant tax issues and broad policy options.
